33 cl bottle. Very dark brown coloured with a medium sized tan head. Very complex and sweet. Malts, candied sugar, liqourice, caramel and various spices.

Had this on draught at a special Belgium event at Chappys in Dayton -- served in a special 6 oz wine-like tasting glass.  Dark brown amber with a brown head and some nice lacing. Dark fruit flavors, plums and dates in the aroma. Initially a bit of chocolate flavor that turns into black licorice taste. I dont normally like licorice, but it works well in this beer. Fruity and spicy tones such as plums, dates and raisins. Medium bodied, well carbonated. Delicious on its own, or would go well as a dessert beer. One of my favorites Belgium Christmas beers, what a pleasant surprise to see it available in the Spring.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2014 Bottle. Pours dark brown, with a shiny tan head. Sweet slightly phenolic nose. Cherries, berries and lots of marzipan in the aroma. Also some chocolate. Rather sweet like most Anker brews. Palate is smooth and silky, alcohol well hidden. Very good.
Re rate: tons and tons of star anise (anethole) / fennel
Tap. Dark ruby brown pour. Off white head. Faint sweet nose. Taste is cherries, oranges, caramel, and yeast. Very nice.

A clear dark brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of sweet caramal malts with fruits and several spices. The taste of carmel, and spices with a fine combination sweet, some bitter and spices. The aftertaste is mostly sweet.

Bottle. Best before 06/09/06.
Dark amber red with a beige head fastly disapearing. Intense malty nose, it has the coca cola nose that all dark carolus carries in my opinion, with candied oranges, figs, dates. Full body, super malty with a long malty and sweet finish. This beer must have had better days but Im impressed considering it was botlled in 2003 or 2004. No sign of overly oxydized beer here, just a bit one-dimensionnal, but its probably the age that did it. Nice winter warmer.

330ml Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Opaque, ruddy brown in colour with plenty of carbonation and a thick off-white head. Aroma of candy sugar, cinnamon and berry fruit. Sweet flavour, with more cherry fruit, liquorice and marzipan, before a dryish finish. Good.
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2010 een donkere boby met een voor mij niet zo lekkere drop smaak. en verder nog een kruidige smaak met een redelijk nutrale afdrong maar ook hier zit een lichte drop smaak.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 Re-rate 24 nov 2010. Dark brown, a bit of a red shine. Nice head, holds pretty decent at 1.5cm and sticks beautifull to the glass. Smell is yeast, fruit and spices. Very spiced. Taste is a bit overspiced, but still decent, and for a christmasbeer thats ok.

I shared this with MereLikesBeer, and this stuff was incredible. Im not usually a huge Belgian fan, I really enjoyed this beer. The aroma, mouthfeel, flavor, all were one hundred percent spot on. Honestly, THE perfect winter time ale, which would pare perfectly with an evening by the fire, or any other winter time activity. Cheers!

This beer is perfect.
It has a wonderful aroma - lots of spicy floral notes.  Quite a nice difference from typical holiday styles.  For me, it has more of a floral than a spice, also quite a bit of alcohol on the nose.
Its a beautiful chestnutty ruby color with a tan foamy head.  Not hazy, just perfect.
It tastes wonderful.  It has great body and is very well balanced.  Not too much hop, not too much malt, its creamy and seems almost buttery.  Lightly carbonated, and it has a nice light hop finish that is almost totally hidden by the alcohol.

Overall, its just a wonderful beer.  I feel the need to go pick some more up!

(bottle - 330 ml) Muddy brown pour with a very thin but long lasting tan head. Sweet aroma with a lot of malt, some fruits, some spice, and some caramel. I definitely smell some cherry and raisins. Flavor has a very fruity and spicy taste at the beginning. Almost like a fruitcake; slightly bready with sweet cherry and orange notes before moving to a malty and lightly bitter middle. Finishes with a hint of apple and raisin along with a very light bitterness. Alcohol is warming but not overpowering.

Bottle from Theatre of Wine. Brown pour with a fluffy beige head. Aromas of raisins, pear drops, raspberries, chocolate, dark malts, tons of fruit. Flavours of dark chocolate, banana, blackcurrants, toffee, raisins, sultanas. A fruity, throat warming, malt laden mound of lovlieness. Yum!

Pours off brown with generous white head. Very carbonated.

Nose is rich with brown spices, holiday dessert baking, some citrus and molasses.

Very full bodied with alcohol warmth, some curry powder, dessert spices, and ginger/cinnamon.

Finish is very long, with cocoa powder, and alcohol. Warms you up quite well.
Bottle, 33cl. Pours dark, with virtually no head. Liquourice predominating on the nose, and similar with the added complexity of dark fruits, caramel and spices on the palate. Well balanced overall.
Pours a deep dark brown, cola color, with a thin tan head. Aroma of malt, citrus, cherry. Taste has a hint of dark fruit, alcohol nicely concealed.

Beautiful beer on tap at the Malt House, wouldnt mind having a few of these: Pours a muddy dark copper colour with medium beige head. Aroma is very pleasent. Rich and full of many spices, carmel, oak and butterscotch. Taste hits you initially of some sort delectable treat- like a desert your mum would make. And then it smoothes out with the grape and caramel apple flavours finishing it off. Soft chocolate and raisin notes underlying the taste.

0.33l - Normally I shy away from holiday ales, but knowing this brewer I made an exception.  Im glad I did.  Red/black liquid under thick tan head, which turned into nice lace over time.  Dominant cherry nose.  Cherry dominated on palate, with chocolate and the warmth of the alcohol supporting.  Black Forest Cake in a glass, evoking like the Christmas. season.

07 bottle pours dark mahogany into a chalice with little creamy head and nice lacing.  Aroma of brown sugar, dates, raisins, vanilla.  Tastes is a pretty consistent blend of raisins, plumbs, sweet malt, pear.  Finishes slightly spicy with a decent touch of alcohol.  Creamy mouthfeel with low carbonation, full bodied.  Unfortunately, I found this very unbalanced as I was expecting much more from this brew.  In correspondence with the lack of balance, I found it sitting poorly in my stomach, something which does not happen to me when I drink beer.
I had this on New Years. The body is heavy. and thick.  Nicely spiced.  Aromas are spicy, of carmel, and figs or raisins.  The taste is about the same.  A very full beer.

Deep Brown in color with a thick,frothy beige head. Sweet cherry, caramel, fig and raisin intertwined on the nose. A quick hint of clove followed by some sweet dark fruits with a grapy finish.medium body with a  long finish,  The finest Belgium X-Mas Ale I have tasted

Deep ruby/brown colour with a big head that largely stayed the course. Aroma of spices and drak fruit . Tasted sweet, hints of toffee, caramel, vanilla, even tobacco. Wonderful spices and fruit tastes. Little bitter at the finish with a big burn but didnt really have a lastin g adftertaste. Full bodied. A very complex beer and pretty well balabnced. Took  me a few sips to get into it but soon appreciated its brilliance. Made it a merry Christmas alright!

Draft pour from the lovely Thirsty Monk in Asheville.  Pours gorgeous dark brown with huge creamy beige head. Nose of slight bananas, but more figs and raisins and -- WOW -- a huge licorice flavor. But not all spice; more the spice of anise, but the fruitiness of good licorice as well.  I have never been a huge licorice fan, but this was the perfect flavor.  Really, really nice.  Great palate; just a wonderful beer overall.

750 Bottle corked- Pours deep brown with average lacing and little head, aroma is bananas and alcohol. The flavor is sweet sugar, bananas, alcohol, of all the Belgian brews of this Christmas Eve night, St. Bernardus Abt 12 was by far the best, although you can not go wrong with a Belgium beer (for the most part).

On draught at Marble Arch, Manchester.  Strong aroma of cherry drops (sweets).  Very dark with tanned, long lasting head.  Couldnt stop myself from swirling and smelling this beer all the way to the end.  Lots of licorice and other spices to taste.  Merry Christmas indeed!

Poured brown and hazy into my Chimay glass with a thin tan layer of foam and decent lacing.  The aroma was malt, yeast and tons of "winter" spice like cinnamon and clove.  The flavor was dark fruits, rich malts and dry cinnamon.  Spices almost got distracting.  Nice warming rush of alcohol towards the end.  Medium bodied and well carbonated.   Just OK.

Pours a very deep and dark red giving up hues of red only when held up to a light.  A bit boozy in the nose.  Typical aromas of dark rich fruits and sweet malty molasses.  But theres a bit of chocolate at the end of the aroma.  Perhaps a touch of caramel as well.  Its grainy initially, but very rich indeed giving flavors of sweet molasses, candied sugar, dark plums, and a heavy chocolate taste on the palate.  The finish is a touch oily but rahter long on the tongue.  A rather complex beer but enjoyable at every level.

From a 750 ml bottle purchased in McCall, Idaho this poured a red to brown with a light tan head and good lacing.  Nose if of caramel malts and ripe fruits with raisins and banana. Medium body and smooth mouthfeel. The flavor is rich and sweet with lots of fruit nuances.  Good Christmas beer.

Tasted 12/27/09.  750ml cork and cage.  2008 Vintage.  First pour has a brown hue with amber highlights.  Spiraling eyeball of off-white head.  Aromas of caramel malts and citrus.  Bubblegum and port.  Cinnamon, toffee and toast.  Doughy and estery.  Solid nose!  Full bodied with a zesty effervescence and lovely Belgian yeast flavor.  Nice mix of perfumy citrus and bubblegum.  Solid malt bill with caramel and toffee undertones.  Touch cola and dark fruits.  Finish is lingering with both a tingling of the gums and an acidity of the tongue.  For the past five years, this has been my favorite Belgian Noel.  Surprised that I havent jotted down any tasting notes before now.  Guess I was enjoying it too much!

Pours a dark red brown color with a nice tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, liquorice and spices.  Flavors of roasted malts, liquorice, dry fruits, raisains and a hint of banana and spices.  Good carbonation, sweet and bitter dry finish, with a spicy lasting in mouth.  The liquorice is quite persistant as you drink.   Very nice ballance of flavors, nice Xmas brew.

(Bottle, 2008 vintage) Poured deep reddish brown with small, fizzy and white head. Aroma contained dark fruits, malts, molassess and bit of raisin. Palate was quite dry and full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were dried plum, dark fruits, malts, aniseed and quite mild bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and mildly bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 Poured a deep amber color with a small off white head that lasted throughout. Licorice, dark fruit and alcohol aroma. Sweet flavors of black licorice, roasted malt and fig. Was a little bit thin. A very tasty beer, the mouthfeel could have been fuller though.

Tatse this beer more times. Now end november 75 cl.from Vanden Bussche.
Dark brown with a small, beige head. 
Aroma fruits, malts, little yeast. 
Medium to full body.
Taste dark fruit, yeast, alcoholic, sweet, roasted malts.
Good.
A very flat beer. Not to my liking. Lots of sugar, candy, anisseed flavors. No aftertaste.
Poured in a trappist glass.  Dark brown with a thin white head.  Aroma of dark fruit and a little funk.  Taste is boozy with some of the fig/date flavor and all of the booze at the end.  Decent brew

bottle.  pours a hazy brown copper hue with a creamy tan head.  Initial aroma is a healthy dose of dates, raisins,  spices.  Flavor adds a nice layer of rum cake, plum skin, and tiny complementary bit of booze.  Tasty stuff.  would drink again!

750 ml bottle 11 oz sample. Strong aroma of banana, less so of raisins. Pours reddish brown with a medium head, good lacing. Sweet tasting, maybe overbearingly so, just a tad. Palate is fully carbonated, medium bodied. Interesting beer for the holidays, but not as good as the St. Bernardus I tried earler tonight. The aroma kicks that beers ass however, given the higher score.

very nice, brown color, not much head or lacing but typical belgian fragrance with ginger and cinnammon hints and more spcy taste, raisens and waxy feel.  a nice level of carbonation that contributes along with the alcohol just enough

Tap at Sunswick. Oh my God - licorice! Poured black like cola with a medium, white head. Nose of licorice, sweet fruits and light malts. At first, the flavor was ALL licorice. Sweet, sweet licorice. After a few sips, My palette had adjusted to the intense licorice and I caught some nice, sweet malt notes and some dark fruits. Medium in body and lightly carbonated. Kind of sticky and syrup-like. Pretty good overall.

good lacing. mostly diminishing. thick, flat and brown body. average, off-white head. aroma: chocolate, alcohol, ginger and nutmeg. if: moderate bitter and sweet. ff: heavy bitter and moderate sweet; long duration. palate: full body, soft carbonation, creamy texture and metallic and light alcoholic finish. 180s; cerveja condimentada, complexa, com bom aquecimento alcoólico
A wonderful holiday beer that is different from most. Spices in this beer generate a wonderfully complex taste that creates excitement from this brown ale.

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown beer with a little beige head. Typical sweet and malty smell, also light fruity and light spicy. The taste is nice malty, sweet and light spicy. espite the high alcohol percentage (10,5%), this is a very easy drinking beer and the alcohol is hidden very well. Overal lacking a bit in pallet and a typical Christmas beer, but one of the better Christmas beers anyway.

bottle from Village de la Bière Strasbourg France. Deep brown colour with a small, but persistant beige head. Aroma of dried fruit and alpine herbs. Full-bodied, intensively malty with lots of raisins, plums, dried fruit, nuts and herbs and spices (reminding me of a certain Swiss candy). Very complex and deep. A beer to enjoy and savour slowly on a cold and snowy winter evening.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a mostly clear chestnut with a moderate light amber head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left bits of lace.  Very pleasant aroma of sweet malt, licorice, raisins and alcohol.  The flavor begins with a solid dose of sweet malt.  This is followed by a raisin flavor that tastes like they have been macerated in brandy.  A strong licorice flavor then emerges bringing all of this to a conclusion.  A bit boozey at the finish as well.  Medium bodied.  Very tasty!

Murky reddish brown, thin beige head. Dark fruit - plum, prune, raisin -dominate the nose. Lots of rich fruity notes in the flavor, plus tobacco, leather. Subtle hints of molasses and honey, then caramel or brown sugar. Very tasty. This is a 2007 or 2006 bottle.
Bottle sampled at Grapes of Mirth Winter Beers Tasting. This was one of my favorites. Nice aroma of malt, nuts, and oranges. Flavor was figs. Caramel, syrup, a bit of hops, and a hint of sweetness.
Bottle at Ølkonsortiet. Dark brown with brown head. Aroma nice sweet malt, much licorice or anise. Taste very dominated by licorice, maybe a little like Pannepot. Good stuf.

Year 2008.
Somewhat this beer smells and tastes of Christmas. Candies fruit skin, liquorice, raisins. Good after taste. Fits this cold snowy day we are having in Mechelen.

Draught, New Oxford, Salford.  Dense super dark brown colour with minimal head. Sweet , spicy aroma with notes of anise and santa only knows what else. Slides down nice n smooth , with the abv reasonably masked.  Warming,  soothing medicinal flavour, that contained an ole eap of spices, dark choc, brandy sodden dark fruit, licorice. Pretty rich stuff, but bloody tasty with it.

330 mL bottle at St. Veronus.  (bb Nov 11).  Deep chestnut brown with a small, short-lived beige head.  Rich aroma of candied fruit, molasses, and brown spice.  Flavour is like Christmas cake with hot rum sauce.  And licorice.  Quite sweet.  Some alcohol warmth in the throat and belly.  One of the fullest beers Ive tried.  A nice treat.

Dark brown beer with a beige head. Aroma isnt all too formed. Taste is of licorish (dutch: drop) with a hint of mint as in after-dinner-chocolate-mints. Palate is very refined, a lot comes by. The end is the typical candy-sugar that caracterise all the Gouden Carolus beers.

After the beer was served in the glass there was found a lasting quantity not wall adhesive light brown foam collar which was fine and evenly of structure. The beer also contained no carbonic acid in the glass.

 The beer has a  thick brown color and a light acid taste. The after tast of the beer is hoppybitter with a anise-like touch. This beer smells spicy.

750 mL bottle. Yeasty aroma features plum, spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice), and vegetable (celery, spinach) scents. Complex and interesting smell but not entirely what I would call good. Pours a maroon-brown with a ruby hue. Hazy liquid with a modicum of effervescence. Large amount of long-lasting, uneven, tan head. Produces nice lacing. Very cool appearance. At first, tastes excessively sweet yet "beery" and dull, but the taste improves greatly upon multiple sips; takes some getting used to but ultimately pretty good. Meaty, umami flavor. Lemon, spice (especially pepper), and toffee tastes. Boozy; calls bourbon to mind. Herbal finish, like a vegetable picked right off the top of the soil. Tasty, long, dry, spicy aftertaste. Medium body. Fluffy and oily in the palate. Lively on the tongue. Gouden Carolus Noël is a complex, interesting, and unique beer. It is unmistakably Belgian. Perhaps I didnt like it as much as this score indicates, but I greatly appreciated it, and I am very glad I tried it.
330 ml bottle red brown colored beer with a tiny head aroma caramel fruit sweet spices taste is sweet and fruity little bit spices and some alcohol.

This one pours a dark, semi-translucent brown, definitely a good start. Aroma is strong, sharp and more like a good rum than a beer. Biting flavor is fruity, syrupy, sweet but not cloying. Texture is smooth and yet rough and strongly fizzy, biting the tongue and leaving a finish like an angry tomcat scratching on its way down.

2008 bottle.  Pours brown with a small light beige head.  Leaves a little spotty lacing.  Big fruity, malty aroma, some yeast.  Flavor is dark fruit, raisin, plums, prunes, some cherry, light notes of apple, banana, yeast.  Some alcohol.  Sweet malty finish.  Some stickiness.  Medium carbonation.  Very nice.

An interesting brew. Far too sweet even for me. Over-bearing anisceed notes. Aroma is full on anisceed and caremel. An ok beer but nowhere near as good as their standard stuff. Poured into a chalis at the Rake on tap. A long lasting drink but actually a little dissapointed compared to their normal offering. Tastes also a lot of sickly-sweet golden syrup mixed with caramel and anisceed. Not bad but too over-bearing on the anisceed which ruins the beer.

Bottle says best before 03/08/10.  Dark brown pour with a tan islands of head.  Aroma of eggnog, perfume, fruit.  Flavor is fruity, almost like those sprays teenage girls spray around all the time.  Some licorice. Some rum soaked fruit.  Medieum bodied, Mouthfeel is kind of chalky. FInishes like perfume.  Eh, this one got hard to drink as it wore on.  Not really something I Could recommend.

Red brown colour with thin, tight head. Aroma is slightly sterile, aniseed, sweet. Taste is similar with strong essence of aniseed coming through. This almost tastes like a liquid version of a Black Jack sweet. Not too many warming Christmassy flavours to be found in this one but it is rich, clean and interesting.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2011 Bottle from Wards in Gainesville. Pours dark brown with a big head. Taste is sweet with caramel, fruit, spices, and some bitterness/hoppiness at the tail end.

Rerate: 2 year aged 2009 bottle. Pour is fantastic, amazing head and retention. Taste is like drinking a weizenbock with the body of a quad. Very sweet, lots of banana and clove. Palate is full and rich. Just fantastic.

Bottle @ Cardinal. Pours dark brown with a big off-white head
 Aroma is fruity, caramel malt, with some yeast and spices. Taste is sweet and heavy malted, with fruit, spices, some alcohol, hops and fine bitterness in the finish. Lingering sweet mats.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown, hazy color with an extremely large, frothy brown head.  Lacing is ridiculously strong.  Aromas of banana, bread, roasty malts, and light raisin.  Palate is a full body, soft carbonation, thick feel, and a long finish.  Taste is medium bitter, flavors of banana and raisin abound, and a nice light sweetness finish.  Very good holiday beer, one that I plan to enjoy countless times until Christmas.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a thick lasting beige head over a dark amber (SRM 10-12) slightly cloudy body.......nose is ginger, light dried fruits (cherry, raisin)....taste is sweet dried fruits (cherry, raisin, plum) to start evolving to sweet ginger, then a light bitter finish.....mouth feel is light, carbonation high, with a tiny bubbled spritz reminiscent of Beaujolais Nouveau. This is rather lighter over all than expected, and there is not the depth of  fruity complexity that so many in this genre have. That is not to say it isnt delicious,it is just not as great as others.

Poured to a fluted fest glass at Brixies Holiday Beer Tasting in Brookfield, IL. The color was a walnut brown with a nice off white/light tan head of tight, small bubbled foam, and clingy spots of lacing. The aroma was sweetness, caramel, dark fruit, dark cherry, and subtle alcohol. The flavor added to these more of a sweetness of brown sugar, along with warming alcohol.  Full bodied and lightly syrupy as a  very nice, seasonal sipper.

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Best before 2012-07-22. It poured a dark red-brown colour with a medium big off-white head that settled down fast in the glass. Aroma is sweet with notes of dark fruits, banana, apples. The flavour is also sweet with notes of alcohol, dark fruits, banana and malts. It has a medium long aftertaste. This beer may not fall in the classic christmas beer category, but it is nevertheless a very nice beer for christmas or any other season.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2016 Bottle at Martythesmarty and Hirigalzkars xmas beer tasting.
Aroma of mint and pear popcicle.
Taste of cherry and salmiak.

After tasting several ordinary beers with seasonal wrappings this year, its refreshing to encounter a brew taking the "Christmas"-part seriously. This beer adds just that little xmasy touch to the familiar Belgian Strong Ale; a delightful deep, malty, spicy, hot stew of extra flavors, that little extra that matters so much. I also noticed, for the first time ever, a discernable bubble gum flavor seeping out somewhere along the aftertaste process. Finally I know what that reference is all about. :-) The complex, deep taste really lingers in the mouth and says "Merry Christmas" to me, suggesting there might be several little xmas eves for me this year. Het Anker has really gone to work on this one.

A little weak in the palate, but otherwise a great beer! Pours chocolate/cola brown with thin tan head. Aroma is dark fruits and a little ethyl. Flavor is caramel malt, dark fruit, figs, plums. Finishes clean. A little hot.

33 cl bottle at home. Vintage 2009. Clear reddish brown color, fine off-white/beige head. Aroma is fruity, caramel malt, with some yeast and spices. Flavor is sweet (almost sugar) and malty, with fruit, spices, some alcohol, hops and fine bitterness in the finish. Typical Belgian, and therefor a lovely strong beer. Some will say it´s too sweet; well, I like it that way.
Deep brown hazy body. Huge brown lasting head. Aroma of banana, anise, licorice and spiced - coriander? Heavy sweet and light bitter finish. Full body and sticky texture.
Old notes from DØE Horsens 06. Brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, fruity, plum, raisin and spices. Flavour is typical belgian, fruity, plum and raisin.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of cookie, cereal, nutty and milk chocolate, moderate flowers, perfume and orange for the hops, maybe a hint of broth for the yeast, and background notes of raisin, butterscotch, alcohol, fig and anise. Head is small, fizzy, very light brown with fair but thin lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is murky brown with a red tint. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy with a carbonation between soft and lively and finishes moderately alcoholic. This is one complex and well rounded beer. The hop profile is fantastic in this Belgian Strong Ale, fruity, spicey and perfectly balanced.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a dark caramel color, typical fruity Belgian aroma.  Thin white head that barely sticks around, and a very nice, smooth flavor...smoother than Ive come to expect from a true Belgian.  Im glad I got 2 bottles.

Appearance: Dark brown, hint of red. Some tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt and dark fruit.
Taste: Warming. Dark, ripe fruit and dark malt. Very nice.
Info: 330ml bottle, 22/9-2009, 30/100

Bottle. Deep ruby coloured pour with a great thick beige head. Fantastic aroma of dark fruit, cinnamon. Sweet, port like, dark fruit, bready, rum like taste. Dangerously drinkable, complex Belgian Christmas beer. I have had this on draught many times. It is probably my favourite beer, utterly delicious.
Lovely beer!  Great taste.  Well balanced.  Yum yum.  A little bit better than Gouden Carolus classiek.  I do love the beers from het Anker.  Try the Cuvee de Keiser!!!
dark red brown coloured body with a off white head a roasted malty aroma a spicy malty sweet fruity taste with a sweet fruity alcholic  bitter finish
Dark, redish amber with a tiny off-white head. Malty with liqorice tones. Malt, spices and sweetness. Full body with a bitter  / sweet finish.

On tap at Delirium, Bruxelles. Pours pitch black with medium creamy head. Aroma of big anice, some roasted malt and dark fruits. Taste is big anice, raisins and cinamon. Really spicy. Extensive lacing.
Deep reddy brown with a thin lasting light tan head, aroma is a joy - sweet, alcoholic and spicy. Taste is sweet-ish with a burnt sugar edge to it and a good dose of spice (licorice and dried fruits)

On tap at Naked City. Pours a dark, cola brown, with a smallish off-white head. Aroma is a punch in the face. This stuff has some serious character, and yes - it smells like Christmas. Candied orange peel, cloves, anise (licorice?), and allspice melded with the classic dark fruity malts of a dark Belgian ale. This is like a liquid version of a baked good someone might give you for the holiday season... except far better. Really, really interesting brew - packed with flavor, extremely seasonal (though Im drinking it in August)... really nice. This has got to be one of my favorite breweries in the world.

750 ml. Rich and sweet strong ale, but far from cloying. Plenty of complexity. Hazy brown body with a frothy, light brown head that diminishes to tan pools. Aroma of dark fruits, plum, clove, cinnamon, orange peel. The flavor is heavily sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. The finish is moderately sweet and moderately bitter with some light acidity. The alcohol is not apparent until the finish and even then is far from upfront. You can taste the candy sugar and fruits and get a hint of licorice. Medium to full body with a velvety texture and lively carbonation. Top-notch beer.

Tap at Delirium Cafe in Brussels.  Dark reddish-brown in color with a one-finger off-white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, candi sugar, spices, and licorice.  Flavor all of the same plus orange peel and some dark fruits.  Medium-full on the palate with alcohol present.

Aroma/Malty-toasted,
Appearance Head/Initia-huge, Head/Color light brown,
Head/Longevity-Fully lasting
Body/Hue-murky,
Initial Flavor-bitter light
Finish Flavor-bitter light
Palate/Body-medium to full,
verry good beer

An awesome 750 ml bottle thanks to my 2009 Summer Secret Santa. Pours an amazing picture of deep mahogany hues, almost completely opaque with a beige head of medium thickness. The aroma is great; full nutty and sweet notes; lots of sugary candies, but more rich fruity malts and caramel. The flavor is great as well; a rich creamy mouthfeel, caramel, light spices, rich fruity malts, strawberries and other fruit, light hops as well. Like a great Christmas cake. Nice. Im feeling merry for sure. Rich and fruity like I enjoy in Belgian Ales.

Nice crystal clear ruby red beer with a mid sized shiny light brown cap, good effervecence, some early ropy lacing and decent retention. Awesome aroma! Licorice and orange are the first think I noticed, good spice, very well balanced, minor amount of yeast which comes out more when warmer, a little bit of pepper, some sweet dark red candy, touch of caramel, really appealing There isnt much of a step down when it comes to the flavour: dark cherry, alcohol, mild anise, mild yeast taste, stiff spice but sweet too, caramel and raisin. Quite smooth, nice alcohol burn, heated medium spice aftertaste, good bitterness as well, but it is secondary. Excellent beer. I still have one more sitting in my cellar from 2 years ago.

Semi-transparent mahogany, light beige head. Lots of bread and yeast in the nose, minor spice and a little fig. Lots of creamy nut in the flavor, some caramel, also some yeast and an undercurrent of toffee syrup. Very soft palate. Overall, quite pleasant. The alcohol is controlled and the flavor mellow, yet complex and malty enough to draw one back.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy dark amber body with a one finger creamy beige head.  The nose is very rich and deep, lots of fruity and fig notes.  Banana, brown and candi sugars, light alcohol, and a bit of yeast.  Rather smooth and soft flavor up front, heavy malt, yeast, notes of licorice, banana, caramelized sugar.  Finishes with a bit of an alcohol kick with caramel and toffee malt, fairly yeasty.  Mouthfeel is full and soft with light fizzy prickly carbonation.  Rather good, maybe a little bit hot, but I think that this might be a good cellarable beer.

Body has a brown haziness about it, very minimal cap was produced during pour and after only a few seconds just a small ring remains around edge of glass. Lots of bubs are floating to the top of the brew that looks really think, all these bubbles are causing a churning effect on the surface of the beer and is pushing around small islands of foam in all directions. Very standard aroma for the style, sweet, touch of alcohol, spices, cherries, slight wood, and there is a aroma hiding in the back ground that reminds me of cigarette ash. Wow this stuff feels thick and the first sip warms the stomach. Taste is also very standard for the style but does stick out more in my mind than some. Sweet cherries just a touch of alcohol blends nicely with cinnamon and nutmeg, dark malts dominate this flavor and Im even detecting apples. Tasty brew, this would be a great sipper on a cold winter evening and not the summer heat wave I drank it in. I liked it but there are better in the style I would most diffentatly drink again but I wouldnt go out of my way for it ."
Thanks to whomever gave me this.  Tons of spices in the aroma and flavor, nutmeg, cinnamon, spruce and everything else.

Bottle: deep ruby-amber coloured, firm bigger beige head; liquorice, cinnamon, roasted malt and mulled wine in the sweet nose; medium to full bodied, robust sweet-bitter flavour; lingering sweet-bitter, cough-syrup like finish. A liquid X-mas cake, very nourishing.........

Dark brown in color with a thick foamy tan head. Head is creamy looking and lasts forver.Smell is full of dark malts, orance peel, spices, and vanilla.The taste has the sxpected spice flavors with a little hint of pepper. The alcohol mixes nicely with carmel malt and toffee. A little bitter on the finish.

Dark reddish brown with thin tan head. Sweet soapy floral perfume raisin banana black licorice aroma. Soapy perfume floral banana black licorice taste. Not my cup of tea or beer.  I hate black licorice. Give me the classic.

750 bottle thats a few years old. Reddish brown body with a one finger head that quickly fades. Nose has varying aromas of banana, caramel, dark fruit, and spice. Flavor is sweet with orange, honey, raisins. Theres a touch of bitterness in there floating around. Full and smooth with low carbonation. While a little too sweet overall, its tasty and packs a nice winter warmer punch.
Bottle.  Amber pour, light head.  Fruity, yeasty, honey and a bit nutty.  Flavor is much the same...spicy, full and sweet.  Very light hops on the finish.  Not too bad.

Candy apple red hue. Billows of auxerrois grapes, lime, and fruit cake with rum sauce...all this just in the nose! Hits the mouth with more auxerrois and the addition of cotton candy. Middle palate kicks in the 10.5% bounty...with oak and sherry (has this been casked?). Goes down showing signs of dry nut. Finish is surprisingly short, with faint traces of maltose and malted barley. Lots of different personalities here. They arent enemies, but certainly dont get along like best friends. Well call it a marriage of aquaitences!
Brown coloured beer with  medium off-white head. Nice spicy herby aroma. Full palate and sparkling. Finish is roasted bitter. Nice one.

[1941-20090111] 330mL bottle. Fruity plum malt aroma. Dark dark red body with a medium-lasting creamy light tan head. Lots of dark fruity licorice and plum cake in the flavour. Medium-full body. Tasty.
(@ The Rhino; Toronto, ON)

Dark red with a beige head. Aroma: Complex, dark fruit, chocolate, caramel, banana, alc, spices, a little hops. Taste: sweet, lots of caramel, dark fruit, lots of alc, a little sourness, a little bitterness in the end. Very belgian and very christmassy. A good combination for a cold winters night.

33cl bottle.
dark woody brown, large untidy lgiht brown head. it jumped at me from the bottle, but was manageable.
malty, dark caramellish, sweet, licorice, cola nut?, the individual aromas are not that great, but together it do get very intersting.
flavor is sweet a little malty, licorice, caramel, faint flowery hoppy, underlying strength from alc, but alc. only noticeable as a kind of bitterness. palate is a bit watery, but also smooth.
a bit rough around the edges and a bit too much alc. to make it a hit with me, but very tasty nonetheless.

Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Ruby red, huge thick off white head, probably my own fault. Aroma: Sweet mango, candy floss, perfume, fruit, cinnamon and yeast. Lovely. Flavour: Sweet, like a Christmas candy, chewy, alcohol is certainly present, fruity, lots of malt, raisins, long sweet finish. Nice.
Dark and rich. Sweet belgian candy sugar and some roast. Stong and sweet. Complex sweetness of raisins and caramelized fruit too. Roast bitterness help to balance it slightly.
Very rich, sweet Belgian. Pours dark walnut brown with thick head. Excellent strong ale!

Bottle at Stone Brewing.  Pours dark brown body with smaller brown head. Wonderful aroma of caramel mixed with lot of things like punch, vanilla, some fruits etc. Flavor isnt any worser, very full, alcohol is not felt at all, a bit sweetish. Palate also without complaints. Low carbonation fits well on thins one. Nice long finish.

I enjoyed this quality beer on tap at Maxs Taphouse in Baltimore.  The beer had a opaque dark brown color with a slight copper hue.  Its head was a thin, creamy dark-white color with good cling but modest retention.  The aroma was a sweet fig, raisin, and prune mix with some cherry notes and a slight earthy hops tone too.  It had a sweet, dark fruit and raisin taste, which was quite good, mixed with a touch of sour and bitter notes.  The beer was wet and had a full, somewhat creamy body, with lower carbonation levels.  A very full mouthfeel and the high alcohol content was well contained.  Definitely a high quality beer!

/From old notes.  Poured dark brown with thick head. Strong aroma of fruit, malt and something else.  Full chewy flavour, malt and fruit with some caramel.  Finish I do not remember, I was singing Afrikaans christmas carols, but remember as being pleasant.  Seek this one out.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Enjoyed via 12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with an ivory head.  Aroma is of dark fruits and a small amount of malt sweetness.  On the palate, the initial sense is one of slightly higher than normal carbonation, with notes of dark fruits and crystal malts.  In the finish, there was some remaining sweetness, and just the slightest touch of alcohol.  Overall, this was a wonderful winter warmer.

On tap at Microbar, Battersea, 13th Feb 2009, with chriso. Wow, what a find, nipping out from the Battersea beer festival as the beer ran low. A supremely flavoursome brew, this reminded me of Bassetts Liquorice Allsorts with its combination of sweet sugary flavours & liquorice. There are woody notes too and a botanical bitterness that reminded me of Angostura bitters. Despite all the sweetness, it is wonderfully balanced and a joy to drink.
sample at PP.  On tap.  Amber color.  Sweet.  Very malty.  Lots of melanoidin caramelization.  Delicious.  This beer rocks.  Alcohol barely noticable.

Dark amber with ruby highlights and a half-inch white head that fades quickly into a creamy film. Fruity malt aroma: apples, nutmeg, cinnamon. Flavor is spicy, lightly peppery. Fruity malt with a dash of yeast. Clean, crisp fruit finish. Very nice.

Pours ruddy brown with a thin tan head despite a hard pour, alcohol, raisins, anise in the aroma.  Taste is big licorice, malty fruitiness, some seasonal spices, maybe nutmeg, cocoa and caramels.  No apparently alcohol.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2010 33cl Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a small beige head.  
Aroma is lovely and smooth with strong malty and caramel note, followed by raisins, liquorice and spices. 
Flavour is malt, caramel, liquorice and spices with a gentle touch of alcohol. Very complex and very good. 
Unfortunately I think the palate is a little watery but its definitely the best Christmas beer in the world! 

However there is a big difference between the tap version, the 75cl bottle and the 33cl bottle. 

The 33cl bottle version is usually better carbonated, which makes the beer more smooth and harmonized. 
If I got the opportunity Ill always choose the small bottle, rather than the big bottle, and the big bottle, rather than the tap version.

Re-rating a 1 year old small bottle adds +1 on the aroma. From 8 to 9.

Bottle from  Liquor World, Fayetteville AR. Very deep copper, small layer of white head, nice contrast. Rum, buttery chocolate, a nice old woody funk. An aroma of bakeries and well-built old horse barns. Viney rich raw sugar flavor, very soft and sweet up front, but nothing sticky in the finish. Delicate pepper and cinnamon, mahogany. A nice little resiny cocoa pinch in the finish. A very beautifully poised beer, subtle but full of interest.

Draft, at Coopers (Scranton, PA) on 12/26/09. Pours reddish brown, topped with a small tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, spice, brandy and  alcohol. Flavor of fruitcake, toffee, brown sugar, caramel, and alcohol. Long finish, with dark fruit and spice.

Reviewed at the 2007 Strong Ale festival
A- Murky amber hue, thin layer of white frothy head, spotty lacing
S- Licorice and spice, dark fruits (raisins and plums), floral hops and spice
T- Initial taste dominated by licorice/anise and raisins, touch of chalk and smoke, dark plums and figs, slight berries and brown sugar, warming alcohol
M- Medium-bodied, watery texture, mild carbonation
D- Smooth and fruity beer full of winter spices, alcohol presence is stiff and limits drinkability

THOUGHTS: My bottle said 10% ABV. Not overly Christmasy, but it was like a sweet candy treat for the holidays. Awfully clear for a bottle conditioned beer. No real sediment either. Not as good as the Grand Cru, but close. Hardly any hops anywhere. Bonus point for being better than the sum of its parts.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark brownish red that looked bright red in the light with a small to average, off-white head that mostly diminished and left virtually no lacing. The aroma was nice, but could have been stronger. There was moderate to heavy molasses and caramel malts, banana, raisin, apple, cherry, red wine, brown sugar, maple syrup, a little alcohol, candi sugar, sort of a rum flavor and other dark fruit. The flavor started very sweet, and finished sweet, ever so slightly bitter, sour and a little more sweetness with and average to long duration. There was caramel, candi sugar, raisin, cherry, apple, dark fruits of all kind, molasses, and maybe a little brown sugar. Very fruity, but it got a little cloyingly sweet, keeping it from being perfect. The medium body was slightly syrupy and sticky on the lips, then a little dry with very fizzy carbonation and a moderate alcoholic finish.

Mini growler from Half-Time.  Pours a clear dark ruby color with a medium beige head comprised of small tight bubbles.  Sweet plum, fig, raisin, and stone fruit aromas with a little yeast.  Medium to thick body with a good amount of brown sugar.  A definite change up from what the nose said was coming.  The 10+% sneaks in on the finish and packs a big warm punch.

Wow. This is pretty astounding stuff. Brown color with a medium sized but very dense head. Aroma starts with some of the dark fruity notes that I expect from a belgian xmas beer but then takes a funny citrusy turn. Intriguing. The flavor is a wonderful balance of toffee/caramel notes along with prune, orange peel, maple syrup, mystery spices, and a touch of clove. I feel like I notice something different with every sip. Truly a top notch beer.

Poured a nice deep rich brown color with not much in the way of head.  Aroma was so strange.  A mix of spice, anise, a little citrus, a lot of malt.  We shared a bomber among four people and everyone of us had a different impression.  i thought it tasted like strong tea with a twist of lemon and some honey and molasses.  We heard peppermint stick, malt bomb, and Wurthers original candy tossed around too.  This was a very complex and very tasty beer.  Would love to revisit.

Part of a 3 sampler, 10 cl in a white wine glass at Birra Artigianle de Qualita in Milan.  Very dark cloudy ruby color.  Severly weet/malty, straight up licorice taste. 10cl is all I can handle, definitely not a whole pint.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2009 33cL bottle drunk with appreciation (for Donfardz64) in every sip. 
Intense aromas of milk chocolate and a licorice, clove style aniseed. Some leathery yeast and smoky notes - giving it an earthy character.
Heavy, roasted malt plus some warming alcohol showing through. Lovely!
Dark, syrupy flavours. I first taste strong licorice and a deeply roasted malt, followed by a raisin sweetness that persists to the finish. This sweetness is complimented by a mild cocoa bitterness in the background.
Alcoholic, spirit-like mouthfeel with an aniseed finish. 
Amazingly complex and warming - its a shame us New Zealanders celebrate Christmas in scorching heat!!

This beer was way.. WAY to hot.  On tap and Pizza Port Carlsbad.  Pours a clear dark brown w/ red hue.  Molasses, caramel malt, dark fruits, plums, raisins, toffee, and spice, clove, etc.  and then heavy on the alcohol.  I really didnt like this one.

In short: A fuller-than-full bodied belgian dark ale.  A malt orgy with a light spicy touch.
How: Bottle 750ml.  (too) many times.  This rating for a one year old 2007 bottle.
The look: Cloudy brown body topped by a small dark beige head
In long: The king of the malts outdo themselves with this brew.  This is a malt orgy with light spicy notes just to spice things up.  Toffee, molasses, caramel, more molasses, cloves, candied fruits, dark fruits, more heavy caramel, red fruits, and more toffee.  but the beer really doesnt feel very sweet.  Something must be drying it up, herbal spices and/or the well hidden hops (that I cant even detect)?  This is a very big Belgian dark whose decadent body can rival that of just any other beer on the planet.  If you like malt and dont mind a little spicy touch this is as good as it gets.  Ha! Christmas, this is the time of year when people like me gather with friends and family to celebrate the birth of a new batch of the Carolus Christmas.  Jesus Christ this is a good beer.
Recommended by landlord of Poechenellekelder (Brussels). Great surprise. Complex, delicious spices and a nice long liquorice finish

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 2007 bottle shared with MmmcKay, jbo, and barrios.  Mahogany pour with good tan head.  Massively hot nose and flavor.  Dark raisin and plum in the aroma.  Fruity alcohol and some banana notes in the flavor with anise as it warms.  Medium thin body with medium carbonation.  Much better as it warms up.  2013 on draft at bucket trade- much better than I remembered.  Huge anise notes. Very enjoyable sipper.

Ve che robe, vinosa in un modo un po strano, molto piccante con un sentore alcolico pungente che però si risolve in astruse note di anice/solvente/spezie vaghe; liquorosa at best, ma nello stile tutto zoomata tipico di Het Anker avventuroso e un pochino mi disturba, così che la apprezzo di più quando è già in fondo al gargaroz.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2011 330 mL 2008 ed. Pours a deep ruby almost brown with a beautiful two-finger, yellow head that dissipates to a thin layer but leaves some spotty lacing. Powerfully sweet aroma of dark fruits, raisins, plums, Twizzlers red licorice, black cherries. Taste is heavy with a velvety mouthfeel. Up front there is some black cherry soda, brown sugar, and cinnamon moving to some sort of combination between Grand Marnier and Southern Comfort. Spicy alcohol, dark fruits in the finish. This is seriously good. I mean really good. 1/28/2009 8/4/9/5/16=4.2 330mL 2008 ed. Pours a hazy, deep mahogany with a stout-like tan head with rocky retention and big webby lace. Aroma is all red licorice, anise, massive fruit cake. Some nice spicy rum comes into play. Taste is massively sweet with bittering chocolate and cocoa. Rich dark chocolate is accompanied with odd sickly sweetness. 12/25/2010 7/5/7/4/14=3.7750mL c&c 2009 ed drank with two years of age on it. A small gusher. Pour is very deep brune generating a huge, tan head. Giant clouds of lace. Nose is very prominent exploding out of the glass and all over the room: huge cherry twizzlers and major chocolate banana split character like an intense dunkelweizen. Dunkel weizenbock? Taste is on the sweet side with mild spice coming to balance. Lemon cake brings some tartness and body in the finish. Very enjoyable, heavier, richer, and definitely a dessert beer. Comes across as a pretty formidable quadrupel with dunkelweizen character. Nice. 8/7/2011 8/5/8/4/16=4.1

Dark brown body with a large, persistent head.  Sweet candy smell reminiscent of jelly beans.  Very malty.  Lots of licorice flavor and mouthfeel.  Lots of spice...very unique beer.  The flavor is odd due to the candy-like overtones, but the palate is very good.  I will have to try this one some more.

330mL bottle purchased at Frugal MacDoogals in Nashville.  Poured a cloudy brown, almost cocacola color, with a thin tan head.  The aroma was spicy, with coriander and cinnamon present.  The flavor was spicy, but chocolate and caramel dominated.
a very good beer, with a very deep white steam. A bit strong for me,

750mL brown cork finished bottle. 2008.

Appearance: Poured into a Duvel goblet. Rich mahogony (reddish brown) color with a thick, fluffy tan head. Nice lacing as it receeds.

Nose: Orange peel and a little manure (barn yard) are the first things to hit my nose. Lots of corriander, a little funky wool (horse blanket), and a nice meaty smell.

Palate: Theres a sliver of cork in my beer! Ok, now that was unfortunate after all the barnyardy smells to feel something like that in my mouth. Moving on: Big orange peel, corriander, and that meaty/wooly thing. The palate is spicy, like fresh cracked black pepper. Medium-bodied and a little wooly on the texture. Finish is more balanced and everything falls into place.

Notes: A little out of balance right now, it might fall together better with some age. The spices are really loud and I cant hear the beer itself. A decent effort, but Ill stick with the Cuvee and the Classic.

330mL bottle from Rumbles. Pours dark brown.black. Fizzy tan head. Aroma has a main aniseed character, some caramel and vanilla and cinnamon showing through. 
Flavour is full of aniseed, like liquid licorice. Raisiny cinnamon flavours are also strongly present. Finishes dry and coffee like. A well spiced ale, but a bit hash. Not really my thing.

Pours dark brown, close to black, with a tan head. Dark aromas, aniseed. Very bitter flavours. Burnt malt, burnt coffee and spice, but with enough dark chocolate and caramel sweetness to pull it back. Very dense and dark, but warming. Can imagine it would fare better in the Christmas snow than New Zealands warm Christmas nights.

I had this on tap at the Hop Cat in Grand Rapids. What a unique beer. No aroma to speak of, thick, frothy, palate not too much unlike milk or egg nog. Spiced but not overpoweringly so with nutmeg, cinnamon and brown sugar overtones. The alchohol is over 10% but I swear, you couldnt taste any. Different and distict for even a Belgian.

(11/3/08) Bottle sample at a tasting in Pizza Port in Carlsbad (thanks whoever). Dark amber-colored. Heavily spicy aroma with some malt and caramel notes. Sweet flavor with caramel and loads of spices. Medium-bodied.

Bottle - 330ml. Pours a dark brown body with low carbonation and a decent creamy head. Nice malty/hoppy aroma with fruity and brown sugar hints. Taste is very well balanced and carries candy, plummy and dark berries notes. Alcohol is very well hidden. Ends with a long warming finish. Well done!
Bottle shared by someone at Woodshop Quad.  Nose of raisins, spice, and yeast. light brown with a medium beige head. Flavor was light peppery spices and caramel.

Sampled at Ds Monroeville.  Pours a dark amber with reddish hues.  The head is kind of small fizzy and off-white.  The aroma is a spicy sour apple with stewed cherry gummy candy.  The flavor has a big alcohol character with a ton of brown sugar and old stale dark fruit.  Great thick body with a nice warming finish.  Solid Christmas beer.

Bottle.  Mild fruity and spicy aroma.  Deep reddish brown body, light tan head.  Flavor is very rich, moderately sweet.  All kinds of ripe fruits, yeasty malt, and a lively highly carbonated mouthfeel.  Warming alcohol in both the flavor and the finish.  All in all, this is a high quality and extremely tasty beer.

Dates, molasses rum, some nutmeg.  Dark brown with reddish-orange hue color, small soapy head, decent lacing.  Dried cherries reconstituted with dark spiced rum sweetness, mild bitterness.  Heavy body, spritzy, tight bubbled carbonation; juicy, spicy, sweet warming finish.  Awesome flavors, has a very sweet quality, but not cloying, very complex with dark fruitiness, excellent.

New Years Eve, 2009. Now that I have washed the Theobroma out of my mouth with a Racer 5, Im ready for a beer that will not disappoint. Deep amber pour with fine off white head. Creme brulee aroma. Thick sweet alcohol, great mouthfeel. Some liquorice and dark rum, dark dried fruits and some allspice?

Very dark color, nice head which dissapears very quick.
smells christmassy and tastes christmassy.
Minimal aftertaste, a bit dissapointing though...
A decent beer from my hometown.

Bottle that Lozs parents picked up for me in Bruges, Oct 08, consumed 11-01-09. Pours conker brown or possibly a little darker with a light beige head which quickly disappears. Initially some sweet dark molassessand even a bit of eraser/rubber on the nose quite bizzarely, seaside candy rock and spices. Taste is malty, spicy with dark sugars again, its soft in the mouth with a nice gentle carbonation. There is also some nutmeg and allspice, dark dried fruits, its a real sipper and is lovely. A7 A5 F8 P5 OV16   4.1

Bottle with Butters.  Pours a thin, lacing tan head with a dark brown body.  Smells of raisins, prunes, spice, caramel, and alcohol.  Tastes a bit like port wine.  Dark fruit flavors with caramel, anise, and nutmeg.  Fine carbonation in the mouth with a small to medium finish.

Caramel brown in color. Fruity nose. Definitely banana and plantain notes. More of same for flavors. Banana maybe in bananas foster. Fruit flavors shine through early on. Beer fades though rather quickly. Mid palete more spice flavors and alcohol begins to shine through. Finish is a tad disappointing. Ends smoothly but too quickly. Was a little flat at the end. Overall a nice brew. Easy to drink and good to pass around the campfire.

Bottle C&C. L0870, ?. Pours a dark ruby color with a good beige head. Aroma hits vanilla, roasted caramel and dark fruit. Flavor is dark fruit, candi, treacle and likely several other things. Its hitting me as slightly pepperish. Finish is a bit astringent. Which doesnt exclude a bit of sweetness it seems. Medium malt bomb.
On tap at Novare Res.  Wow, lovely winter strong ale.  All the normal malts youd expect, mixed in perfect quantity.  Paired with a delicious yeast strain this beer hits it perfectly.
A dark brown beer with a fast disappearing tan head. Strong sweet aroma of caramel, figs, dates and raisins, as well as for flavours. Too sweet.

pours a very dark amber-mahogany with a nice light tan head. Aroma is wonderful, with malt, dark fruit including prune and fig, and some definite alcohol as well. Flavor is also exquisite- lots of candied sugar and fruit, though slightly lighter than the prune and fig that came through in the smell. Malt is still extremely present, and lots of spice is added. Palate is nice, not overally thick, with a booze presence, but still sticks to the tongue nicely. Very very nice belgian strong.

750 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown colour, thick light brown head. Strong malty aroma with spices, dark fruits and some alcohol. The flavour is sweet and malty, with fruits and spices, alcohol warmth and yeast. Delicious.

Appearance: Pours a deep, dark chestnut brown body topped with a quarter inch off creamy, off-white head. Very thick, very coating lacing as it goes.

Smell: Earthy, spicy, malty nose with notes of anise, prune, black currants and, wait, is that Jäger I’m smelling?

Taste: Sweet caramel, spiced molasses, black licorice, and candied fruits blended with a full shot, no, make that two shots of Jägermeister. The heavy malts, fruits, and bitter herbal liqueur all vie for dominance. Who’s the winner? Well, I’ll just say you get a bit more Jäger on the dry finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Chewy mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Grr, when I get my hands on whoever dropped a shot of Jägermeister in my Gouden Carolus Noël, I’ll take my shoe to them!

2007 vintage bottle shared by akevitt.  Pours a clear, reddish brown body with a generous, off-white foam head.  Lots of sediment in the pour.  Aroma of belgian malts, orange, coriander, and clove.  Flavor is similar with notes of banana and brown sugar.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  Hides the 10% abv well.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 030109.
Amber with beige head. Aroma of dried fruit and yeast. Flavor is malt, yeast and a high carbonation

Poured from an 11.2oz bottle. Pours dark amber with thick off white head. Great aroma of dark fruit, malt, banana and yeast. Nice smooth taste with lots of dark fruit notes and hints of banana and brown sugar. Real good Christmas beer.

750mL pours an attractive deep clear amber with firm tan head. The aroma is full of bright fruity notes of raisins and prunes followed by more subtle spicy notes of clove and coriander. The taste is even bolder than the aroma with big syrupy raisins, plums and prunes. It gets slickly sweet by midway and holds on into the finish. About midway coriander, cloves show up with a faint pulse of allspice. This could use a few years of age to really shine and smooth out. It leaves a slick sweet dark fruity flavor behind deep into the after taste. Never really gets overly sweet even to the end of the bottle.

Aroma is brown sugar, yeast, a hint of raisin. A deep copper pour with tight tan head and lace. A brown sugar front with alot of sweet raisin. Smooth full bodied beer. Very nice. A beer that reeks of Christmas cheer. Would have never guessed it was 10.5. At least maybe until it warms. 07 model.

On tap @ Map Room.  Pours amber with a thick off white head.  Interesting, strong aroma of Belgian yeast, banana, and some clove.  Flavor was solid with some dark fruits, banana, clove, and some other spices.  Nice winter warmer.

Very deep brown beer with a thin tan head.  Aroma is very rich and fruity.  Figs, plums and prunes with an absolutely intoxicatingly balanced mix of spices, nutmeg, allspice and clove.  Very rich plummy character.  Balanced spiciness, baked/dried fruits, a touch of berries and a very rich lightly cocoaish character.  Both rich and light at the same time.  Flavour is loaded with stewed fruit, figs, orange peel, coriander, allspice and a kiss of molasses and treacle.  There is a kiss of black pepper and some light lemony character.  Both intense and delicate... a gorgeous beer with a multitude of contrasting elements that are still harmoniously incorporated.
On tap at Sergio’s.  Dark pour.  Good but I am not a big fan of the style at all due the whole Belgian candy sugar thing, and this has a lot of it.  Pretty enjoyable though.

750 ml bottle. Reddish-brown color, tan head. Strong anise aroma, which continues in the flavor and presents itself as licorice. Plenty of alcohol as well. Full body, medium carbonation. I’d call this a one trick pony: great if you like anise, but if you don’t, well...

Pours a dark brown with a slightly red hue when held to the light.  Head is tiny, light brown in color, and thins rather quickly.  Aroma was very nice.  Had a nice rich maltiness and some sweet alcohol.  Flavor resembles an abbey dubbel with some spice and a kick of alcohol.  Palate was superb!  Perfect carbonation, great mouth-feel, and a smooth finish.  I was expecting something a little sweeter, but this was great!
75cl bottle. Dark brown colour with a small off-white head. Sweet, fruity aroma. The flavour is sweet, fruity, spicy and malty. Smooth and medium to full-bodied. A very nice Christmas brew.

Pours a dark cola consistency with no head, just a little froth.  Smell is yeasty and wooden, pine.  Taste is similar, wood and caramel/mollases sweetness with yeast, liqorice and spice, and a strong fairly alcoholic finish.  Enjoyable slow one.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a dark drown color with a cream colored head full of tiny packed bubbles.  There is very nice retention and lacing.  Aroma is sweet candy with some hints of candy banana/banana bread notes and some dark fruits with a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is spice and some of the banana from the nose.  There is a bit of alcohol burn at the end but nothing unexpected for a 10+% beer.  Very nice winter warmer.

2008 750 mL bottle poured into a goblet.

Pours a clear copper topped by a one-finger creamy head that lingers as a small cap for a few minutes and leaves good lacing.

The aroma is fairly subtle and mostly sweet caramel malts and candi sugar.  There are hints of spices but not much and certainly less prominent than the alcohol whiffs I got.

The taste amps up the spices a bit with a definite peppery finish.  The sweetness of the candi sugar and dark fruits are dominant up until the finish where the peppers and alcohol are more detectable.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and very smooth with decent carbonation.  Its sticky sweet on the palate with the peppers tickling the tongue at the end.

This is one of the better Belgian holiday ales Ive had, mainly because I actually enjoyed having that slightly peppery finish which differentiated it from a normal BSDA.  Tasty.

Very nice beer, pours dark brown, medium thickness on the palate, a little like syrup - not over done, licorice, hint of pepper, like raisins. The smell is nice, similar to rootbeer, mild burn hides the alcohol and a chaulky finish..

Dark brown in color, small fluffy white head.  Earthy aroma with hints of sour.  The flavor leans toward an abbey dubbel, but has a bit more alcohol burn.  the finish is dry and light.  Nice beer.

My sample was a year old.  I wish I.d had it fresh.  I may have to pick one up this winter to rerate.

Very nice Belgian beer. I have 3 empty bottles of this waiting to fill with homebrew and as I am drinking the 4th realized that I never rated it.  Aroma was strong and full. Plum, raisin and alcohol. Pour was  a nice deep dark ruby with a 1 finger off white head. Taste was delicious and strong. Every dark fruit you can imagine with just a mild alcohol burn. Theres a hint of yeastiness  and pepper in the aftertaste but not overpowering. Could use a little more carbonation, but great nonetheless
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very nice beer, pours dark black, medium thickness on the palate, a wonderful sweetness - not over done, licorice, hint of pepper, sweet dried fruit like raisins. The smell is nice, not unlike rootbeer, mild burn hides the alcohol.

330ml bottle 
10.5% ABV 
I tried this beer on November 13, 2008 at "Smokeless Joes" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a dark brown with a thin tan coloured head.  The aroma was candied sugar, maple, plums, raisins, and caramel.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied, and medium carbonated.  The flavour was SWEET.  The alcohol was not all that noticeable, but the sugary taste was very dominant!

750 ml. bottle. Pours dark, slightly reddish-brown. Medium-sized head is beige. Complex aroma is warm, it has lots of licorice, dates, dark (ripe) fruits and earthy yeast. The flavor is vinous, strong and matly. At first there is sweetness of ripe fruits that turns to a bit sour in the finish with spices, fruits and some alcohol. Palate is full bodied, soft and sticky for lips.

Poured a very dark brown with small tan head.  Smell of burnt toffee, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, coffee, and a hint of cinnamon and clove. Taste is burnt sugar and toffee, dark plums, walnuts, raisins, with a pleasant bitter hop finish. The 10.5% alcohol is apparent. Think on the palate, fizzy and lasting. Sweet and nice! Merry Christmas!
Awesome christmas beer. Mouth filling and satisfying. Holiday flavors hit you from all sides, slides down like a great eggnog :)  Well balanced, super.  Happy to make this my 700th rating.

Bottle a couple years old.
Spicy, malty sweet aroma, alcohol, caramel, dark fruits, raisins, port. Rich winey flavor with molasses, spices, raisins, port. Thick and rich. Complex and holiday-like. Firy finish of alcohol, figs, molasses. Mmmm. Great stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a mahogany body with a 2 finger tan head.  Aromatic character of sweet dark fruit, minerals, malt, candi sugar, alcohol.  Plum and cinnamon.  A very creamy body.  The final note is a light metallic flavor which keeps this beer from being an all time favorite, honestly great stuff!  4.2

Had this on draft and so much of what i enjoyed about the bottled version was lost and overpowered by licorice.
Draft rating is 3.6.
Bottle. Pours brown with tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, sweet malt, spices. Flavor is mostly the same with sweet yeast notes.

On tap at the Bocktown, nice place. A very expensive brew!  Pretty dark but appears without a haze. Mild olfactory of mint or perperment in the aroma. Interesting old world flavors greet the tongue. Creamy taste bud impressions but barely any carbonation. Comes across a little strong and at 10% it is. Perhaps more personality than this lager lover can appreciate. Fun to try but would not by again. Long alky linger on finish. S6L4F2T3O7
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The best Christmas beer and one of the best beers period. Great aroma, flavor, palate. Excellent stuff
bottle- smell was hot, phenolic, and unpleasant- taste however was smooth, delicious, and left me wanting a few more sips- Alcohol well hidden, and the flavor was tasty.

Bottle shared.  Pours dark with a big head.  Aroma of malt, sugar, fruit, yeast, spice.  Taste was similar.  There are tons of dark fruit and sugar in this beer. The yeast gives good balance.  Mouth is very nice, coating and full.  Finish is warming.  Overall, the best Christmas beer Ive had, and IMO the best of our winter ale tasting.  This is what you would think a belgian Christmas ale would taste like.

Bottle pours very dark brown with a thick head.  The head lasts and laces the glass as you drink it.  Has a subtle aroma of cinnamon, dark fruit and holiday spices.  Flavors follow suit with a yeasty undertone.  Has a nice sweet finish.  Nice brew.

Nice burgundy brown color poured into a Gouden Carolus glass.  Wonderful aroma of brown sugar and stone fruits.  Initial flavor of plum and a little cinnamon  that slowly warmed and left an excellent aftertaste after swallowed.  High alcohol content barely evident as this one was enjoyed.  Make sure to bring a bottle to Christmas.
Pours dark brown, dark fruits, malty , yeasty, spice, caramel, little chocolate, little citrus.

Prune and plum aromas that are pretty nice.  A bit of a sweet and fruity drink.  The finish is a bit sticky and the sweetness stays around for a while.  Pretty light bodied which is surprising after such a big aroma and dark color.  Brown pour with a red hue.  As the beer warms it gets a bit hot with alcohol which is unfortunate.

Cask at Sandbar, Manchester.  Clear dark brown with ruby tinges and a thin, tan head. The aroma immediately lets you know what youre in for.  Rich winey alcohol hit followed up by powerful orange-tart fruit notes with cinnamon and spice in the background.  Flavour is packed with dried fruit, dark muscovado, figs and cherries.  Chocolate malts also feature.  Superbly balanced sweet-spice finish.  The alcohol has an immediate impact with a warming glow spreading outwards.  Very rich, full palate with light carbonation it carries the alcohol well.  Perhaps not one to start off an evening.
Bottle. Poured a cloudy orange body with thin head. Aroma is light figs, dates and dried fruit. Flavor has a slightly fruity taste with a dried fruit and spice after taste lingering...

On tap at The Red in Santa Cruz. Dark cloudy brown color with a creamy tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is boozy with lots of orange peel, cinnamon, and fig. A little too boozy for me though. Flavor is similar, theres a sweet dark maltiness doused in fusels with tropical and dark fruits and heavy spicing. Full bodied and warming, not hugely drinkable from all the alcohol.

On tap @ La Trappe.  Pours a very dark brown with a brownish head.  Awesome aroma, very sweet, maple syrup with a hint of fig.  Warming body, dark chocolate, caramel with a herbal-spiced finish.  Great brew.
Pours a deep red-brown with an aroma of alcohol, caramel, toffee, candy sugar, and wood/ vanilla.  Flavor is the same with earth, cinnamon, and spice added.  Finishes with whiskey, earthy, sugar.

First off WOW On tap at The Front Door Boise, Pours out a dark red topped with a tan head. Aroma was GREAT all sorts of sweetness. Pitfruit, caramel, and spice. Tast was just as good as the aroma. Sweet and spice. This is my kind of winter brew.

Dark ruby, slight sweetness, lots of ripe berries and just a touch of spice.  A definite winter beer, hearty and warm, not for the faint hearted or those who don’t like Samicluas or other strong, strong ales.  Not my favorite Xmas beer, but good.

Draught at the Red.   Dark brown with a big tan head.   The aroma has dark caramel, cherries, and silky nutty vanilla, accompanied by spicy yeast.   Dark fruity flavors, with molasses, light tart fruit, banana, and some spicy additions.   Rather sweet and malty, though cleaned up by alcohol and dusty spice.   Full bodied with smooth carbonation.   Quite an elegant sipper for the holidays.   Not quite magical, but solid.

Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights. The head is 2 two fingers thick and creamy tan. The nose is earthy, some cherry, woody, light alcohol, rummy, some balsamic aromas. The flavor is earthy, mild Belgian/yeasty character, cherry and wood, some sweetness, similar dubbel characters, balsamic flavors. The palate is lively and crisp with a very mild alcoholic warmth.

Bottle. Enticing dessert-y aroma. Dark fruits, banana pie with toasted nuts, grape bubblegum, nutmeg. Amazing that things as simple as malt and yeast can produce such an aroma. Pours a deep, dark coal brown with rich mahogany and cherry highlights. flavor is loaded with sweeter malts. Maple syrup, honey, dark, dried fruits... plums, raisins and dates. Brown sugar. Plenty of spice... clove and nutmeg. A decent amount of sweeter (banana and gummy) yeast esters compliment the malt throughout. Medium to full bodied with lively carbonation. Finishes lengthy with a touch of alcohol soaked fruitcake. Thanks John!

330ml bottle courtesy of fiver 29  thanks John!  Pours a clear dark reddish brown with a one finger cream head and decent lacing.  Nose is dark fruits, Belgian yeast and spice.  Taste is plums, raisins and spice.  Theres a hint of alcohol in the finish but it hides its 10.5ABV pretty well.  Medium prickly mouth feel.  Great Belgian.

Dark brown color with minor tan head that doesn’t last long.  Very complicated flavors that seem well balanced.  Sweet, malty, fruity.  This is an excellent brew.  If I see it again, I’m picking some up and aging a bit more to see how it matures.

Pours a dark brown. The nose is nutmeg, cinnamon and banana.  Comes across the palate with a a little more than necessary carbonation, with strong notes of cinnamon and banana; very malty. Finishes with almost a nutmeg, and banana that lingers.

Shit yeah a really nice picturesque bottle lable.Beautiful bottle label  o. Gosh I’d like to enjoy a few 750mls of this in front of the fire place with the proverbial X-mas sweaters- at least untill I pass out and burn the crib down : Its a beer that makes you play Christmas music in late september: A beer with a crap load of dried fruit profile.from the yeast ? .dry backdrop. I enjoyed the spices. Any christmas ale worth their stuff needs spices. Nutty multiness moves around.Classy :)

Bottle (in NZ), pours a deep reddish brown with a filmy head. A christmas spice hop aroma, with cakey malt, caramal, banana, currants, licorice, and rum. A full malty palate, sugary, with caramal malt with those christmas flavours picked up in the aroma. The finish is firey and spicy.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 [Eyes] Dark brown like the classic color with a moorefoamy white head. 
[Nouse] The aroma is festive and strong... Christmas fruity with hints of banana, malt caramel, yeast, vanilla, and brown cuban sugar. 
[Mouth] Great Full body with nice and gentile carbonation, notes of flavors of sweet, strong fruits, sugar and yeast. 
The Afther taste is long and sweet with a touch of caramel and vanilla. mmm!

Serving type: bottle
Deep brown color, aroma sweet with notes of maple syrup, malt, bread, Flavor is sweet with hints of roasted malt, caramel, toffee.

Bu au Festival Bière et Saveur 08 (31/8), en bouteille au kiosk de Brouhaha. Ambrée noisette, très peu de collet. Arome de caramel anglaise malté mentale, avec des notes de mélasse légé. Goût de caramel anglaise licoreuse, bien malté, pas si alcoolisé et un peu sûterre. Bonne bière de Noël pour la Fête du Travail!

Thanks to Dave from By the Bottle for letting me in on a two-year-old bottle of this.  Poured a dark brown, effervescent body with a medium off-white head. Nutty, mildly cardboardy, brown sugary, candied, and spicy.  Apples, sweets, malts, bubblegum, and coriander flavors.  Held up well being cellared.  Great tasting complex beer.

11.2 oz. bottle from Market Street Wine Shop Downtown Charlottesville dated 03/08/10. Hazy reddish brown with a big head. Moderate retention and low lacing. Aroma is banana, spice, pineapple, spice. Sweet taste shows notes of pinepple, anise, brown sugar. Alcohol is barely noticeable if at all in either the nose or the taste. Very nice way to end the evening!

On tap. Dark brown beer, beige head. Aroma of candy, christmas spice, malts. Flavour is very sweet, a bit sour, christmas spice (speculaas), roasted malts. Again, like most of their beers, way too sweet for me.

Bottle. Deep brown pour with a minor head. This beer was not what I was expecting at all. Pine and juniper dance around the malt-sweet and charcoal aroma. Big, lightly sweet malts in the flavor are unctuous but extremely drinkable, with a fast, tobacco and floral finish. Definitely the most drinkable 10.5% alcohol beer I’ve ever had. Well done.

On tap at OBriens. Deep burgundy color, fading wispy head with some bubbles. Becomes still after sipping for a while. Very sweet aroma of candy sugar, raisin, rum and a restrained bubblegum note. Toffee, cherry and grape flavors meld with some medium caramel. Ends sugary with a red wine character. Quite alcoholic. Becomes a bit difficult to drink. Somewhat unbalanced.
75cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, yet heavy, clear, small head, very good X-Mas brew

750 ml bottle with Paul July 08’.  Deep brown amber pour with beige head that falls slowly.  Sweet candi sugar and licorice nose. Christmas pudding and rum rasin. Tight small bubbles on the carb.  Beautiful well balanced beer.  Paal loved it.

Pours a very dark, murky amber brown with a tall, thick beige head. Sweet, nutty, caramel, Belgian yeast aroma, like fruity bread. A little of that sweet then soured fruit pokes through in the beginning. The body is spritzy and a little cider like. An oily alcohol lingers on the finish. Overall very smooth and well balanced. Not a favorite style, but a great representative.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2008 75cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Rated on 3/20/08. Pours a chocolate brown with thin tan head. Smells very sweet with notes of maple syrup, malt, chocolate, caramel, bread, yeast. Flavor is sweet with hints of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, and overtones of port wine and brandy on finish. Very good.

Bottle. Dark brown colour. The aroma is sticky plums and port like vinuous. Some aniseed and some licquorice. A really big, welcoming aroma. The taste is big and fruity. Wery complex with a perfect balance. This is an absolutly amazing beer

Dark red-brown with a nice, creamy head. The aroma has notes of raisin, dark fruits, roasted malt and caramel. The flavour has sweetness, notes of roasted malt, candy sugar, dark fruit and raisin. Its nice and complex.

Little bottle, best before March 8, 2010. Pours stark ruby with a dense off-white head. The aroma is sweet and fruity with intricate spiced character. It leans towards berries and licorice with a delicate spice backdrop. The slick, dense palate is much appreciated. Flavor is decently warming and thick. The sweetness is perfectly in check and a timid burn highlights the drier aspects of the brew. Notes of licorice, clove, chocolate, and some spice I cant identify are all here.

Pours dark brown with a decent sized tan head. Awesome aroma of cherries, caramel, and maybe some other fruit. Bold flavor of more fruit and caramel but with a bit of spice  and alcohol. A strong licorice flavor emerges as it warms. Good winter beer, great for the licorice lover.

Bottle from Party Source. Poured clear brown color with an average fizzy brown head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Complex heavy spicy sweet aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Heavy dark fruit bittersweet flavor with a heavy bittersweet finish of long duration with a warming alcohol bite. Good brew.

Bottle:  Dark copper pour with a huge sandy head.  Aroma is bright and fruity with bits of spice, some caramel, and breadiness.  Flavor is rich; fruity with caramel sweetness.  Light spices - cloves mainly.  Smooth and creamy palate.

Dark red-brown color.  Aroma of sweet malt and hint of mulling spice.  Flavors of molasses, white peach, and hint of hops at the finish that balances everything superbly.  A truly excellent beer that is underrated.
This is superb.  Beautiful dark mahogany pour.  Super complex spicy aroma.    Flavor is rich, nutty and spicy.
0.75 bottle. heavenly superbeer. syrup, liquorice roasty. some refreshing hops balancing the sweetness.

Tasted 12/05/2008. 330ml bottle from Rumbles, Wellington. Pours a dark reddish amber, bright, with a diminishing light tan head. Sweet herbal medicine character on the nose up front, reminiscent of cough syrup - or Jagermeister! Sweet in the mouth, plum and dark sugar, and reasonably heavy, with a light carbonation, a minty herbal note, and little spot of pepper. Medium bitterness, slightly toasty, with a woody, spicy alcoholic finish. Some aniseed too.  Warming. Good.

75cl bottle. Dark ruby brown with small fizzy beige head. Nose is aniseed, liquorice and syrupy, roasted malts. Syrupy, spicy flavor with liquorice, slight pineapple, aniseed and malts. Some hops in the finish. Medium to full bodied, smooth palate. In the end, quite simple and very easy drinking for its strength. Its good.
had at hardliver barleywine festival at brouwers in fremont. one of the better selections there.

33cl bottle courtesy of Hogtownharry. Thanks! Deep chestnut pour unleashes a billowing fluffy beige froth. Aromas of mint and dark fruit(plum, black cherry) upfront followed by floral spiciness and yeast. The flavour profile is sweet candied dark fruit with Belgian candy sugars. Following that there is a nice licorice component with other spices and sweet roasted nuts. Quite creamy and easy to drink considering the weight. Quite good. Thanks for the bottle Harry!

Pours a dark brown with tan head that falls to a thin layer.  Aroma is figs and anise.  Has a medium-heavy body with a good level of carbonation.  Taste is a mixture of anise and alcohol with a mild bitter aftertaste.  This is a really good beer.

Pours dark copper with off white head. Aromas of bread dough, caramel, brown sugar and dark fruits. Flavors are same as aromas. Medium to full body with prickly carbonation, creamy mouthfeel and slight warmth of alcohol. An excellent brew from one of my favorite breweries.
[bottle] Pours dark brown with a healthy off white head. Aroma is cinnamopn, spices, and malt. Flavor is black licorice, brown sugar, and some alcohol burn.

i dont know how i havent rated this beer before?  Sweet and spicy in the aroma, with hints of mint and chocolate.  Pours dark red, amber.  Sweet malts upfront with anise, brown sugar and molasses.  This brewery is excellent!

UPDATED: APR 17, 2008 Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Chestnut brown.  Anise, green spices, bubblegum and brown sugar in the aroma; very spicy, full of prickly, zesty character.
