Flavor is very nutty, with lots of roasted hazelnut and that pungent black licorice-anise sweet sharpness warming the body throughout; rich candied fruit sweetness.  Palate is full, generous and sparkly with long life in the warming, fruity overripe banana and berry finish.  Heavy, with a chasing bitterness consistently present.  Prime example; satisfyingly dense and thorough with no residual weight.

absolutley loved this beer.  On tap at erasmus.  Went perfectly with the candy glaze of the rabbit I had as a main course.  Rich candied flavor, dark fruits and currents.   Possibly the best food/beer pairing I have ever experienced.  At the recommendation of the owner.  Im glad he convinced me to change my order.
Tap at Kulminator  .... Deep brown ... WOW what a load of spices ... Cloves ... cinamon .... rich blackcurrent ... and dandylion and burdoch. (2005 vintage i think) too spiced.

750ml bottle from Rumbles in Wellington.  I had it at Galbraiths in Auckland too.  This is the best of the Christmas beers Ive had this year.  It was dark red in the glass with a decent off-white head.  Loads of spicy and fruity notes.  Quite sweet but the alcohol balances that.  Try not to drink a whole 750 by yourself like I did.

YERP. Wow this was very different. It has zero body to it, literally like 150proof liquor, but the flavor is so strong that the body seems to sting the flavors on your tongue. Really just a great beer, and a very harsh one if you arent into BSAs. 
The beer is sugary sweet like pickle juice is sour, and there are tons of ripe fruits floating around. Not so much many dry flavours like lemon or orange rind.  Very excellent.

330 ml. Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a soft off-white head.  Aroma is fruity with hints of plum and belgian yeast. Mouthfeel is highly carbonated and the glass has nice that persists throughout.  Flavor is sweet and complex with hints of dark fruit, star anise, raisins and belgian candi sugars.  Goes down warm and smooth, perfect for a cold winter night.  Finish is short and relatively sweet with just a hint of alcohol.  Would love to try an oak aged version of this beer.

bottle (2007 vintage) from west lakeview..... pours a semi-clear dark plum brown and decent sized off white head..... strong fruity aroma that jumps out of the glass along with some black licorice and spice..... flavors continue along that front but something mediciinal and cloyingly sweet gets in the way of it for me. the anise is very prominent.  mouthfeel was smooth and creamy but i couldnt get past the sweetness and black licorice.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2009 Dark brown. Sweet aroma with notes of liquorice and dark fruits. The flavour is sweet, but also a bit citric with strong hints of anis, banana, syrup and port.

330ml bottle courtesy of Mr. Manning.
very dark ruby/mahogany pour. GOod thick bubble tan head. Aroma is somehwat metallic, but has some nice fruity, and yeaty notes. FLavour is super sweet, lots of carael, candi sugar, and very fruity, especially plums, and figs. Finish is sweet, and slightly bitter, with a nice fruity aftertaste. WICKED belgian!

bomber from 7th street.  holy smokes this thing is bottled power.  Dark dark red with minimal foam.  smell is sweet like red man.  taste is of prunes, nuts, chocolate malts, honey, caramel... very sweet.  you sure cant taste the 10.5 abv but dude watch it, strange things start to happen.

Dark ruby red in colour, small white head. Spice aroma, hint of aniseed.
Candy stick and aniseed flavours. Very refreshing. Probably best suited for winter Christmas than southern hemisphere summer Christmas.
Uni Staff Club Tasting 29/01/08. clear warm, dark brown colour. Great head. Big full dark fruit aromas, prunes and raisens. Warming flavours almost a licorice note. Not overdone, perfect Xmas beer
pours brown with thin tan head.  Fruity nose. Fruity complex flavors consisting of Banana, orange, spices and a big licorice finish.
2005 Vintage Bottle @ Toronado 1/4/08, shared with Bikesandbeer.  Pours light orange with a 1 finger tan head.  Nose is wonderfully sweet.  Taste is sweet, light and very nice, quite smooth.

750 ml bottle. An unclear dark red beer with a quite big and persistent beige head. The aroma is very rich and sweet, with notes of port, fruits (banana and orange), spices and a litlle bit of alcohol. The flavour is also very powerful and sweet, with nose of sweet wine, caramel and cherry. The alcohol is not extremely hidden, but is warming more than disturbing. Full body, lively carbonation (maybe too much for my liking), long lasting finish with light bitterness and more sweetness. Complex, powerful, flavourful and very warming. This is an outstanding Christmas beer.

Pours lightly hazy copper-brown with a one-finger off-white head. Big candy sugar and spice aroma with a toffee and chocolate background. The chocolate comes through more in the flavor, where its joined by anise, heavy phenols, and musty yeast. Alcohol is apparent; it mixes with everything else for an unpleasant rubbery finish. Good, but I was expecting more from these guys.

Pour is a dark red with a large whtie head.  Aroma is of dark malts and some peppery spice.  Flavor is pretty decent with molasses and licorice with a touch of dark fruit and alcohol.  A tasty beer with no alcohol showing up that is going to overpower.

Deep red brown. A large creamy head that lasts. Filigrees on the glass. Unclear. Aroma of sweet fruit and berries. Flavor of plums. At last the alcohol kicks in giving you a warm sensation. OK winter warmer.
Dark read pour with little head.  Very strong bubble gum aroma.  Medium body.  Strong bubble gum liquorice taste to it with some bitterness at the end.  Very strange...not bad, just not for me.
Pours a deep burgundy red and looks very inviting! really smells like liquorice and tastes like that too. Dangerously drinkable at 10.5%

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. BB 29/08/10.
App.:  Clear, deep mahogany, large tan head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of sticky dark dried fruit, licorice, ginger(?), a bit vinous and woody, some alcohol, some bubblegum esters, warm spices, molasses, bread/cookie/biscuit.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Lots of molasses and deep, dark licorice, a bit vinous and woody, some green hop notes, more warm spice than the nose; on swallowing, quite sweet, tingling alcohol and a touch of bitterness; leaves a thick, oily licorice and dark malt afterbite.

A big beer.  Christmas brews are often over-spiced for my tastes, but this one works well.

Bottle. The color of a coke with a big, inviting, foamy, tan head. Smells of licorice, caramel, and spices. Real nice sweet, malty, spicy flavor with a touch of cherries. Something in the finish is quite sour, and when combined with the heavy alcohol notes, its pretty harsh to drink. Certainly an interesting beer and a good one, just not an easy one to drink.

Bottle at garethyoungs, via pat! Looks great in the glass, not bottle conditioned though? Aroma is bursting with liqurice, notes of tar and molasses, very spicey. Taste is again packed full of liqurice, sweet dark fruits, spicey and harsh carbonation doesnt even help just makes it hard to drink. This was one of the biggest let downs berwise this year.

A great looking beer.  Dark brown with a red tone and a massive head.  Sticky lacing on the glass.  Aroma is sweet, fruity, and alcoholic.  The aroma describes the flavor as well but there is much more going on.  Flavors of black pepper, plum, alcohol, toffee, anise, and more, all in no particular order.  This one is in the "WOW Zone."
On tap @ George Keeleys.  This full bodied beer is strong with rich undertones of spices.  Pleasant aftertaste.  They are not joking that its 10.5% alcohol.

Well in my emerging beek geekidness, this has surely got to qualify as complex. I feel like Im taking an exam each sip. Im on my own having a beer so Ive got nothing but the beer and my paranoia to fill my head and bloody hell its noisy in there. Brown in colour, almost like coke. Smells of all sorts, you posh nonces can put your finger on individual smells Im just enjoying drinking and smelling it. Great beer. And they had it on tap at my no.1 offy The Bottle Stop in Bramhall. Impressive for a tiny shop. Great drink, love it!

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2009 On tap @ the Delirium. My favorite of the night. Beautiful dark amber brown color with a thin cream head. Nose and flavor are rich dark fruits, toffee and caramel. I wish I would have taken better notes on this one!

75 cl. bottle from 2003. Pours a garnet color with an off white three finger head. Smells of black pepper, vanilla, mint, and caramel with a whiff of alcohol. Has a creamy yet lively mouthfeel. Medium to heavy bodied. Has a complex fruit, spice flavor of plums, apples, cinnamon, and black pepper, among others. Finishes with a nice peppery alcohol tang. 2004
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Clear brown with small light brown head. Complex aroma with dates, plums, rum, toffee, yeast and anise. Flavor is sweet with fruits, rum, toffee, yeast and anise in the end. Very complex and full bodied. Lovely!

On tap at Badaboomz.  Pours a dark slightly hazed reddish brown.  Lightly sweet.  Round malt.  Fruity bit of bite.  Subtle nose.  Thinner body.  Still.  Low carbonation.  Sweet.  Rather tannic somehow.  Dark malt character, raisins.  Toasty, which I dont care for much.  Fruity cherry, with some spice perhaps.  Higher alcohol in the flavor than the nose suggested (makes sense seeing the ABV here!).  Lingering toasty finish.  The toast and thinner body ruined it for me.  Who knows, might be a good ager.

Murky red/brown body with cream head.  Aroma of spices, candy sugar, and raisins.  Flavors of caramel, sugared dates, licorice.  Spicy in the finish with a nut like yeast.  A nice warming sipping beer.

Dark brown body, short to medium beige head. Smells like dark fruit, alcohol, raisins, caramel. Warm and sweet flavours with an emphasis on licorice and asinette. Body is robust. Its a rich and strong winter ale but I would have appreciated a litlle more balance, with some added hoppiness and bitterness, especially in the finish.
Draft at Ashleys in Ann Arbor.  Pours dark brown with no head and good lacing.  The dominant aroma is licorice.  The taste is winter spices, raisins, and a little cinnamon.  Slightly bitter.
33cl bottle- Very dark brown in colour with an alcoholic nose with an appealing liquorice, roasted scent. LIquorice and raisins feature in the sweet taste. Delicious.

From the bottle, pour is a ruby reddish/brown, with a meduim beige head.  Aroma of malt and sweetness.  Mouthfeel is very full with taste of burnt sugar, sweet malt and some nuttiness.  Loads of carbonation in this ale with a nice sweet finish.  Enjoyable on a cold winter evening with family members.

Feb. 2006 - Beer poured dark brown with little head and lacing. Aroma was dark fruits...also smelled like molten brown sugar (reminds me of the wife baking)...very sweet. Flavor was tempered...not nearly as sweet as it smelled...dark fruity flavor, caramel, strong alcohol. Thick mouthfeel. A nice experience.
Brownish amber pour with tons of carbonation. Enjoyable yeasty elements with an alcohol and biscuity kick and perhaps some candi sugar. A strong ale for sure.

Pours a deep brown with lots of ruby/amber reddish highlights and a large bubbly/frothy off white head that left lacing.  Aroma of molasses, licorice, brown sugar, nutty notes, Belgian yeast and some various spices.  Flavor of toasted malt, nuts, Belgian spices and yeast, some brown sugar, light alcohol. Got more spicy as I drank this.

Typical Christmas beer, that was super thick with very dominant alcohol. Poured a dark brown with thin head that lingered awhile and left okay lacing. For me, there were only two dominant features throughout this beer....black licorice and alcohol. Unfortunately, Im not a fan of black licorice, and so whatever else was in this beer was lost to me, as I just kept getting sidetracked by this taste.

IDefinitely a winter warmer at 10.5% abv, just not my favorite.
Old rating Reddish brown color. Spicy, nutty, brown sugar aroma, very Christmasy. Flavor is malty, brown sugar, wintergreen, and spice. For me, too much added spice. Nice mouthfeel.

This Belgian strong Ale pours a muddy brown amber color from a corked finished 750ml bottle. Large sized beige foamy head. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, candi sugar, fruit and a touch floral. A medium to full bodied BSA. The malts are fruity and sweet, with lots of brown sugar and caramel. A touch of chocolate and dark fruits and well. Earthy and round. A great sipping beer for a cool winter evening. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet.

330ml Bottle:  Sweet, malty aroma.  Smells of malts, dark fruits, raisins, alcohol, and caramel.  Poured dark amber/ruby in color with a large, dense, rocky, tan head that lasted throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Some medium-sized floating particles.  Heavily sweet, not bitter flavor.  Tastes of malts, dark fruits, raisin, graham crackers, alcohol, cherries, plums.  Medium body.  Sticky, tingly texture.  Lively carbonation.  Sweet malty finish.
WOW-EEEE smells like a candy store!!! Mmm Mmm Yummy!! Thick and hearty and full of Christmas Joy!!!! Wowww! on tap at Burpcastle.

Pours a deep burgundy-brown with a cream, light tan head. The nose is big and malty with spicy notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and a solid red wine-like note. Medium to full-bodied and slick with a dry woodiness and light alcohol on the finish. Sweet, malty and spicy with notes of cinnamon and anise concluding with a dry, vinous finish. A nice warming seasonal thats definitely worth trying at least once.

Bomber....dark brown with reddish hues, creamy lt., brown sugar head....smells like a mix of vanilla and candy sugar muddled with apples and alcohol...the quick carbonation floods the mouth with alcohol, then distinct licorice, then alcohol, then licorice follows again...it gives me that "strong shot face"....bitter malty finish....needs time im thinkin....just not my style of brew...perhaps I havent found just the right Belgian strong for me....or perhaps it has a lot to do with the licorice
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 Draft.  Pours very dark and the result is very smooth, cinammony, and christmas tasting. Some malt etc.  A great beer.

Its Christmas vacation at my house and I thought this would be a good one to help me relax in a house full of screaming teens (hopefully it works)
 The 750 ml bottle poured amber -ish brown the head for how long that it lasted in my Chimay challis was brownish but it turned to a nice lace. The mouth feel on this is incredibly smooth and it has a nice carbonation on the tongue. Aromas of sweet candy sugar along with Christmas spices (cinnamon, anise, cloves) with some dark fruit thrown in .Flavors of sweet malt , licorice along with a nice clean bitter finish to me it taste more like a spice than a hop bitter . It has a warming alcohol effect as well so this is a great winter sipper I will be looking for another one of these to put away for next year

Managed to sneak this one in at the Swan and Rushes, Leicester, on our S.Damagement lads night out. Aged blue cheese-tinged nose with nuts and slight cabbage. Smooth, narcotic ruby sipper steeped in marzipan, cherry and toffee headiness. Yellow piled suds. Definitely a dusting of cinammon in there. Maybe aniseed. But more than anything (as identified by Rob), Dandelion and Burdock. A fat, sweet, elusively spiced festive ale.

Pours dark ruby-brown with a small head. The aroma is sweet malt and fruity. The taste is slightly sweet malt, with dark fruits and complex spices and molasses. Nice mouth feel and warming when swallowed.

750ml bottle.  The beer pours a dark redish/brown color with a thick tan head which dissipates pretty quickly.  The beer has a caramel, dark fruit and holiday spice aroma, with generous portions of malts.

A fantastic warming winter brew from Belgium. The alcohol is noticeable, though it does not detract too much even with it being 10.5%.

11.2 oz. bottle. Attractive red-brown color. Active head on pour, but receded fairly quickly. Nose is of brandied fruit with hints of maple and honey. The alcoholic fruit character is full on the tongue, slightly touched with anise and molasses. The alcohol is almost medicinal, not in the best way. Ive another bottle, and I think Ill cellar it for next Christmas. Lets see how it does.

Deep ruby in color with a deep tan head.   Sweet aroma.  malts, spices, dark fruits, tart cherry, brown sugar, bubblegum, and floral.  Thick, silky body.  Intense flavor.  Dark fruits, spices, yeast, brown sugar, floral, and alcohol.  Finishes warm and full of alcohol.  Glad I opened this one on Christmas.  Excellent.
Overwhelming sweetness with hints of liquorice and cherries.  Presents well in a glass, a deep rich amber colour.  Nice to sip away on a cold night.

Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de caramel et dépices. Apparence: La couleur est brune légèrement opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et dépices avec une pointe de raisins. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de mélasse en arrière goût. (Rating #1396)

NorCal December 07 - An absolute pleasure of a beer to drink. Like Scaldis Noel, this beer is best savored during the later fall/winter months when its cold outside and you need some warmth inside. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, green apples, bubblegum, and a touch floral. Mouthfel has a little harshness to it but gets better after a bit of breathing. Appearance is carmelized brown color, nice fluffy head with fantastic lacing. Flavors that dance on your tongue are brown sugar, caramel, ginger, dark fruits, licorice and alcohol. A slow, soft burn as the beer travels down your throat. A fantastic finish to a fantastic beer. Glad I have half a case of this.

Bottle; poured a reddish brown color with medium to large off white head.  Aroma was of caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit and spice.  Flavor was very similar.  Malt dominated as expected.  Brown sugar and chocolate malt presence was very tasty.  Alcohol was well hidden.  Dark fruits and spice were only secondary notes, but worked well.  Moederately sweet.  Very tasty brew.

Pours a nice dark ruby brown with dense but small off-white head.  Nose is serious licorice, mild fruitiness and pine.  More licorice on the palate, which is quite smooth and thick without being overwhelming, but some nice cherry and dark fruits, maple syrup, and a solid menthol hop bitterness follow up. Alcohol is pretty present throughout.  A nice, if unusual, take on the winter brew.

Bottle, 75cl. The beer pours clear dark brown with a lightbrown head. Aroma is with caramel, malts and some spices. The flavor is very close to the aroma. The mouthfeel is rich and spiced, and has a great aftertaste. Overall one of the best seasonal beers on the market.

750mL Bottle: Dark brown to black body w/ a huge light brown sugar head. Has some blood red in the body when the light catches it just right. Real sweet sugar, licorice & sweet malts in the aroma. All alcohol here, perhaps it needs some aging (one would think Id learned my lesson w/ the Grand Cru). Perhaps this simply isnt a style of beer that I enjoy. Maybe Ill buy another one to age...probably not though.

(Bottle thanks larsniclas and rlgk) Pours deep reddish brown. The aroma is desert wine like with tones of sugar, light wood, sweet dark fruits but also lighter fruit tones of grapes, citrus/oranges, bananas, green apples, unripe pears, nectar and a light floral overtone. Malty tones of caramel and toffee. Some marzipan sweetness is also present. Hints of dark bread and liquorice. The flavour is nicely grapey vinous with some fruity tones of apples and pears. Too sweet finish with a lingering sugariness. Spicy and creamy yeast and malt mouthfeel. Alight sourish touch of dark berries is also notable. Medium to full bodied.

The pour is splendid a dark brown, with a large off white head and great lacing.  The nose is that of dark fruit, rum, malt and caramel. The flavor is pleasantly sweet up front followed with nice touches of dark fruit and vinous characteristics, not to mention just the right warming effect.  Another great seasonal, cant wait to age some and try this one again.

Very nice... Interesting aromas of spice and earth, malt and caramel. The flavor is full of prune, banana, spice, malt, and alcohol. The blend is very nice, and has given me interest in aging a bottle for next year.

12/12/07, 750ml bottle, Christmas 2004 vintage. pours murky brown with off white head. nose is loaded with rum raisins, plums, and lots of toffee. flavor is initially sweet toffee, raisins, hints of rum and port wine. it sort of thins out towards the finish while the aged malts become clear with port wine and caramelized plums. alcohol is well hidden. body is medium. This has aged well and its really tasty but perhaps this peaked at 2 years.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 Dec 2007
2005 (aged):  Excellent!!  

Really aged nicely.  Aroma of fruit and malt.  Really smooth with minimal alcohol burn.  Body maintains fullness.  Great stuff.  Thanks to Fatheads, Pitts.

Seriously heavy it is.  Perhaps the best Christmas beer ever.  The aroma is loaded with malt and fruit, but spice as well.  Some coriander and liquorice.  Anise in the flavor with more sweet malt and dark, fermenting fruit.  Some red wine, port.  Exceptionally full palate.  World Class.  I look forward to trying my 2005.
2007, poured a dark amber color, hints of sugar and light spices. nice tan head. sweet taste hoppy too. medium mouthfull, nice bitter ending. warming finish.. I liked it alot!

Christmas 2006 version poured with with a thick tan head and produced bold aromas of raisins and candi sugar. Flavors offered hints of maize and liquorice. Overall slightly sweet dark malt flavors dominated, with a slightly warming finish. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy dark amber/brown with a one finger lasting tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of caramel, sweet fruit, light spices, and light floral hops. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and a hint of alcohol. Very good.

Pours dark brown with reddish hues and a mostly receding wispy light tan head. Aroma of tropical fruits: banana, pineapple, lemon, and flowery esters. Taste of caramel, cherry, wood, banana, and peaches. Mouthfeel full bodied, lightly sweet with lush carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2016 First ratingRating added 12/8/200733 cl bottle, thanks larsniclas!Apparently purchased one year ago before our tasting session.Deep ruby red color, tan to brown head. Scent is alcohol, sweet, milky and spicy. Marzipan as well, also solvents. Spicy and alcohol taste, also milk and a slight bit acidic. Medium high bitterness.Smooth nice mouthfeel.6/4/6/4/14=3.4RerateBottle thanks to Rick! Sampled on December 7, 2016.Clear deep dark reddish brown color, tan head. Oranges, malty, chocolate scent. Sweet, oranges, chocolate, zest, lime taste. Sugary sweet, lime aftertaste. Medium full mouthfeel, medium low bitterness.8/4/7/4/15=3.8

Pours black, almost opaque, until raised to the light, when beautiful garnet highlights shine through. Head is huge, leaving a tan lace on the glass with each sip. Aroma is dark malt, candi suger and loads of dark fruit, including figs, dates and even some figgy pudding. Alcohol notes shine through in aroma. Flavor reveals more candi sugar, alcohol and dark fruits. Warming all the way down, leaving rich dark chocolate aftertaste. Body is suitably light for a Belgian style beer.
Flaske. En årgang 2006. Superdejlig juleøl. Her er sødmen bakket godt op af krydderier og en fløjlsblød mundfylde der gør at selvom man kan smage at øllen er potent kammer det på ingen måde over.
Superb.  Only very lightly spiced, but the usual notes of fig, black cherries, dark caramel and molasses are present.  The faintest nutmeg is also the only creature stirring, including the mouse.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 Pours a dark chestnut brown with a large forhty head.  Very malty, spicy aroma with hints of dark fruit, chocolate and pepper.  Sweet matly alcohol taste up front with a dry, peppery finish with hints of raisin and dark cherries.

Pours a very dark brown, approaching black.  Carbonation and lacing fairly low, but not bad.  Roasted, dark malt flavor, not much bitterness.  A very nice, Belgian flavor with some roasty, raisiny, fruity flavors dominating.   Really a beautiful, complex, very interesting beer.

A warm, spicy and tasty licorice bomb of a barley wine. 33 cL shared and sipped from snifters. Dark brown with a decently lasting off-white head. Big licorice and spices in the aromatics, some brandy notes. Light sweetness, mild licorice-and-hop bitterness. Thin and boozy and Id like some more.
Brown unfiltered body with little head.  Licorice flavor with brown sugar. Jose pistolas Philadelphia 12 oz tulip $7.50

[2003 Draft @ Mugs Ale House] Poured a lightly hazy red brown color with a small ring of off white bubbles, no lacing. Aroma of nuts, wood, caramel malts, dried fruits, and light oxidation.  Taste of tart cherries, nuts, wood, spices, with toffee, light roast, and a bit of alcohol in the finish.
UPDATED: FEB 25, 2009 Dark.  Light, transient head.  Aroma of malts and spice.  Flavors of sweet fruit and spices.  One of my personal favorites.  Id drink this any time.

Bottle 0.75 l. Very intense and deep almost non-existent head. Aroma has plums, liqourice, malts and spiciness. Flavor is initially mainly liqourice and anise, even a bit too much so. It took a while to get over it, but there were the usual suspects, plums, raisins. More on the sweet side, but very well hidden alcohol. The liqourice is very strong, but still surprisingly balanced as a whole.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 Dark semi-opaque cherry color with almost no head. Slightly sour aroma with brown sugar and cinnamon spiced apple notes. Taste is sharp and raisiny with caramel and spice burn at the onset, and ebbs to smooth balance. Finish is lightly carbonated with biscuity taste and alcoholic warming. Rating #600.  Draft 13 oz/$7.50
Pours dark brown with a large head. Taste is balanced, soft and quite sweet. Malty aroma with liquorice and herbs. Raisins and fruits. Very multidimensional taste. Alcohol is very well hidden.

330ml bottle.My God, what a gorgeous beer. Pours a deep, ever slightly cloudy ruby-chestnut with a pillowy, bubbly khaki head. Streaming bubbles keep that head from disappearing so that it can leave lumps of Brussels lace on the sides of the glass from beginning to end. Aroma consists of layers of fruit and spice, including juniper, raisin,  dried cherries, malty molasses, a touch of citrus and a judicious dash of black pepper. Flavor includes all of the above with a touch of anise for good measure. Moderate hop bitterness comes online on the middle of the tongue. Full-bodied with a smooth and strangely creamy finish. I have found a new favorite Christmas beer. Wow, is this stuff good.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2013 A very deep and dark brown colour with a blond and medium head. The nose is complicated and there are sweetness, liquirice, lot of anise and hint of herbs. Taste is quite similar than aroma: quite sweet, anise, liquirice, dark fruits and maybe some alcohol. This is very pleasant, strong and complicated beer for a warm up the cold winter nights.

We drank this 2006 version of Carolus Noël while we were preparing our Thanksgiving meal. It was a gift and thank you. I liken this beer very much to the Gouden Carolus Grand Cru of the Emporer that I have drunk before. Very sweet, very smooth and way to tasty for a 10.5% beverage. This would NOT be my Go-To beer, but is a good special treat for the holidays. I like the slight anise flavor at the finish of this beer. This is skillfully done, fine beer.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2007 Nice aroma...very nice appearance... flavor is great but not FANTASTIC. A bit too sweet for me with a hint of something... clean and hides the alcohol well. Palate is smooth and creamy.....

Overall very pleasing. Not an everyday beer but a damn fine treat. 

======================

After finding this on draft, I must recount. This beer has a great flavor; semi-sweet, hides acohol well, ....

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2009 Bottle (33 cl) from Barley Wine, Copenhagen, Denmark. Deep copper with a creamy large beige head. Sticky caramelly aroma with sweet liquorice and spices. Medium bodied and very smooth. Way too sweet.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2008 Bottle (10%) from BevMo. Dark ruby in color. Sweet aroma. Some interesting spices, maybe ginger and anise. Some yeast and a root type of scent. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is somewhat spicy. Quite a bit of roasted dark fruitiness and more black licorice. Very rich. Good winter beer. Too bad were having Santa Anas. Alcohol is well hidden. Enjoyable brew.

Bottle. You dont get a much better balanced spiced Belgian Strong Ale than this one. Dark brown colour with a nice head. Aroma is dark fruits and spices. Flavor is dark fruits, caramel, anis and malts. A beautifull mouthfull.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2015 750ml bottle (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Winter Ales 2004)
Rich brown. Sweet winey strongly spiced malts on the nose. Salty salmiakki in the taste, ginger and dark fruits. Very complex, very potent.
Rerate: 750ml bottle - shared by Janne - thanks! (7:4:8:4:14=3.7)
Apple, marzipan aroma. Crisp palate, lively carbonation. Apple in taste too. No hint of 10.5%.
Rerate: 750ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki) BB2011 (7:4:7:4:14+=3.6+)
Lovely apricotty aroma. Super mellow fruity body. Light palate, soft, has no sign of any strength at all. Lovely malty brew, aged wonderfully, but perhaps beginning to weaken.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before 25.09.09, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on Halloween 2007; eye: ruby, clear, good effervescence, voluminous beige head that turnes into a carpet, lacing; nose: alcohol, caramelized malt, candied fruits, spices; mouth: caramelized malt, alcohol, candied fruits, spices, pepper from the alcohol, Amaretto, finale in caramelized malt with a good presence of alcohol, creamy and alcoholic texture, full body, mildly sweet, not much carbonation; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant 25.09.09, via Importations Privées Bièropholie; savourée à lHalloween 2007; il : rubis, claire, bonne effervescence, mousse beige abondante qui se transforme en un tapis, dentelle; nez : alcool, malt caramélisé, fruits confits, épices; bouche : malt caramélisé, alcool, fruits confits, épices, poivre de lalcool, Amaretto, finale en malt caramélisé avec une bonne présence dalcool, texture crémeuse et alcoolique, corsée, moyennement sucrée, peu carbonatée; en résumé : bien

UPDATED: APR 18, 2008 Thanks to Joebrew for sharing this 07 vintage.  Spectacular, but will be better with some age on it.  Sweet malty nose with spice revealed as the beer warmed.  Similar taste with some dark fruits.  

------- />
Had to up the rating a little.  HUGE anise flavor in this latest batch, one of my favorite Christmas beers.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2008 Aroma of liquerish, alcohol and spice. Dark deep brown amber color, darker then i expected. Spiced amaretto liquor taste with  traces of plum raison and spice, enjoyable but different then most other belgians. Deffinately drink this on a cold winter night.

750 ML Bottle-Clear brownish color w/almost no head. Spiced Belgian aroma. Dark Belgian flavor w/traces of plum, raisens & spice. Traces of pine to it. This beer has some kick to it; Id call it a real Winter warmer. I drank it at the wrong time of year; save this one for a cold winter night around the fire & you will really enjoy it!

bomber corked and caged poured a thick looking brown red in color with a tan layer of foam on the beer. smell is yeast, plumb, alcohol, spice, pine, and some sweetness. the taste is really quite smooth, midrange on mouth feel, and finishes with a spicy alcohol snap. quite a layer of dried dark fruits like figs and plums, definitely some sweetness but not in a way that is over the top, many interesting subtle flavors like anise and licorice, and there is a light bit of mint. very interesting beer that warmed on me, perhaps because i drank the whole bomber myself.

2003 vintage on tap at Lucky Baldwins.  Coffee with cream color and a creamy off white head.  Aroma of caramel, tobacco, leather, and spice.  Creamy palate.  Amaretto liquor taste with a touch of orange and clove, tobacco in the finish and a lingering warmth.

750, corked and baled. Pours nearly black with a moussy tan head of unremarkable depth. Nice figgy, roasty, green-apple-y nose, with maybe a bit of cardboard taint in there but scarcely at all. Nice soft velvety body with subdued carb and gentle flavors. Figs in the lead, prunes, other tree fruits. Some light caramely sugary sweetness. Gentle, soft finish. Lovely stuff Id happily drink anytime.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2007 0.33 l bottle. Pours dark brown body with smaller brown head. Wonderful aroma of caramel mixed with lot of things like punch, vanilla, some fruits etc. Flavor isnt any worser, very full, alcohol is not felt at all, a bit sweetish. Palate also without complaints. Low carbonation fits well on thins one. Nice long finish. Alcohol is felt only after finishing the bottle. Oh yeah, almost perfect beer!
750ml bottle. Pours dark copper color with brown head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and spicey. Taste of caramel and malt with clean finsih.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2009 Garrafa, 330 ml, em 2007 e em agosto de 2008. Coloração avermelhada, escura, creme bege denso e persistente, deixando uma fina camada perene. Excelente aroma: malte torrado, frutas vermelhas e fermento. Final levemente amargo e torrado. Consistência aveludada, densa. Cerveja complexa, encorpada e harmoniosa. Carbonatação média-baixa, muito boa. Álcool muito bem inserido no conjunto: presente, mas equilibrado.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2012 
Name: Gouden Carolus Noel
Date: December 31, 2003
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Whole Foods Market, DC
Vintage: 2003
Appearance: muddy brown, easily excitable thin tan head
Aroma: big complex malt aroma with lots of candy sweetness, licorice, ripe fruit, and a hint of spices showing up in a mild alcohol fume
Flavor: rich malt flavor with lots of complex character including chocolate, plums, and raisons, no bitterness but well balanced to keep it from being too sweet, a fine way to end the year

Name: Gouden Carolus Noel
Date: May 15, 2007
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar stock
Vintage: 2003
Score: 5.0 to 4.8
Appearance: specks of drippy lace
Aroma: such wonder ripe fruit aroma and light spices like rum soaked fruit cake
Flavor: rich flavor with caramel, chocolate, and lots of ripe fruit, tons of complex flavor, light balancing bitterness, sweetness has dried a bit but still incredably big and rich, the yeast shot adds a bready character and enrichens the chocolate but detracts from the fruit

Date: December 25, 2008
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar stock
Vintage: 2003
Aroma: rich sweet fruity aroma, lots of ripe plum, brown sugar sweetness
Flavor: rich and fruity flavor, light spicyness, brown sugar sweetness, deep rich fruits
Overall: a few years of age does this beer proud

Name: Gouden Carolus Noel
Date: December 31, 2009
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar stock
Vintage: 2003
Aroma: continues to be the best plum pudding aroma, rich ripe fruits, caramel candy and vanilla sweetness, light spices
Flavor: rich caramel malt flavor, lots of ripe fruits, brown sugar sweetness, nice spicyness, sweet caramel and vanilla, the yeast shot adds an extra dimension of richness

Name: Gouden Carolus Noel
Date: February 07, 2012
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar stock
Vintage: 2003
Aroma: sweet rum raison aroma, Christmas candy, spices
Flavor: sweet candied fruit flavor, spices, dark fruits
Overall: stands the test of time, as wonderful as ever

One of the better Christmas ales that I have had in quite some time.  Aroma of dark fruits and spice (plums, raisins, currants and nutmeg).  A hint of sweet on the palate but not over powering.  Thick rich and heavy, something to enjoy on a cold winters night.

Bouteille 750ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur brune rubis et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (figues et moyen de raisins vineux, léger de prunes, notes dagrumes et de cerises noires), épicé (anis, muscade, cannelle, coriandre, notes de clou de girofle), malté de caramel toffee sucré, de sucre brun et de sucre bonbon, léger dalcool doux avec des notes de noix, de vanille et de chocolat noir. Ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse et moyennement sirupeuse. Goût de levures fruitées (figues, raisins vineux, moyen de prunes, léger de zest dagrumes, notes de bananes, traces de cerises noires) avec un goût épicé (anis, coriandre, léger de clou de girofle, notes de cannelle) et des notes de vanille et boisées lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de caramel toffee sucré légèrement rôti, de sucre brun (léger de sucre bonbon rappelant la gomme balloune) et avec des notes de chocolat noir et de mélasse parallèlement à un goût dalcool moyen et assez réchauffant (légèrement vineux et aux notes liquoreuses rappelant le rhum) puis en finale lon retrouve un goût asséchant de levures épicées (léger de muscade, notes de poivre, traces de gingembre). Post-goût long et un peu sec, moyennement amer dalcool ainsi quun goût de levures fruitées (moût de raisins, figues, petites notes de zest dagrumes et de pelures de bananes) et des notes boisées.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a very large sized head of foamy fine to large sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent typically carbonated brown colored body and a good lacing. The aroma was malty and spicy. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt hops spices and a mild alcohol backing. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Liquor aroma. Wood, nuts, chocolate, coffee, alcohol a little extreme, toffee.......................................Delir Cafe, Brussels. aroma de licor. Madeira, nozes, chocolate, café, álccol um pouco excessivo, toffee.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 Hard to go wrong with anything from this brewery. This Christmas ale is basically a modified version (i.e. more prominently spiced) of their exceptional Grand Cru. A dark, strong Belgian, the holiday taste comes courtesy of a quite subtle (and subtlety is too rare for these kinds of seasonals) incorporation of anise, clove, a hint of cinnamon and fig. Add that to the already gorgeous big malt profile of this brew and its a superlative drink.

Tastet it as well from draft as well from bottle. Very spicy beer. You already smell it. A very special tast, you will find also in the Brown Easter Bear. Also very strong and you feel it after drinking large bottle. A must for beer lovers

Bottle saying "Christmas Ale", from 2006. Amaazing brew indeed. Pours a dark hazy brown colour. Ha sa beaut of a brownish head though it doesnt last for long. The aroma is bustling with sweet caramel malt, fruits (raisins and figs), nuts and spices, which also are to be found profoundly in the flavour. Great mouthfeel with a nice tickeling touch of the alc. on the tongue. 
I drank several of these with an old brewer from Carlsberg, who said it was one the best beers he had tred in 40 years!

Bottle. Small tan creamy, fizzy head that was mostly lasting, fair amount of lacing, transparent, visible carbonation, and a ruby hue with brown highlights. Nose was malty, hints of chocolate and caramel, alcohol was noticeable, light floral notes, and dark fruit. Flavor was vinuous, malty, darkfruit, and some chocolate. Mouthfeel was tingly with a slight burning, warming sensation. Medium body. Wish this one would have come my way during the winter as it would have been a very nice brew to sip on on a cold, snowy night. Oh well. Definitely worthy of a try if you get chance.
Ruby red in color with small off white head. Sweets, fruits, nutmeg, and licorice in aroma and taste.

The 750ml bottle poured a clear, deep ruby red beverage with a small creamy off-white head that was mostly lasting and left great lacing on the glass. The aroma was wonderful, displaying notes of banana, peach, cotton candy, licorice, coriander and caramel. The body was medium-full with soft carbonation and a silky, smooth texture. The flavor starts out moderately sweet staying that way throughout the medium-long finish. There is also a nice alcohol warmth at the end.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2009 750 ml. Pours dark brown, ruby red when held to light. Head is light brown and small-medium. Aroma is slightly spicy toffee. Flavor is toffee-caramel with some alcohol warmth, turning to a dryer date-raisin-fig. Palate is creamy smooth with a nice dry prickly alcohol finish. A spiciness that subtly hints at coriander, ginger, and bitter orange peel. Excellent winter holiday warmer, even though I sampled in April!

750ml bottle, 10% alc. listed on label, pours a a dark brown ruby with a off-white head, nice lacing, spice, caramel and dark malt aromas, sweet & apple cider fragrances, faint alcohol in the background, light fruit scent, dark malt and caramel flavors with a citrus in the mouth, small bite in the finish, faint alcohol taste that was unveiled as it warmed, not overwhelming at all just in the background, this is a Winter Warmer drink, medium mouth feel.

Cloudy dark mahogany hue, with some reddish highlights, a tan-colored head, but falling quickly, and leaving laces, yeasty, fruity nose of candied orange peel, toasted malt, spicy nutmeg, sweet dark dried fruit of raisins, dates, plums, brown sugar, hint of chocolate in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet yeasty, curaçao fruity character, with a candied lemon peel fruitiness, spicy notes of nutmeg, anise, faint licorice, with a subtle Grand Marnier liquor alcoholic warmth mouthfeel, toasted and chocolate malt flavors, leading towards a malty, spicy anise, alcoholic finish.

750 mL bottle. Pours opaquely cloudy rusty brown with tight tan head. The aroma is tremendously malty, rum, chocolate, caramel, just a hint of bubblegum, fruity sweetness. The flavor is initially a sweet, yeasty muffin type taste, then rum soaked raisins. Some orange comes out toward the finish. The aftertaste is sweet and slightly woody. Honestly, the flavor isnt as rich as the aroma. But its still quite tasty.

Bottle.  Pours brown/copper color with a medium tan head.  Aroma of banana, bubblegum, cloves and some other pungent spices.  Nice aroma.  Taste is sweet, some molasses, caramel, spices and dark fruit.  Plums come to mind, especially in the finish.  Silky mouthfeel, alcohol is well hidden for 10.5%.  Good brew.
This nice christmas ale is very strong according to its very high alcoholprocent, but still with a nice ale
Bottle. Dark brown colour with medium white foamy head. nice aroma of chocolate and caramel.  Very good taste and Suberb palate. Fantastic beer.
Silver medal in Beer World Championship 2004 category Dark strong ale. Not my kind of beer usually. Some caramel and vanilla. Sweet spices too. Typical strong aroma. Complex.

Drak brown, hazy, but the fizzy head seemed to disappear quickly. Aromas of caramel, banana, and sweet spices. Sweet caramel flavour, a little banana, some sweet spice, and a definite orange rind note in the finish. Not as smooth or complex as the classic in my opinion, still delicious.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Dark cloudy brown with some white head. Great aroma of choclate and spice, vanilla, and citrus orange. Very smooth mouthfeel, and while all of the tastes do not materialize boldy, it is very tasty and refreshing.A great brewery.
thanks for bringing in IPFreely.

Bottle: Poured a deep burgundy brown color ale with a huge foamy head with great retention and good lacing. Aroma of sweet candy and anis is dominating and quite enjoyable and almost reminiscent of Rochefort. Taste is a nice mix between strong Belgian malt, sweet candy and anis. There is some sweetness but it never goes overboard and provides great balance with some light typical Belgian yeast. It appears that this brewery just wont stop to amaze me with all those great beers.

Hello my name is Ryan and this beer kicks ass....Now, on to the more detailed aspects: A typical color and aroma, though more pungent, for this style. Heavy aroma of malts, spice and dark fruit. Flavor was (SURPRISE!) more of the same, though extremely smooth with light carbonation (this bottle was a cellared 2005 vintage via BigSilky). The aftertaste was light but lingering and yada yada....just all around, fantastic.

A long after Christmas treat for me.   Sampled a 750ml cellared bottle, 2005 vintage.   Plum, spiced and sweet malt flavors and aromas in the full bodied Belgian Strong.   With all the ratings listed here and the fact that I never heard of it before tells me that Im out of the loop.    Ill have to try more Gouden Carolus offerings in the future.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2008 BB 03-10.  Pours a dark brown-red color with clarity and a fairly full, frothy, creamy, beige head; head is mostly lasing and leaves nice, tight lace.  Nose is fairly fruity and almost rum-soaked; anise is dominant with lighter notes of toffee, raisin, plum, light yeast, and some spicing (ginger/clove).  Flavor is complex and quite potent; still lots of anise with toffee, brown sugar, raisin, light cherry, clove, nutmeg, light yeast with some acidity and mild bitterness.  Palate was fair and detracted some from the unique flavors; lively, medium, but round with some noticable warmth from the alcohol.  Finishes still mostly sweet with anise, raisin, and brown sugar but also with a tobacco note (interesting but not unpleasant).  Palate and the overpowering anise notes do not allow this to be something special with so many wonderful flavors and complexities.  Very interesting and showing lots of potential; unexpected and surprisingly likable.  I tried this one aover a year ago and had something completly different: much more carbonation and less anise notes.  Both were interesing in their own right but both would be great with a bit of tweaking.

At the 2007 Big Beer, Belgians, & Barleywines Festival in Vail. Pours a copper color with a thick white head of spider-web lacing. A concoction of raisins, brown sugar, coriander and cough syrup. This has some serious heat. An outstanding holiday beer in the old school manner.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 Pours a two-fingered creamy white head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Cloudy mahogany color. Strong carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Raisin/plum nose. Flavor - sweet raisin, caramel and spices, high ABV is noticeable. Nice Christmas ale. 750ml bottle, gift from Liquid Solutions Oregon City, Or.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, candis sugar, orange. Flavour is spices, alcohol, hop, cellar notes, candis sugar, roasted. Harmonic christmas beer.
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with tan colored head. Sweet candy caramel and spice aroma. Sweet spicy malt flavor.
bottle 2006 from World of Beer - light head, fruity, sweet with spices, very complex flavor - absolutely delicious! Thank You Santa!
750 ml bottle Lots of dark fruit and banana on the aroma of this brown ale with smallish fizzy head.  Flavor was more dried fruit and caramel.  Alcohol burn and nice fruity finish.  Very yummy.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of licorice, spices, and citrus. The flavor is smooth, spices, licorice, citrus, and fruit. Great Beer.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2007 RE-RATE. Bottle.  Pours rich crimson brown with nice, clinging lace.  Aroma is banana that is quickly offset by sweet berry, concealed in part by sour malt.  Flavor is a rush of banana followed by a sweet malt that slowly fades along the back of the tongue.  Spicy wood and hints of alcohol are detectable as well.  Full mouthfeel.  Much better than the last bottle I had.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 5, 2009 750 & 330 ml bottle compared. Mahogany body with big beige head. Complex aroma, candysugar, malt, fruit and alcohol. Flavor is complex and sweet. Candysugar, malt, alcohol (less than expected) yeast, spices, dry fruit and some caramel. Nice and interesting, but the sweetness may be to overpowered after a few glasses. The difference between small and big bottle is minor, one extra year storage make more to this brew (smoother).

Dark amber brown color with a dark tan, rapidly diminishing head that leaves some sticky foamy lacing on the glass.  Theres some magical quality to the aroma that all Gouden Carolus beers seem to share... a mouth-watering, brown-sugary, spicy, malty sweetness.  The flavors of the Noel are similar to those of the Classic and the Grand Cru, but also present a heavy spiciness (cinnamon, clove, nutmeg), dried fruits (dates, plums, raisins, cherries), dark brown sugar, caramel, and a certain woody smokiness.  This beer is very complex and interesting.  The finish is somewhat astringent, and leaves behind an amazing tobacco-like, woody, smoky aftertaste.  Great stuff.

Cellar temperature corked 750ml bottle:  Pours a cloudy brown amber color with mega floaties and a small light tan frothy head that leaves quite a bit of lacing as it dissipates. At first, the alcohol in the aroma was dominant.  Thereafter:  Excellent blend of rich malts, grassy hops, cinnamon, brown sugar, cherries, plums and orange peel.   Heavy body and very smooth with ample carbonation.  Ending is pleasant and subtle.  Give me more!  : )

Bottle:  Pours a dark brownish orange with a thin tan head, aroma is of rumcake, brown sugar, lemon, cherries, plums and other dark fruits, medium bodied, smooth texture, mellow carbonation, starts and ends lightly sweet with a long aftertaste.  Very nicely done.  This bottle is between four and five years old and aged nicely.

C&C 750. No date on the bottle, but I believe this is the current vintage. Murky dark amber with an orange tint. Dense beige head. Very complex nose - sweet, spicy fruit, estery, dates and caramel. Spicy fig and date flavors, very deep malt flavors, dark brown sugar, light anise. Heady stuff - very good!
750ml bottle. Light brown colur with a little head. Alot of flavours..caramel and fruits. Good strong beer. -I like it-

0.75 l bottle. Reddish brown color with thick tan head. Sweet, tart, fruity, caramelly and spicy aroma with notes of licorice, anis, cinnamon and  artificial candy store aroma. Sweet, tart and warming flavor with raisins and caramel. Too sweet.

Bottle from the Blue Max. Pours an amber brew with very little head.  A fine example of the style. Loads of luscious
exotic fruit esters from the Belgian yeasy strains. Man, what mastery. Even some funky spices tossed in there to make this even better. Rich and flavorful.

This beer was really nice on tap at Concordia ale house. Pours dark copper brown with a small of-white head. Rich caramel flavor with hints of chocolate, plum, cherry, and molasses. Sweet up front with a lightly bittered finish to keep it from being cloying. The spices in the finish show, but are slightly muted since his didnt have a ton of carbonation cutting through the thick body.
pours a hazy dark brown with a small tan head.  brown sugar aroma.  flavors of plum, raisin, peach, brown sugar, caramel and molasses.  very rich and full bodied.

On tap at oak cafe. Poured a brown color with a  small head. Aroma was of spices and also some malty and belgian yeastiness. Flavor was a little too medicinal tasting to me and it kind of overpowered the taste.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Of the three Noels I picked up for Christmas the Gouden Carolus stood out as the weakest.  In retrospect it seems regrettable because it presents such a wide pantheon of tastes, but none of them work in concert.  It fulfills neither the Christmas spirit, nor any secular day of festive drinking, and so was cast into the shadows of the two other Noels and left to ponder its mistakes.  The head is thin but soft as goose down, and maybe even softer than the calm, soothing narrative voice of Morgan Freeman.  The Noel itself is a little less comforting, taking the unmistakable shade of red of human blood.  Freshly ground black pepper and hops lead the aromatic charge, sending the drinker reeling with its pungency.  Then it mellows with a very dairy phase, smooth and silky like cream and a bit funky like good stinky cheese.  A little banana is thrown into the fray to sweeten things up, but gently enough that it doesnt trespass on the aforementioned cream, and then a little coke to rough it up with even more sweetness but of a more calloused and inveterate kind.  Theres also a nice smell that borderlines between plum and wine, and after that a few dashes of spice, including cumin with its distinct association with chili, and a smattering of nutmeg.  Its a very raucous smell, but lacks cohesion, losing some of its potential for excellence.  It is, however, well matched to the taste which maintains a kinship to its more gaseous counterpart while maintaining enough difference to give it something to show for itself.  The banana makes a triumphant return but this time holding hands with a dark malty figure.  Its a fun pairing and reminds me of a lot of chocolate-banana combo desserts, like the hallmark banana split.  Then this simple pairing slides down to a spicy and peppery stage reversing the order of the smell, before collapsing into a surprisingly simple, quiet and anti-climactic yeastiness.  The whole sequence is flavored with allspice, juniper and cardamom, but it ends up being too spicy, and very similar to excess alcohol ends up eclipsing more flavors then it complements.  I see a lot of expression and a lot of brewers frustrations, but its simply too many flavors all at once without any direction or precision.  It seems fuzzy and chaotic, and even worse, purposeless.  Its hard to describe, but I like a beer thats confident with itself, and determined enough to have a specific agenda.  The Gouden Carolus Noel seems a bit confused, and may need time to straighten itself in preparation for Decembers to come.

A priori, Gouden Carolus takes a simple but elegant approach, showing deep Burgundy hues and a clean off-white coiffure - the mark of a quiet noblesse, a certain feminine flair begging wordlessly with powdered cheeks. Up close, it is a grand perfume that exudes. A symphony of spices, soft yet striking, translated on the nose as allspice, saffron and black pepper. Sweet esters appear with agility: banana, bubble gum, lemon, a hint of minty pine and maraschino cherries forming melodious legato. It seems, however, that darkness lurks. A touch of fig, the ripeness of raisins, caramel orchestrating transparently; this context allows the springy fragrances to sing even louder and echo tumultuously in the mouth. The burning spiciness of black pepper, orange peel, nutmeg, anise and saffron combined initially overwhelm the tongue, forming a voluptuous cacophony, a sudden and deafening climax. Soon, interwoven subtleties begin to appear, tones of bread and wood, fig, prune, bacon, cherry and banana. Sip after sip, as the ale warms its body becomes smoother, individual spices begin to dissociate, its flavor lingers long after the swallow. The rhythm progressively slows until the last drop is consumed. Beer is sometimes a sensual experience.

Quarter inch haed thas gone in a minute.  Very bark brown.  Could smell this bad boy from 2 feet away.  Light yeast, light bread, and light maltiness.  Strong cherry, with maybe a hint of allspice and vanilla.  Moderate alcohol taste.  Good, but not outstanding as a "Christmas" beer.

2006 bottle shared with tpkenned. Translucent and chestnut copper in color with a foamy, dark tan head being fed from below. Black pepper over prunes and plums marinating in a pool of brandy, licorice and caramel sauce lead the nose. Nutmeg dances with burnt anise for a charming, spicy black dimension. Grape currant gets boiled down into a plum paste. Daisies twine into a broiled concord bed being charged with charred cocoa beans stuffed with raisins. Nutmeg gets tossed into a pruney, dark ginger and rye bread compound. Fluffy mouthfeel and supportive effervescence to the flavorful stream. Plum sauce coats spicy, spiced pumpernickel on its way out, along with a hint of caramelized cardamom cola to sweetly sing into the night.

Dark copper appearance with a large beige head and light lacing.  Yeasty, rich malt aroma with layers of licorice, ripe dark fruit and some spicyness.  Sweet, caramel malt taste blends with flavors of plums, cherries, licorice and molassas.  Smooth, full bodied, modestly carbonated mouthfeel with a warming, lingering, dessert wine-like finish.

Full aroma of sweet malt and belgian yeast thats completely decked out with spices. Appears as a bold dark brownish red and creamy head. The drink is perfectly balanced and still allows a strong domination of malt, sugars, and light dashes of spice.  This ale gives off a warm presence of alcohol but also hides it beneath all of the flavors and full body creamness. Merry Christmas is very true if you have this during the holidays.

Shared w/ Ben during 8th annual New Years chill fest.  Golden/copper amber color with moderate carbonation.  Floral and berry aroma; with a touch of alcohol fizzle for good measure.  With global warming taking its effect on our KC winter, we needed a beer that resembled a chilly night.  The label helped.  Tasted of berries: Blue, Straw, and Black.  I swear there was some maple syrup in there too.  This was tasty.  Not Bens favorite but what does he know? (Acquired from Johns; IA CTY)

Bottle, 2005 Edition. Pours with a dark color and a nice head. There is a subtle spiciness in the aroma as well as in the finish. Otherwise, toffee aroam and a hint of sweet fruit.
Flavor is a combination of many subtle components, Belgian yeast of course, as well as strawberriy, caramel and the mentioned spicy finish. When it warms up the alcohol becomes a bit more pronounced. Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours a golden brown with a yellowish/light brown head. Sweet candy aroma  wine gums maybe. Sweet licorice. Spicy. Interesting but cloying. Flavour is sweet and candy-like like the aroma. Notes of plums. Slightly bitter finish. Again, interesting, but cloying. Overall this was an experience, but its  like I said  just too damn cloying. Couldnt even finish it. So Ill have to go against the grain on this one. 29-12-06.

Nice aroma of ripe fruit, spicy yeast and candy. Pours a deep copper, thin head. Fruit sweetness up front, candy makes an appearance again. Hops also show up, along with warming alcohol. An enjoyable beer

Pours very deep, dark brown (nearly opaque) with a lovely tan head consisting of very fine bubbles that lace the glass heavily. The aroma starts strongly with bubble gum, freshly mowed grass, and funky, funky yeast. Some malt and dark fruit also make a subdued appearance. The flavor starts off spicey - nutmeg and licorice. It is sweet on the tip of the tongue, too, though also quite carbonated and tingly. The middle of the tongue shows some acidity, lots of fruit (banana, prune), sweet malts with the brief suggestions of caramel and chocolate, and more tingly carbonation. The finish is dry and full of alcohol, but also other flavors like caramel, spice, more fruit, and yeast. The mouthfeel is surprisingly thin for a beer that is this strong and sweet (no doubt thanks to dark candi sugar) and it is very highly carbonated. As I swirl the beer in its snifter, agitating it to release carbon dioxide, the mouthfeel gets smoother and creamier. Overall, very nice and quite memorable.

Bottle. Fantastic reddish dark colour with a nice off-white head. Aroma was raisin, prunes, caramel, liquorish, roast, cinnamon and some characteristic Gouden Carolus yeast in there as well. This almost makes you think of a good Port wine. Full bodied with a creamy texture and a lively carbonation. Medium sweet flavour, but some hoppy bitterness to balance it with. Finish is sweet and average lasting. Wow this beer is just so smooth and defiantly the best Christmas beer we had at the evenings Christmas party. Great for sipping while unwrapping the presents.

Rating number 600.
Last night was a 2004 bottle of Gouden Carolus Cuvee de Kaiser; tonight (Christmas day 06) this 2006 bottle of Noel. 

As before, the cork comes out with an explosive pop, though maybe not with quite the force of last night. The beer pours nicely but not with the full elegance of the other.

The aroma offers rich dark caramel again; orange zest and a bit of spice,  dried fruit -- and the flavor comes through with bits of all of these, though dominated by spice and alcohol. Perhaps in part, the flavors of this young beer have not yet had time to meld and soften adequately.
The mouthfeel is adequate though not quite as luscious as the Cuvee de Kaiser, and overall the beer - while nice - pales in comparison that other offering from the same brewery.
Taste is of dark chocolate, smoked almond and baked apple. Big and delicious with enough holiday spice and licorice to justify its noel status. This is what big belgians are all about.

25.4 oz bottle marked 04-05.  Hazy copper brown with a slightly tan head and coating lace.  Nose of caramel, raisin and alcohol notes that remind me of rubber cement; maybe this is the yeast.  Roasty chocolate and raisin with some subtle spicing.  A little thin body-wise with light carb.  I expected more richness but still a nice holiday brew.

[bottle] Deep, dark brown color, with a coarse, tan head that quickly diminishes. Aroma is alcoholic, sweet and fruity. Flavors are very malty and sweet, with dark fruits and caramel. A hit of licorice and plenty of booze finish things off. Very dense, syrupy mouthfeel, with moderate carbonation. Really seems to warm you up quite nicely. Overall a really tasty, complex beer.

(Bottle 75 cl) Vintage 2003. Pours a hazy orangey brown with a tall, dense beige head leaving laces. Extremely complex aroma - roasted malt, prunes, raisins in rum. Full, rich and sweet body with roasted malt, again raisins in rum and soft accents of port. Some licorice and other chrismasy spices as well. A well balanced and beautifully complex beer. 241206

75 cL bottle. Pours deeply amber with creamy light brown head. Smell is dry and liquorice with spice elements. Taste is very dry with dominating liquorice notes, hops, malts, a bit of yeast and some caramel but with complete absence of sweetness. Alcohol is hidden deeply beneath. I miss the sweetness to give a perfect balance.

On draft at OBriens.  Arrived a deep, mostly clear reddish brown with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, yeasty and spicy.  Flavor is also sweet with dark fruits, hints of molasses, interesting spice notes and floral hops help to hide the apparent, but not over-powering alcohol character.  Medium body and tingly carbonation. Yummy!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2007 # 200[Tasted at Carlsens.]

My rating no. 200 exclusively to this christmasbeer.

An alcoholic brew which you truely can taste, but its not too much. Notes of licorice especially danish PIRATOS. But also caramel, hoppiness and more complex maltnotes. Ill look forward to taste some in a year or two, which Ive cellared in my secret room.

Biggish offwhite head over dark red body. Deep, sharpish banana aroma with notes of licorice and spice, and, very faintly, traces of alcohol. Taste is again a deep, sharpish, harmonic mix of banana and licorice with bread, yeast, and peppery spice notes. Very complex. Smooth mouthfeel. Dry, peppery licorice aftertaste with yeast notes. Quite a bit of alcohol heat. (0.33l bottle.)
There are many Belgian beers I liked more. This one is too alcoholic and perfumy, slightly too sweet and somewhat unbalanced. Aroma and flavor are dominated by pear brandy.

On tap @ Hamiltons.  Heavy and strong adequately sums up this fine ale.  Not one of those youre going to have more than 1 glass of in an evening.  A sweet, thick and heavy sipper.  I had to use an Orval to wash this down.  So, as you can tell, I was having a good night.

(Bottle BB 03/08/09) Alcoholic, anise and licorice aroma. Red brown colour, clear and small, light brown, more or less fully diminishing head with fair lacing. Sweet, anise, licorice, malty and slightly acidic (initial) flavour. Alcoholic, astringent, lively carbonated and medium to full-bodied palate. Good brew but slightly too alcoholic! 18/11/06

Dark mahogoney and slightly cloudy with perfect head. Aroma of sweet dark fruit with some spices. Very tasty sweet caramel and dark fruit taste...Alcohol is sharp, but not out of control. Definitely enjoyed...but man, this would be fan freaking tastic after a few years of aging.

What a great beer, this is what a Belgian should taste like. Its pour is long and smooth. Its malts is whole and frothy. The many taste of fruits, caramel. toffee and mild mint makes this a winner among beer drinkers.

I was really impressed with this one. I should have had this one for my 1000th. The aroma is complex with toasted malt, brown sugar, spice, dark fruit, bubble gum, and yeast. The appearance is amber brown with a nice foamy head. The flavor is like the aroma with a toasty, caramel emphasis. The palate is smooth with a nice warm toasty finish which is one of the best I have had. I really like this beer.
Full flavored but wonderfully elegant, this does not taste like its 10.5%.  Beautiful Gouden Carolus fruity aromatics with nice caramel in the mouth finishes with full but clean malts.  Very nice.

mohogany pour with rising bubbles and frothy tan head.  beautiful aroma of bananna, plum, raison, brown sugar, nutmeg and bubble gum.  lively palate.  10% alcohol.  This is fucking great.  slight burn which is welcoming.  dark fruits are sweet and the malts are thick and sticky.  sugar dances on your tounge and melts like a maple sugar candy.  Best Christmas brew that Ive had to date.
On tap @ Coles. Buffalo, NY. Dark amber in color with long lasting full head. Flavor is all over the place with fruits & spices. alcohol is present but not overbearing.
once again, dark and clear. less dark. great elegant head. smells like bubble gum.  smells like break. alcohol does not hide in flavor. reminds me of an eisbock or dopple.  so malty.

Dark amber, this looks as potent as it sounds. Aroma is almost aggressive with fruit and spice... aniseed? Extraordinary. Flavor follows along the same tracks; plum, herbs, liquorice. No taste of alcohol, but you can really feel the 10.5%. Yeasty finish with a nice warm glow. Excellent, but while tasting this with a group of friends, there were some opposite opinions, not the easiest brew around.

Wonderful dark mahogany with clear red colour when seen through. Great big beige creamy headStunning aroma. Fruit, yeast, cloves, plums, alcohol, some cinnamon, some ginger. Taste is equally complex. Good full mouthfeel and slightly vinious. Plums, sweet, raisins, coriander, some vanilla - stunning.
had a taste on tap at muddy pig.  Dark ruby/amber with thin head.  Basic belgian yeasty smeall, but with a great sweet fruit candy.  Very good.
On tap. Nice sweet candy and Belgian aroma. Nice sweetness, pleasant to drink.
Aroma is sweet with some belgian yeast.Pours dark copper with very little head.Flavors of sweet malt and alcohol.Lots of carbonation with an alcohol finish.

Bottle: Red pour with an off white head. Aroma, spice, yeast, caramel malts, and some cinnamon. Flavor, spicy, brown sugar, more sweet than anything. There are some fruits in there as well. Good stuff.

Bottle: Pours dark amber with a large beige head. Nice lacings. Nose dominated by burned malt, caramel and anis. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, dark fruits, licorice, coffee and brown sugar. Full bodied. Molasses texture. Sweet and alcoholic finish.

Very dark copper with a thick cloudy light brown head. Aroma of alcohol, warm malt, brown sugar and light Belgian yeast. Sweet flavour almost like a brown sugar liqueur. Alcohol is very present but not overpowering. Flavour is like a marshmallow candy with a trace of Cinnamon.

330ml bottle from Vinmonopolet (Harstad). Nice beige-yellow foam over a hazy, dark orange body. Candy sweet smell dominated by anise. There is also good amounts of anise in flavour. Hints of sweet, ripe citrus fruits remain in the background. A bit port-like impression. Aftertaste of yeast and warming alcohol. Almost full mouthfeel, but gets a bit too sweet and carbonated (13.12.2006).

Cyrup like aroma with hints of complex set of flavours, malts and hints of cinnamon. 

Nice reddish brown colour, nice small bubble foam cap that vanishes quite shortly. 

Flavour is sweet smooth full tasting malty with hints of rosted barley and chocolate. Even with overpouring sweetness there are some bitterness (like from juniper) from hops in after taste (but not enough for me to balance the sweet taste).

Palate is little viscose and the mouth is covered with strong after taste of malty sweetness and some edge of hops.

Overall quite nice stron beer for christmas season. Two 0.75 bottles would be too much but one with traditional Finnish christmas roast ham would do fine.
Full-bodied ale with incedible complexity of tastes. Very fruity aroma loaded with banana notes. Smooth like velvet, very tasty, but not overdone.
Sub par. Poured dark with a nice head. Aroma was sweet and earthy. Flavor very earthy, musty, and dry, not great.
Very rich. Deep flavor. Not spicy like other Christmas beers. But strong malt flavors and high quality Gouden Carolus style.

this was actually kind of good.  Heres the deal:  all of these belgian breweries have a christmas beer which is only different in the fact that it is hoppier.  they are like that.  i remember the good one from this brewery actually beeing good and this being similar, less so, but more hoppy. screw you, i dont have to justify myself to you.

Shared at Coastal Wine Connections monthly tasting.  Whiskey-colored.  Big sugary aroma that almost scared me off.  And while that explosive alcoholy-ness floats onto the palate before you actually drink, the actual flavors are surprisingly smooth and evenly malty.  Outstanding.

This was beautiful, just a stunner! Poured a reddish brown with a full head. Featured a big phenolic bubble gum nose with hints of caramel floating about. The flavor was quite similar, not dominated by bubblegum, but punctuated with it, as it was all cut by a lively carbonation and tingle of alcohol. There was also a hint at fruitiness, perhaps apricot and rum raisin. Finished easy. Semi-sweet.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2008 poured from a 750ml bottle in to a westmalle then hoegaarden grand cru glss. It survived better in the tulip, with a a dark tan head, A strong scent of sweet herb and alcohol. A strong alcoholic presence on the tongue with a lingering spice taste on the end. Enjoyable

330 ml bottle. Dark brown colour. Slightly hazy from yeast residue. Strong banana and alcohol aroma. The aroma is very strong and distinct almost so that youd think that they had fermented this thing way too hot. Anyway, the nose is complex from malts and caramel, but those all cannot quite compete with the banana. Warm sensations when the beer enters the mouth. Rich maltiness and clearly high in alcohol. Just a little raisins and nuts. Little detectable hop bitterness, but there is a little hops, but just so that it balances out some of the sweetness.

On tap at the maproom.  Served up dark brown with a creamy head that clung to the glass.  Ruby red against the light.  Fairly sweet aroma somewhat subdued by the smoky atmosphere.  I tasteed a lot of anise in this bad boy.  I dont normally like anise but it was not too unnerving here wehere it balanced well with the strong sweet body and slightly bitter finish.  Smooth and rich, with only a little alcohol preseence.  Solid.
Pours deep amber into a trappist glass.  Tan micro head quickly subsides with no lacing.  Strong alcohol and spice aromas.  Sticky rum caramel with lasting alcohol burn.  Festive.

Poured a nice dark copper color with hints of ruby and a thin white head.  Aroma of cinnamon, coriander, and a hint of pit fruit.  Palate is exceptional.  Silky, but not thick.  Taste has a sweet start and smooth finish.  The Belgian yeast notes and spices complement each other nicely.  This brewery doesnt get talked about as much as some others, but they put out some great brews.

Bottle. Dark amber color with a slight haze. Nice tan head. A wide range of pleasant aromas; Dried dark fruits, cream-caramel, dark rum, red berries, spices... Taste is rich and complex as well, sweetish  malts dominates with lots of fruits and spices and warming alcohol with a vineous (port) touch. Full body. An excellent Christmas seasonal.

A great seasonal brew.  Lots of things going on.  Has sort of slight taste of bubble gum and spice.  Ive been told to lay one of these down for a year as they only develop and get better. We will see!

Medium, fluffy head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of alcohol, sweet fruit.  Clear with an amber hue.  Average carbonation, medium body.  Taste yeast, fruit, sweetness, alcohol.  Finishes smooth and sweet which is very impressive for such a high alcohol content ale.  Good stuff!

750 ml bottle. Pours to a murky, garnet color, with a thick, creamy, off white head, and a lively carbonation. The nose is very inviting, with lots of big aromas of toffee, sweet malt, fruity esters of apple, and peppery alcohol. The palate is firm with good toffee and caramel malt flavor, paired with a really delicious, estery/apple flavor, and hints of spicy yeast. This beer finishes with more good toffee and apple notes up front, then ends with some soothing, alcohol warmth that lingers. Really a delcious beer, packed with big aromas and flavors. Very drinkable for a 10% abv beer. A great Christmas brew to sip and savor by a roaring fire. The fruity esters in this one almost give it a hard cider character to it, and with the malt character, this beer tastes like an alcoholic  caramel apple. I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle. High and lasting off-white head. Hazy red brown body. Aroma dominated by anis and other spices that I cannot figure out. Licorice flavour with a touch of lemon and again spices I cannot recognise. The high alcohol percentage is well hidden. Long aftertaste of licorice. Of course the result is still quite sweet, nevertheless well done.
On tap at the Duck Saloon.  Aroma was hoppy with lots of yeasty spice undertones.  Has lots of plum and sugar flavour thoughout with nice balance and flavour thorughout.  Very complex and tasty.

Bottle, 2006 (the one rated). Aroma is sweet with caramel, yeast and a little banana. Flavour is alcohol, sweetness and caramel.
2003: Raisins, ripe fruit, caramel and prunes. Delicious aroma. Flavour is sweet with raisins though quite light if palate. 9-4-6-3-15

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark bronze with a large light tan head. Aroma of black licorice, spices galore, fruit, and citrus. The flavor is smooth, loads of amazing spices, licorice, citrus, moderate carbonation, and fruit. Excellent brew.
750 ml bottle. Dark amber colourw ith a mostly diminishing fizzy and frothy off-white head. Licorice, light toffee aroma. Yeasty and toffee flavours with some light anise. Medium body, effervescent.

From draft.  Golden brown, semi-transparent colored pour with a thin finger of creamy beige head.  An aroma of medicinal spiced cherries, a touch of bourbon, and a hit of anise blend in a bit of a boozy fashion.  Light bodied, full flavored mouthfeel.  Caramels and prunes create a richly malty body, but this is seasoned with a menthol spice that leaves a medicinal taste lingering on my taste buds.  Too hot on the finish as well.

Bottled(330ml). -So far the best Christmas beer that Ive had. Dark brown coloured, medium sized pale brown head, spicey port like nose. Aroma is nice malty and fruity with great spicy notes and touch of yeast and coriander. Lingering alcohol in the finish.

0,75l bottle. The looks are dark brown with a small off-white head which never quite disappear. Aroma of cognac, cherry and... something I couldnt quite place. Intense flavours of wine, plums and liqurice.
Bottle. Dark brown color with a medium sized tan head. Very complex and sweet.  Malts, candie sugar, liqourice, caramel and various spices.
Bottle at Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Huge brew, immense in flavour and aroma. Sweet and intense. This is really good, wish it was available in Sweden
Burned sugar, candy, warming full malt. Smooth, bitterness in the finish. The alcohol strength is evident, and almost masks a fine flavour of dried fruit.

0.33l bottle (for Mexican market (!!)) at the Hopdevil in Zagreb Scant traces of a tan head on a beautiful dark red body. Lovely nose; spicey, berries, malt, orange peel, a touch of alcohol. The taste is very nice too. A tad earthy. Grapes, caramel, a faint touch of bubblegum, hints of mint, apricot flavoured candy. Yum. Faint malty/bitterish aftertaste. Damn smooth and a great beer.
Bottled. Very dark brown coloured with a medium sized tan head. Very complex and sweet. Malts, candied sugar, liqourice, caramel and various spices.
A great beer. It had cinammon aftertones. Medium, cloudy body. Very unique and sweet.
no. 52. And the second real disappointment of the party for me. The aroma was very gross, like sour milk.  An untasty, icky beer.
on tap at Concordia Ale House in Portland, OR. very nice palate, sweet, tasty.
Draught at "Den Tatoverede Enke" Clear dark red/brown - white head. A lot of licorice, high hopped, red berries, sharp hoppy, very nice.

På fad 2006, Den tatoverede enke.
Klar mahognifarve med lyst skum. Dufter af kirsebær, heksehyl og lidt skolekridt men også julekrydderier.
Smager af de samme ting. Er dejlig og ikke så tung som frygtet.
bottle. dark amber color. very dark aroma. xmasy and very sweet. big and heavy mouthfeel. good quallity.
Vintage 2003. Pours a clear brown with a dissappearing head. Very sweet and portish. Strong notes of nuts. Full bodied with a sticky mouthfeel. Long sweet finish.
Bottle. Chestnuy, golden brown head. Vineous, wooden nose. Herbal, heather notes. Burned sugar sweetness. Medium body, mellow mouthfeel. Nice spicy brew.

loudy orange with tan fluffy head. Aroma of figs, dates, raisins, cotton candy, and just general sweetness. Flavor was very sweetly malted with notes of dark fruits, raisins and plums...a very nice Christmas beer.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 Draught from Paradise Beer Weekend. Smashing Christmas beer from one of my favourite breweries. Ive enjoyed it on many, many occasions (and currently possess an obscene collection of 75cl bottles), but this is my first taste off draft. Beer notes are nearly illegible, but will update from the bottle sometime soon. Dark, clear amber in colour with glorious creamy head.
