Aroma and taste of liquorice, dried fruits, heavy spice, rum, and all things that remind you of the festive season. Velvet texture - absolute luxury for the tongue. Smooth, loooooong finish. Just Mmmmmm. Words do no justice. The King of Christmas!!!

A spicy dark winter brew with a bitter finish available in bottles and also (if youre really lucky) on draught, I think it was better on draught but it might just have been the company I was keeping!!

Transparent dark amber with only a ring of bubbles. Leaves great lacing though. Tons of spice up front, almost minty, couldnt really pinpoint. Flavor again is dominated by spice, mostly mint and licorice, but not in a bad way. Nice malt backbone, shows through fron time to time. Looking at my notes curious as to why I gave this a 4.1, so se a re-rate coming if only for a better review.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2006 Dark ruby, big, creamy off-white head.  Intense aroma of spices and licorice - or is it just a whole lot of anise? I dont know why I havent rated it during the winter, but stored through the summer (and quite some heat - but tonight was a worthy occasion). By now, its a bit one dimensional in all its anise glory. 
Fresh rating: Yes, its supposed to have that much anise...
Bottle. Amber colour with a huge creamy fully lasting head. Rich aroma of malts, fruits and spices. alocohoic finish.

Bottle. BB nov. 2006.
Creamy lightbrown excellent mostly lasting head. Dark amber colour. Week malty aroma. Nice spicey flavor but way too alcoholic. Average finish and oily palate.

Dark brown colour, nice smooth beige head. Caramel, toffee, raisins, spices in the malty aroma. Outspoken spicy initial flavour, malty. Malty finish but with some light hoppy notes. Some cherry. Medium to heavy bodied.

Poured a caramel-brown color with a nice respectable smooth head that thinned but maintained coverage. Lacing was weak. The aroma was of caramel and spices. Some sort of bourbon or whiskey in there. I was ready for a flavor that was underdeveloped, but this one actually was quite smooth, as the alcohol and spices didnt overwhelm. Caramel was for sure the feature flavor, almost like caramel candy. The mouthfeel was moderate for the style.

Bright  garnet color with active carbonation.  Big thick off-white head.  Aroma of cherries and spice.  Sweet and thick mouthfeel with flavors of cherries, prunes, maple, chocolate, and some alcohol.  Aftertaste is roasted malt, alcohol warmth, and some yeasty notes.  Im enjoying this in June since it was part of a 1/2 off sale on winter seasonals.  Glad I waited, its delicious even in warm weather!

Courtesy of MrWalker. 2005 Bottle
<!-- P -->
Rich sweet malt and dark fruits flood the nose. There is a musky perfumey flourish as well. Body is a murky brown and holds two fingers of mocha thickness in the creamy, but bubbly, head. Fore is somewhat toasty with malts and there are mild sweet fruit flavors. Alcohol is fairly hot and assertive through the middle and the finish is midly bitter and almost tart and acidic. Some very mild spiciness as well. Overall a good beer, but doesnt tie things together nearly as well as the Carolus Classic.

Nice opening pop from the corked bottle.  Pours dark amber wtiha small off-white head that end up in little patches.  Aroma has caramel malt, earthy yeast, toffee, dark fruits (raisins, prunes) and bits of alcohol.  Medium to full bodied with soft frothy carbonation.  Taste has earthiness and caramel first, then comes anise, spiciness and peppery flavors.  Spiciness and sourness linger around on the finish.  However, the sourness mellows down further down the glass.  Also as it warms dark fruits and earthiness join in on the finish.  There is beautiful lacing  on this beer.  At the end some sharp citrus seems to sneak in.  Overall a very nice winter beer that is also enjoyable in spring.

Bottle-Shared with a friend, poured a deep, deep brown with a small brown head that didnt stick around.  The aroma was nutmeg and cinnamon with an undercoating of berries.  The taste followed along with the aroma.  A nice little kick of hops finished off the drink.

No date. Dark ruby brown with large, spongey, tan head. Nose of toasty caramel malt, licorice, peppery yeast, dark fruits, mint. Same flavors with some tequila, herbs, alcohol, and chocolate. A touch of absinthe in the finish. Dry, roasty, bittersweet, yeasty,  alcoholic aftertaste. Can I say complex? Full, balanced body. Definitely a brew to savor slowly. Excellent.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2010 75 cl bottle.  BBE 10/11/08.  A dark brown coloured beer which pours with tan bubbles but these dont stick around long enough to be described as a head.  The aroma is sticky plums and port like vinuous.  some aniseed and some licquorice thrown in for good measure.  A really big, welcoming aroma.  The taste is big and fruity.  Some more spices including a dash of cinnamon combine with the alcohol to produce a big Christmas warmer.  The depth of flavours are maybe not as brash and as complex as Id have liked, nor the body as big, but its still a good bevvy.  Score 3.9Subsequent rating scored 4.2. Average becomes 4.0

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2006 Orange-rød ufilreret belgisk øl købt i sverige.

Øllens er en typisk belgisk klosterøl tilsat alle julens kryderier.

Duften er meget krydret - mest tydelig er appelsin.

Skummet er let brunt med store bobler.

Smagen er varm, stærk og krydret. Øllen er ikke så tung - men stærk.

Efter et år aftager kryderismagen en del, og øllen er aldeles rund.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2006 One of the best kerst beers I have ever tasted. This one deserves all the hype!
 Brown with creamy white head. Very filling and has a complex variation of the regular christmas spices. Long lasting finish!

Bottle.  Coriander strong sweet nut bread flavor.   Beautiful full heady head on garnet brown body.  Detecting brown sugar syrup.  Lacking any real holiday character and not really that unique, but very drinkable and pleasant stuff.

Large beige creamy full lasting head. Mahogany color. Aroma is fruity with raisins, dark fruits, banana, vanilla and light spicy notes. Flavor is fruity with banana, candy, raisins and chocolate tones, ending in a long sweet finish. Full bodied.

750ml (no idea what year) i would love to know because it seems like it has been perfected. pours nice head. the fruitiness goes well with the right amount of spice. A treasure of a find. a delicious beer

33cl bottle from Dorstvlegel, Antwerp.  I bought 3 Christmas beers from Belgium and this was my favourite.  Dark brown/red with thin beige head.  Dark malts and spice.  Lots of spice in mouth.  Lots of dry malt.  Quite chewy in mouth.  Its like liquid Soreen malt loaf, complete with raisins.  Full, nice, got good most things about it.

Pours dark brown w/ medium head. Full nectar w/ a sweet cherry smack on the nose. Its a cherry bomb and it tastes like sweet cherry caughdrops. Leaves no room for anything else. Drink it cold as a dessert. Alcohol is well hidden. Jeeeez, I can still taste it. I keep hearing Warrant singing their famous song, "shes my  cherry pie....sweet cherry pie.."

On Tap at the Borough Arms, Crewe 20/05/2005
Mid to dark brown with spice and liquorice aromas. Some dryness and bitterness in a warming malt finish.

"Poured a nice brown color with okay head. Aroma was of carmel and spices, brown sugar. Flavor was spices dark fruits and carmel, not near as sweet as the aroma, still a little too sweet for me. Overall good beer"

On tap at the White Horse, Parsons Green. Tried this alongside Abbaye des Rocs Noel and was rather surprised to find I preferred the Gouden Carolus. Reddish copper colour. Packed with jammy fruit on the nose. Lots of berry fruit on the palate and plenty of rich, deep malt. Sweetish, but theres an acidity that balances that. Very smooth, silky mouthfeel. Rather fuller and more voluptuous than the AdR to my palate, but it avoids being too rich. Very impressed.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2017 Hazy reddish brown, moderate sized tan head that lasts. Aroma of berry, spice, caramel, chocolate, yeast, brown sugar, spice. Medium to full body, alcohol hidden well, very drinkable. The writeup changed, the score didnt - this is nice.

Bottle. Has a mahagony color and pours with a foamy tan head. The aroma is bubblegum with caramel malt. Sweet and creamy caramel and roasted malt that makes a smooth and creamy beer. Llightly spice with a maple or brown sugar.

1 pint, 9.4 fl oz.  Pours mahagony with a frothy tan medium-sized head and lined lacing, good head retention.  Yeast (dough, bubblegum) and medium roasted malt (caramel, nutty) with faint perfumey hops and alcohol notes.  Warm, spicy medium sweetness and medium acidity, medium to light bitterness, sugary, caramel, maple, bubblegum, port and alcohol.  Full, warm bodied, medium fizzy, medium dry palate.

(Bottled) Mahogany/dark amber in colour. Huge foamy head. Big, potent nose with caramel, dried fruit, liquorice and herbs (sweet cicely, rosemary, thyme?).  Full, fiery flavor, with dried fruit (prunes), more herbs (caraway, aniseed?) and a well balanced hint of yeast. Sweet but not sticky. Complex stuff and a magnificent beer.

The aroma is straight root beer.  This has a deep black color until you hold it up to a light, and then a very deep ruby.  The flavor is plum, faint citrus, very complex, with a hidden hint of banana.  Its fizzy, olive oil, like hard liquor.  And it left a tingly freshness in the mouth.

Mahogany with red highlights and a large but quick tan head. Aromas are warm & coat the nostrils but are difficult to decipher. Fruity pine & fusels, some banana and brandy. High carbonation contributes to a fluffy mouthfeel carrying malts, spice and ginger. This is a complex and very celebratory beer, one that is perfect for the holidays.


<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL 60452<font size=-1>

750, left by somebody at my nye party.  aroma is tart and malty fruit, some coffee?  dark reddish brown, low carbonation.  heavy body, and flavor mirrors the aroma: tart, with tons of malt, and a good bit of acidity.  hides the 10.5 quite well, but drinkability suffers at the hands of the body and acidity.
cloudy dark amber w/ a brown head.  sweet fruity aroma w/ hint of some spice, the flavor is dominated by alcohol and fruits.  full bodied and warm.

Bottle.  Blackish beer with a red hue, the head is smooth and quite whispy.  The aroma is sweet, spiced and mulled fruit in nature.  The flavour is strong, liquor like with a load of spice, sweetness and appley fruits.  Overall a pretty good comforting beer.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2006 Had this at BJs Winter Ale Fest, 2005. Originally rated 8/01, 3/5, 7/10, 3/5, 15/20. Rerate: Beer is lightly hazy, dark-amber color with a small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma is malty, spicybut extraordinarily and obstrucively peppery. Malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, caramel and a trace of molasses; Hoppy with a moderate note of oregano-like herb, resin/pine; Yeasty with a light notes of banyard, dough, attic and basement; Miscellaneous notes include light alcohol, heavy, dusty white pepper. Alcohol is well hidden in the nose.

The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter with a warm, long, moderately bittersweet finish.

The body is full, the texture is velvety, the carbonation is lively, moderate warmth.

12.31.05  750ml bottle.  Dark caramel color, looks like flat cola, with a medium sized, fairly lasting white head.  Aroma is banana and bubblegum with a spicy and bready yeast (banana bread) and some hints of band-aid.  Almond and vanilla fill in a spotty scent of chocoalte chips and dried apple.  Unique flavors, it reminds of many dubbels Ive tried but less yeasty.  Body is lithe and ful of coating eff.  Pleasantly sweet, not overly so, and a very light finishing snap of eff, alcohol, and spice.  Licorice hints saturate throughout.  Very nice stuff.

Deep red-brown body, thin/medium beige head.  Flowery, perfumey aroma, spciy, with hints of yarrow, toast, and banana.  Peppery, licoricey body, with perfumey yarrow, toast, and a tight bitter finish to go along with hints of chocolate and other candies.  The spicy, flowery, peppery yeast flavors remind me a bit of something Brasserie des Rocs would brew.  Good but a bit heavy on the spices for me.

Pours dark brown, with a tan head. Aromas of sweet malt, spices, dark fruit, yeast. Flavors are spices, sweet malt, dark fruit, brown sugar, and toffee.
Body is rather thick and heavy. This one should age well.

This is another of my 2005 Christmas Beers.   What a nice surprise.  The head formation was modest and the color was deep amber or brown.  There was excellent lacing down the glass.  Upon uncorking this bottle there was an immediate release of yeast and malt aroma.  The body is medium with some sweetness.  There are hints of other spices and hops.  The high alochol is hidden very well.  This has been of the best Belgium ales that I have enjoyed.
A brown-black appearance. A sweet and fruity aroma. The taste is sweet, fruity and a bit malty. Not my kind of beer.(Bottle 75cl, tap)

750ml - Aroma is sharp bubblegum, cherry, red licorice, yeast, and spice.  Pours a reddish-brown with small head and good lacing.  Flavor is cherry, bubblegum, yeast, spice, and cinnamon.  Palate is tart and sticky.  Different and interesting.
Pours out a dark brown amber color with a nice big tan head.  Beautiful sweet aroma.  Flavor is reminiscent of dark fruit and licorice or absinthe.  One of the best Christmas beers Ive had.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, tupalev & jerc -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Last beer of the night at our last tasting. Pours a murky reddish-brown with an average size fizzy tan head. Big sweet aroma of sugar, spices, fruit, yeast, caramel malt and more -- quite complex. Flavour is sweet and spicey with a big alcohol kick, some dark fruit, nuts and a nice bitterness. So much going on in the flavour. Mouthfeel  is thick and syrupy. A perfect Christmas beer to end a great Christmas tasting with great friends. Bring on 2006!

Bottle, at No. 5 (031202).
Dark brown with beige head. Aroma heavy malty (dark fruits) and moderate hoppy. Flavor have sweet and moderate bitter. Full bodied Christmas brew.

Rich creamy and lacing foam tops this dark ruby red beer Liquorice, yeast and caramel aroma. Lots of liquorice flavour, some citrus, warming alcohol, almost like a liqueur. Sweet, yet with balancing bitterness. Soft, but well-carbonated with a full body. a very intense beer with lots of character.

bottle. brown-mahogany with a small ring of off-white head. the aroma consists of sweet dark fruit, dark bittersweet chocolate, yeast, and cheese. a very big full body with flavours of bready malt, chocolate, yeast, and fruit. another good one.
Bottle 75cl. Superb aroma and apperance. Flavour follows the aroma with a full body. I will try to get some more of these and store them to the next season.

Bottle cellared 2 years: Pours brown with a generous tan head.  Complex tarte fruity aromas eventually give way to banana and coriander elements.  Taste is initially nutty with some nice chocolate and fig notes.  Hints of peaches and cherries in the background.  Oily mouthfeel and a sweet nutty finish.

750ml Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a light off white head. Nose is dark fruits, candies and sugar, lightly malty. Taste is very sweet and candy like. Some fruits, malty caramel sweetness, and a nice thick finish that stays on the palate.

Brown with a full head upon pouring.The first flavour that hits you is liquorice aqnd this stops throughout the drinking time.Lovely full bodied with as you would expect plenty of alcohol presence.This makes Christmas worth waitiing for.

Dark amber-red colour. Some acid aroma and flavor. Malty and fruity taste.
It´s wious and to much pepper.

het ankers holiday brew might be the nearest thing to liquid fruitcake ive yet beheld. no, not that cheap, sucky fruitcake composed of artificially colored, rubbery psuedo-fruit blobs embedded in discusting gummy nogahide cake thats pressed into molds like particleboard and has a dangerous half-life longer than strontium. no, i mean real home-made fruit cake blended judiciously with chunks of dried cherries, pineapple and plum, praline and orange peel with pulsing arteries of honey and rose water-- and finally dosed with enough brandy to render it incendiary within fifty feet of the fireplace. this is lovely and potent stuff. the cork pops like a starting gun on your race toward insousiant inebriation. like a brazilian beauty queen the caramel malts are brown and flushed with ruby highlights -- and even on a winter night, this gal is nude with amber clarity under that frothy woolen blanket of foam. the lace made lingering snow flake filigrees on the snifter--arabesques that defied gravity and traded electrons with the surface of the glass in a bid for archival permanence. this tenacity is owing to the huge amounts of sugar demanded by this recipe. when the sugar export market responded to the needs of just this beer, we can reasonably imagine fidel castro gleefully pumping his jubilant fists like a winning boxer. so share it with a loved one; this is a liqueur, a dessert-- and strong-- your designated driver shouldnt be allowed to even sniff this...
Bottle shared with some fellows at work.  Amber color, foamy head. Nose was candy and spice, caramel. Taste was like the smell, with some wondeful warming from the high abv. Great x-mas brew.

Beautiful pour with solid head and a nice lace pattern.  Wide variety of spicy undertones in this Belgian.  Smooth, none of the alcohol burn one often finds in high content brews.  I like it, but for the price expected it to be a bit more special.  Got bonus points for my wife picking it up as a surprise for me.

Amber color, nice and lasting head. Aroma is fruity, some dried fruits, milky and with some spices. Some raisins and figs. Flavor from sweet fruits, malty, strong with some alcohol. Malty, some brown sugar, peach and banana. A bit nutty and vinous. Malty finish with some strong notes

750ml bottle, 2004 vintage. 10% abv.  Fruity, sugary aroma, malty, spicy, complex and rich with hints of red grape, dried orange peel, black cherry, milky chocolate, toffee, faint leafy herbs, flowery perfume and doughy yeast.  Hazy rusty red-brown color with a fully lasting ivory head and spectacular lacing.  Flavor profile is predominantly malty, dark and sweet but featuring plenty of subtlety as well, with suggestions of mint, cookie, raisin, banana, licorice and pepper in the background and with an extremely lengthy, fruity, spicy and satisfying finish that shows only the merest hint of the stated alcohol content.  Creamy and very smooth on the palate, body is quite full.  Decadent and highly enjoyable.  A fine choice for this time of year.

Pours a clear brown color with a thin light brown head. Excellent aroma of malt, spices and yeast. Excellent flavor of malt, spices and yeast. Light to medium body with a dusty mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Excellent Christmas treat.

Sampled at a 2005 Christmas and Winter beer tasting at Delilahs, Chicago, IL. 2004 vintage. ale having a small white diminishing head. No discernable carbonation.  Sweet fruity bubblegum aroma.  Medium bodied that starts with light sweet malt and notable bubblegum (tuttifruitti?) flavor. Finishes with light malt aftertaste. A decent drinkable beer but some may find the sweet synthetic chewing gum flavor somewhat overwhelming.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, tupalev & jerc - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Dark, hazy mahogany with a small mocha head. Big aroma that is sweet, spicey, herbal - really nice. Flavour is quite sweet as well, with notes of cherry, pineapple, spice (cinnamon, clove), dark malt, brown sugar. A great winter warmer, and the perfect way to end a long night of tasting great beers with great friends.

Big frothy head covering a dark brown liquid. "Belgian" smell. I know its is like swearing in church in a forum like this to say that belgian beer taste stale - but it does. This xmas variety however has a spicy sweetness that makes me forgive all the others. Not a favorite, but OK.
Robe brune surmontée dune mousse blanche qui sestompe. Arômes de caramel, de malt et dépices. Saveurs de malt caramélisé, de levure et dépices.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry, GregClow, Jerc, and blankboy, courtesy of Harry.  Last bottle of a solid tasting.  Dark brown, huge bubbly thick tan head.  Big strong aroma - floral, sweetness, bubblegum, candy, and root beer - incredible.  Medium mouthfeel.  Taste is good - sweet candy giving way to alcohol. Bubblegum, yeast, and hops at the end.  Spicy as well.  A special occasion beer for sure.  Excellent.  A perfect beer to end our Christmas tasting with a great bunch of guys - thanks for the fantastic 2005 tastings lads.

Bottle. Hazy dark brown body with a small creamy khaki head. Huge fruity aroma with moderate spices - nutmeg? cinnamon? Reminds me of egg nog for some reason. Fairly complex aroma. Sweet malt and some sugars in the flavour, with a subtle malt complexity and more spice similar to those in the aroma. Creamy medium palate. Very nice, and a perfect Christmasy end to the evening. Almost worth waiting an hour for the bus for!

"...theres going to be like vikings and sh*t in there!" - Blankboy

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2005 Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc, tupalev - courtesy of yours truly.  Poured murky ruby-brown with a huge light brown creamy-foamy lasting head, beautiful lacing.  Aroma of hard candy, vanilla, caramel and brown sugar, yeast, mild spices (nutmeg, cinnamon), gets darker and richer as it warms - oh yeah, this says "Christmas" to me.  Taste follows the nose, but man, theres the 10.5% alcohol - lovely, warming, spicy - a comfort beer that could make you wake up under a bridge with a huge smile on your face.  Mouthfeel thick, syrupy, long lingering ....  terrific seasonal strong beer, Im proud to have had it and shared it.

750 ml bottle 2004 vintage poured a cloudy reddish brown with a large, long lasting tan head. Aromas of raisins, plums and some spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark fruit, spices, carmel and molasses with a sweet, warming finish.
Just too overpoweringly medicinal...with VERY strong licorice and alcohol.  Just couldnt get past the anice assault on my senses...although the alcohol assault pulled me through to save the day.
Bottle, Dark ruby. Aroma of... everything? Notes of solvent and banana. Sweet taste, sweet finish, mmm

Has a bit of dry, chalky dustiness that conveys the spiciness, kind of nutmeggy, I guess. Sweet but not overly so, nicely malted with hints of biscuit and caramel, this is a very easy drinker for 10.5% (although my bottle said more - 11.5%)...Good Christmas beer for sure. Thanks for the bottle, Andre.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: This ale is what the adjective "medicinal" was created for.  Ultimately I liked the beer, a lot, but the intial hit of the aroma, a strong licorice and alcohol base blended with spices, reminded me of some of the cough drops that I had as a kid.  But it grows on you.  Brown with red highlights, it sports a solid tan head.  The flavor is built on a rich, dark caramel malt laden with anise and containing elements of black cherries, spices, and alcohol.  Theres a light sweetness to the medicinal, alcohol filled finish.  Both interesting and warming to drink.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve & Winter Beer Tasting at Delilahs, Chicago, IL 12/10/2005<font size=-1>

Very dark ruby body that is almost brown. The head is a very light khaki color and sticks around. The aroma is alcoholic with some cherry cough syrup, cinnamon and herbal tea. The taste is maraschino cherries with some light cinnamon spice. There is also some herbal tea and a warming alcohol finish. This has a thin and slick mouthfeel for such a big beer. Well made and lends itself to sipping and enjoying. However, it is a bit medicinal.

Another awesome beer from DragonStout. Bottle shared at the First Annual Florida Ratebeer Gathering. 

These ratings were taken from one day of about 60 different tastings all were good and all have blended together but I know I thoroughly enjoyed every one of them and none were bad.

Dark brown colour, diminishing off white head. Heavy aroma, fruity, banana, sweet caramel, little bit roasted. Taste is sweet and fruity, fizzy carbonation. Finish is sweet, but not to much, with some alcohol taste.

Bottled.  Deep brown hue with a short-lived beige/caramel head.  Heavy, roasty plums, figs, alcohol, caramel, Christmas-like spices, and a great musty Belgian yeast presence grace the nose.  Absolutely wonderful malty flavor profile... loads of dark fruit including vinous notes, a little port, cloves, cherries, more holiday spices, and musty yeast rounding it out.  Exceptionally smooth across the palate... flavors just dance.  Finish is long, fruity, spicy, and warming.  Excellent fireside sipper.
Dark redish brown colour. Rich head.  Liquorice aroma. The flavour is loaded with salty liquorice with dashes of caramell and oranges. Warming alcohol on the finish.

Served on tap.  Cloudy dark amber color with a thin tan head.  Aroma had raisin, caramel, rum, cinnamon, nutmeg, apple cider and other spices.  Taste was laid back for the strength with a good rum and apple cider finish.  A solid holiday beer that I would have again.
Little head, brown in color.  Spicy aroma with some mint presence.  Very licorice taste with very little ending.

An intens dark chesnut brown coloured beer, slight hazy and with a creamy beige froth. Aroma is malty and has hints of dried raisins, grape sugar, chocolate and some roasted hints too. taste is very silky and has a full-bodied caracter. You can notice touches of milkbread, caramel, butter-toffee, some soft spices, Zanzibar cinnamon, caramel malts, dried fruits like raisins, malts, cookies and soft roasted edges of sweet bread. In the afthertaste there is a well integrated touch of hop bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2006 Tap 2003. Hazy dark amber body with a small white head. Very sharp sweet caramel and sugar aroma. Gentle caramel and spice flavor. 
Tap 2004. Hazy brown color with a thin fully diminishing head leaving light lacing around the glass. A bit of a licorice aroma and flavor.

Bottle 33 cl. BB 09.08.09Roses (first time Ive ever smelled that in a beer!), honey and oranges in aroma. Very nice and christmasy. First taste is very sweet, then the honey comes through. Upons swallow the alcohol content is quite powerful. A  bit of caramel is present in the vineous aftertaste. A bit one dimensional after the initial impressive aroma. Leaves a sweet residue on your lips. Needs another year in the cellar. Good thing I have a few more bottles :-)

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2006 First time:
Aroma: honey, nectar, sourish, wonderful hops, caramel, flowers, sweet fruit (exotic, perhaps passion), mash, vinous.
Bitter, sweet, warm, rich, yeast, sticky, yeasty.
Second time:
Smells of liquorice, aniseed, yeast, malt, rubber, ctrus, hops (bit fresh), fennel seed, cardamom.
Sweet-bitter, rough, full, rich, malty.
A really powerfull christmas-brew. Dark beer, with a fine, big head. Spicy aroma. Strong flavor, malty and spicy. A bit sharp, unharmonic.

Pours a clear lighter brown color with a small amount of whitish head that quickly dissapates.  Aroma is delicious and potent: sweet malts, plums, raisins, dates, and figs mixed with some spices but not overpoweringly so.  I like the fact that it doesnt have that yeasty orangy smell/taste that many belgians do.  Flavor is extremely sweet and malty with alcohol notes and a dry bitter finish.  Overall, Id say a decent enough belgian, though a tad too sweet.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 Bottled, 75cl champagne cork. A brown beer with a nice tan head. Sweet malty aroma with fruits and some alcohol and christmas-spices. They come back in the flavor, with cardamom and notes of banana. A little too sweet perhaps. I had the beer once again on 061229 from both crown-capped 33cl bottle and 75cl champagne-corked bottle. The smaller bottle had been lagered for two years and had a more mature aroma and flavor, whereas the fresher beer had more cellar in both aroma and flavor. My rating stands untouched as the new rating gave the same total score. (051028)

Bottle. Rich dark brown/amber with a nice beige head. Spicey aroma (Xmas spices) with a bit of plum/fig and malt. Smells like an xmas puds. Rich, fruity, spicy, malty flavor - again xmas puds though banana starts to come through to take away that association (a bit too much banana). Velvelty smooth mouthfeel. A bit of alacohol wamring comes though. Very enjoyable.

2004 Bottle: Sample at WFM. Dark brown with a thin beige head and decent lacing. Lots of sweet malts and spices in the nose. The body is pretty chewy with more sweet malt, ginger and fruit flavors. The finish is flavorful, with more spices and a nice woody character. The alcohol is kept in check very well too, making for an enjoyable brew from start to finish.

Amber color, nicve and lasting offwhite head. Aroma is fruity, some dried fruits, milky and with some spices. Soma raisins and figs. Flavor from sweet fruits, malty, strong with some alcohol. Malty, some brown sugar, peach and banana. A bit nutty and vinous. Malty finish with some strong notes.

Bottled.
2003-vintage : Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of caramel, dried fruits and spices.
Flavour of caramel, dried fruits and  butterscotsch with roasted notes : 9-4-9-4-18.
Tasted the 2005-edition afterwards :
Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of anise, dried fruits and spices.
Flavour of dried fruits, anise and spices : 8-4-8-4-16.

Bottled.
I had a tasting of 3 yeaars worth of this beer. 2003,2004, and 2005. This rating is of the 2005, which i liked best. the older beers was, well older, more mature, with a more rasin/plum like taste and aroma.  Pours a deep reddish brown, with a big tan head. Aroma is sweet fruity, with some notes of alcohol and spices. Candy sugar and caramel is present too. Taste is of candy sugar, spices, fruity, and yeast. Long warming aftertaste.

75 cl bottle. No yeast in bottom. Reddish brown colour with a fantastic nice head. Great aroma of spice, caramel, brown sugar, anis and some sweetness. Wonderful flavour of kandis, anis and some yeast overall very complex with a sweet and warm finish. This christmas beer is defently one of my favorites.

Rich Brown opague color with small tan head.  Chocolate Malt taste and smell.  Has hoppy signature very unlike the Cru or the regular Gouden Carolus.    Its a very bready yeast present and the spices tingle your tongue and the aftertaste is a slow bitterness not too overwhelming.  Its thick and full and very wellbalanced with the malt, yeast, hops and alcohol.  Available at Knightly Spirits in Orlando.

750 ml bottle, corked "champagne" style. ABV is 10.5%. Deep chestnut colour, large light tan head, nice lacing. Malty sweet and spicy aroma - aniseed, cardamom, ginger, nutmeg, cloves(?)  Notes of oak and leather too. Flavour is also dominantly malty sweet (too sweet) with caramel and spices, a certain hoppy bite too. Alcohol is evident, but not overwhelming. A fairly complex beer, but too much malty sweetness keeps me from giving it a top rating.

Poured beautiful mahogany/ruby. Looks like rosewood! Head is only one finger but very dense and long-lasting. On the nose are aromas of herbs, spices, anise, clove, fruit esters, alcohol, bready yeast and malt. The flavor is most complex -- against an earthy backdround, theres a malt smokiness blended with a berry sweetmess and a malty caramel, some treacle/brown sugar, the blend of 6 herbs and spices (I taste cardamon, ginger star anise, sweet woodruff, and caraway), and a warm complex 3-hop finish. The alcohol is not that evident. Mouthfeel is delisciously thick and chewy, slow to release carbonation, and leaves a pleasant aftertaste. This ale has it all earthy malt, fruity sweetness and tartness, some herbs and spice, and a nice hop finish.

This dark brown ale poured with a modest tan head, eliciting a strong malty aroma. There was a flavor of caramel candy with a slightly bitter chalky finish and a noticeable carbonated mouthfeel. There was also a warming alcohol sensation after a few sips. This is a very satisfying drink.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2006 NOt my type of beer, but it is really good. But the alcohol is strong with the aroma. After almost all the bottle, I started to get upset at this beer, I think it was too much.

Thanks for sharing KP! Pours a hazy tobacco brown color, no head. Aroma is stale plastic, salt water. Flavor is too sweet for me, syrupy in texture, brandy and caramel round out the flavor. Just not a fan.

This starts with a dark amber color under a creamy, thick, off white head.
Lacing is incomplete, but it tries hard. 
Lightly sweet, spicy and well done, but I tried the Jolly Pumpkin Firefly just previous and this was the looser of the two although it had a spicier flavor.

Pours with a cloudy cherry brown color, and fulminant tan head with different bubble strata.  The smell and taste both have lots going on.  Smells of anis, oak, coriander, orange, and some very slight sweetness.  The taste is sublely sweet with a sourness that lingers.  Very spiced, with some cardamon and absolutely no indication whatsoever of its 10% alcohol.  I had the pleasure of rating this and Gouden carolus easter side by side, and the main difference is that this is more fresh, smooth, and subtle than the easter brew.

750 ml bottle, 2003. Rich amber color with a nice head. Aromas jump out at you with black licorice and malt. Taste is strong all right with some flavors of ripe fruits, pine, caramel and an assortment of spices. Very sweet, it starts out as a sipper but as the palalte acclimates, its smooth sailing. Just too sweet to drink often.

Pours a cloudy maroonish-brown hue with a huge, dense and durable off-white head. Thick lacing prevails throughout the glass. Rich, fragrant aromas of raisin, fig, yeast, gingerbread, anise and dark caramel prevail. Taste certainly does not disappoint with a blast of overwhelmingly delicious flavors to match the aroma along with a subtle presence of cocoa and licorice. Mouthfeel is silky smooth and creamy. A real exquisite holiday treat, even on a warm May night in Florida.

muddy brown body with frothy, lazy, light tan head with lots of lacing. hazelnut, cinnamon, spicy chocolate, fresh baked bread, alcohol, light banana. delicious. like a brown without the emphasis on nuttiness, and like a weisse without the whole banana thing. awesome dessert beer.

75cl bottle, unknown age.  Pours dark with NO head...strong spicey aroma also includes a sort of sweet fruit...chocolate cherries sweet plum sauce...Big sweet alcohol...lingering burn...my lips stick to the glass when I drink...Good as a nightcap...It starts to look ruby red as I finish my glass, and I think this is something to be thought of like a big, jammy red wine...but it does seem a little lifeless to me...a beer to sit and sip, and very enjoyable by the end!

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 A Mes rate: 33cl bottle from Kris Wines.Awesome jet black appearance with a good tan head then can be added to whenever you wish by a quick swill. Wonderful nose of heavy liquorice, malt, vanilla and spice. Stunning creamy alcohol type notes. Flavour more of the same but just slightly let down by the huge huge alcohol. Plenty of burn that is just about tollerable but in a so wrong its good way. Full bodied and sweet and fruity and all round excellent. Aged bottles are fantastic.Original numbers: 8/4/8/4/17

Bottle: Dark, red-brown color with a medium short lived beige head. Aroma is bittersweet, caramel, coffee and chocolate. Unfortunately the taste is overpowered by a strong alcohol presence; licorice and caramel notes.
Tapped. Hazy brown colour, big foamy beige head. Strong caramel and licorace in aroma along with hints of alcohol. Stinging very sweet flavour of plum, fruit and alcohol.

Thanks again Wunderbier. A very nice belgian seasonal this one is. It poured a cloudy brown. A nice malty and spice filled aroma.  A complex flavor consisting of raisins, ginger, cinammon, chocolate, and some mint. The aftertaste is sweet and warming. Enjoyable in small amounts.

Bottle from "The Offie", Leicester.  Very dark red/browen/purple with an off-white head.  Aromas are fruity and very floral with spices, sweet malts and aniseed.  Very Xmassy (even in April).  Flavours are sweet malts and aniseed with bready yeast, winter fruit and a good deal of boozed-up Xmas pudding.  Very  herblal with more aniseed towards the finish with complementing floral hops.  Warming alcohol vapours on the finish.   Xmas in a (big) bottle.
I was surprised that I liked this so much, but I so did.  Tasted of raisins, ginger, carmel, brown sugar, hints of indian food ingredients.  aftertaste was like dishsoap and mint, but whatever.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 from old notes Rusty brown hue under a buff, frothy head.  Spicy and sweet nosenot unlike root beertoffee, nutty and very lightly roasted; ginger and nutmeg in the background.  Begins quite sweet with caramel and malt before a soft acidity, eventually thinning out into a lengthy finish of spices, lightly bitter and roasty.  Creamy texture, lively carbonation, medium bodied made quite palatable by the alcohol slickness.

Intense, well attenuated and drinkable even with a little bit of heat.

75 cl bottle, best before 8 October 2011.

750 mL, snifter.  Deep brown red body with a large, creamy, off-white, frothy head.  Ginger, caramel, candi sugar, anise, dark fruits...it goes on and on.  Heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter flavor becomes a moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter finish.  Medium full body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: good!  Really good!  Took me a minute to get into it for some reason, but I repeat, good!

Pours a reddish brown color with a medium head.  Aroma is very spicy with mint and a fruity sweet malt.  Spicey flavors.  Malt at the beginning becomes minty.  Upon warming was getting a fair amount of bubble gum.  Complex beer.

Everything about this beer seems to be black - color is a super blackened ruby oil capped by a tall, softly whipped yet lumpy, cinnamon dusted, light tan head. Settles off to a thin, uneven skim and the lacing is whimsically placed in thin and webby broken sheeting.

Aroma is airy and pleasantly soft yet robust of black licorice, dirt, and the blackest of black malts without much sweetness at all. Cindering hints of bright pepper phenols and anise percolate right over the top.

Taste nearly mirrors the aroma with a tender sweet black malt, fainter dark fruity nuances, and cola sryup masked in a ever present black licorice spice. Finishes with shadowy cinnamon, anise, ginger, minty skoal tobacco juice, earthy pine needles; quick, yet muffled, phenol laced alcoholic heat, some leftover cola sweetness and a drying of light throat burning sweetness. 

Complexly characterized in girth that sits just above a medium body but somehow keeps a general softer sweetness and spice thats magnificently handled. Lots of subtle spicy layering and a finely heated throat burn, belly warming, and mind-boggling play between sweet and dark; and, warm and spicy. Fun stuff. It really grows on ya as you engage in its presence.

Even with all its finely set warming and spice this makes for a really nice drinker and an even finer treat. Im becoming more of fan to these Noel/Winter Warmer-type brews and Im thinking Winter isnt really that bad here in MN as long as I have this kind of beer around to keep me company.

Tart cherry and dark fruits in abundance all malt and yeast derived. great malt complexity, with a silky smooth praline and nuts mouthfeel. Some Orang blossom and lemon zest notes on a coriander and basil spice mid body. Great finish with some liquorice and dark caramel notes with Turbinado sugar sweetness.
That is a good beer with a taste of artificial blueberry and smooth taste i could drink plenty of this one. And i think that its marvelous with a piece of dark chocolate

Aroma:Sugar,alcohol,blueberry,caramel and candy...
Appearance:Brown good head...
Flavor:Sugar,candy,blueberry and alcohol...
This is a great beer.

Good complex aroma, malts, sugars, a little bit of apple.  The color is a dark amber with a beige head.  The flavor is a sweet caramel with strong hints of alcohol.  The mouthfeel is sticky.  Quite a nice mellow beer.
poured a brownish red thin tan head.  Sweet alcohol and malt notes a slight bubblegum presence.  Some roasted malt notes and a sweet finish.  easy drinking yet filling.

Bottle conditioned, at Essen Kerstbierfestival 2004. Deep red brown, thin off white head and moderate condition. Sweet caramel, butterscotch and a hint of liquorice in the nose. Alcohol, caramel and butterscotch with a gentle roasted bitterness in the mouth and a slightly burnt note in the finish.

From memory, I cant really tell the difference between this and regular Carolus.  Maybe a little more alcoholic.  I am ashamed to admit I just love the decadent Carolus sweetness - the citrus/coriander really balances it out.

750ml bottle no date code, poured into a grottenbier glass. 
Pours the color of maple syrup, with a creamy short lived head.
Alcohol floats on top
Big fruity aroma, melons, dates, raisins, with some brown sugar and spice thrown in for good measure.
Flavor is sweet, prunes, oranges, anise, candied fruit. a little pithy on the finish.after it warms it takes on a cream sherry like feel. almost a dessert wine type beer. 
ABV is well hidden, so use caution when drinking.

Dark ruby color with a creamy head fading quickly.
A very estery nose (pineapple, citrus), very malty, a lot of curaçao there, thick coating mouth, pretty complex with this  dominance of bitter orange.
it finishes very long, with all the alcohol creating a feeling of Grand Marnier...
Nice holliday beer.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2007 (750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy dark brown body with a large rocky beige head.  Complex aroma of banana, raisins, plums, licorice, and nutmeg.  Flavor of dark fruits and malt.  Alcohol is nicely hidden for 10% abv.  Creamy palate.

750ml Served in a St. Bernardus goblet. Pours a clear mahogany brown with a short lived tan head.  Strong aromas of fruit and booze.  Flavor is heavy dark fruits and dark rum with caramel.  Sweet malt and fruit really comes through strong.  Some carbonation lightens it up a bit otherwise this ale would be too heavy and syrupy.  The high alcohol is fairly well hidden, although there is some warming in the swallow.  There is an odd candy flavor that I am not able to place, and some spicyness. Tasty and interesting.  A very nice seasonal brew and change of pace, but this is far from the mainstream.  I can appreciate the quality here but I couldnt drink a 750 of this often.  Best to share this one, but my lady dont drink the same stuff I do..  took one look at it and passed...  she wanted a Baileys Irish Cream..  oh, well..

GABF 2004 (Dr. Bills tasting @ Falling Rock) and Christmas, 2004, Bellevue NE.  Gold raisins all up in this piece, this is a great Belgian strong.  Mouthfeel is rich and full but not syrupy, despite the considerable sweetness of the beer.  Light melon flavor with a sublte hopiness and prominent caramel maltiness.  Beautiful in a trappist glass, huge frothy head with great retention, dark transluscent orange in the bulb.  Its better after some time in the bottle (my Christmas sampling was about a 13 months old).

UPDATED: APR 18, 2005 Rerate Have had this several time in the last few weeks - my girlfriends favorite beer - it kind of grows on you, the flavors just melt in your mouth, licorice, mint, chocolate, you name it is there.Original 4.3 750 ml. botle - Market Square Liquors, Tallahassee, Fl. Pours a dark, sparkling copper with a thin, wispy off-white head. Aroma is delectable. Pick up hints of bourbon, brandy, mint, dates, raisins, like a liquor soaked fruit cake. Flavor is sweet and malty with hints of brown baked bread (the kind in the can), some mint, bourbon and brandy - like the aroma. Finishes strong and the alcohol is hidden extremely well. Mouthfeel is thick and sturdy - holds up well, missing that spritziness that I find distracting.

Fruity, spicey aroma. Deep ruby red and beautiful, graceful , playful carbonation. If I could have given it more points for appearance I would. Large tan head. Caramel notes, high alcohol profile. Under carbonated.

(Draft: OBriens in San Diego, CA) The flavor is driven by a sweet maltiness and plenty of winter spices like nutmeg.  Candi sugar and yeast are prevalent in the flavor.  Sweet on the palate, but not sticky or cloying.  Aromas of candi and spice, predominantly nutmeg, plus very malty.  Chestnut brown in color, nearly still in appearance.  Light tan head fades away to nothing almost immediately.  Decent carbonation considering the still appearance and total lack of head.  Damn fine beer.  I could drink this all night, but the wallet says no.
Dark reddish brown, moderate brown head, banana, port, raisin aroma, sweet flavors of fruit, particularly cherry, some chocolate, and sugar. Finishes slightly bitter. Not bad.

i drank this  in a chimay trappist glass,revcieving  a lovely crimson body a small off-white head.i gathered an aroma of liquorice,brown sugar,and blow pops.i was very happy with my first sip of this.liquorice,malts,ginger bread,christmas trees,and bubblegum.this brought me right back to christmas day.what an outstanding brew this is!!!

Delicious!  Im shocked that I absolutely loved this beer.  The 10% abv is extremely well-hidden and the malty sweetness and complexity are just fantastic.  Nice fruits (oranges) in the body and light spiciness to boot.  Sensational brew if you go for a sweeter, malty, beer that tastes like its 7%.

Draft - cloudy red with a beautiful creamy head - almost looked like a nitro pour.  Very fruity in nose and flavor.  Cherry and berries are what really jumped out at me.  Long, slightly sour finish.  Sweet and very nice!

A big thanks to npdempse for this one.  Pours turbid brown with a big, creamy tan head.  Aroma of big fruit, berries, spices, slight detergent.  Tastes malty, very fruity, with some spices, caramel, and nuts at the finish.  Full bodied, well balanced, and absolutely delicious.  Christmas is over, but you should still get out there are grab some of this for yourself.

2002, Draft: Liquorice dominates aroma with some chocolate and dried fruit (raisins, prunes, apricots) notes. Brown edging on amber with a beige lasting head. Aniseed, spice, chocolate, caramel, raisins and apricots all in the flavour. Smooth full bodied feel. Very nice beer.

First, I should note that I drank a bottle of the 2004 vintage, which was probably way too early but I couldnt help myself.  This beer has a somewhat sweet, but not fruity, essential flavor, almost like a tawny port but without the spice.  A lot of subtle berry flavors abound.  I had a glass of vintage Noel this summer and it was much better than the 04, but that must be due to age.  I definitely recommend picking up a few bottles and aging them for a few years at least.

The beer came in a handsome 750 ml. bomber with the obligatory wire cage and cork.  As the cork was pulled the wonderful aromas of cherry, brown sugar, and slightly grass hops filled the air.  The pour revealed the body to be quite dark brown, with a small head that was short lived.  The carbonation level was quite low.  The taste was spicy, roasty, and not the least bit boozy.  Brown sugar, cinnamon, mint, and nutmeg were the stars of the show here followed by a crackling dry hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel was full but not overbearingly so.  The alcohol was sneakily hidden under these layers.  This is good craftsmanship.

750 ml corked and caged, Dark and cloudy reddish-brown in color, big thick clingy brown head, sweet fruity and bready aroma, full bodied, alcohol hidden very well, smooth and velvety mouthfeel, finishes a little sweet, this is a great Belgian ale, very drinkable and tasty.
Deep red color.  Quickly dissipating head.  Great aroma of sweet candi.  Spicy and sugary taste.  A very nice christmas beer.
Bottle.  Deep chestnut color.  Tan head.  Very malty and sweet.  Yeast and cola in aroma. Medium bodied.  Very nice

#400 Pours out a hazy mahogny color with a small light tan head.  Fine lacing is maintained very well. Aromas are a very nice combination of caramel, apple ciderplums, brown sugar and just a little of that classic Belgian spice. Flavors are much the same.  Lots of sweet caramel and brown sugar with some smokey notes as well.  The high ABV is noticeable but plays well together with the other flavors.  Fine but lively carbonation and a slightly bitter woody aftertaste.  Very nice way to close out 2004 Thanks for the recomendation Larry Pitonka

Pours thick and dark reddish brown with minimal head. Vinous aroma with light spices. Maybe some nutmeg, allspice and cinnamon ? I also get some black current. A bit oxidized. Rich in body with a warm alcohol finish. Subdued spice flavor with some star anise. Chocolate malt taste too.

Nice dark brown colour, with a beautiful soft foam head. Lots and lots of spice in the aroma. So much so I could barely detect the malts. Mostly cinimon and and clove. The spice carried through to the taste and was pretty good. NOt an every day bear, but it was nice to drink while opening presents with my fiances family.

Very attractive pouring mahogeny colored beer with a big well retained tan colored head.  Aroma is malty with spruce and tons of spices, cinnamon, clove, and more.  Flavor is big and deeply malty with one of the strongest use of spices I have ever experienced, however in the case of this beer it is not over done.  A perfect ending to a wonderful Christmas day.

very interestging aromalike cinimon alspice, burbon, cherrys, caugh medicine, and alcohol. clear dark brown color. smooth, fruity, astringent,  cherrys, cinimon, other strange spices. not as thick as I thought. very spicy. akin to vin chaud.  good on a cold night

750ML. Man phew. Unexpected going into this. Deep dark brown with a coca coloured fluffy head.  Very fruity and sweet. Malty aroma. Yeasty. taste of banana, raison, vanilla and cinnamon. Alchohol afterbite, nice hit. Perfect Christmas brew on the eve of Christmas Eve. This thing is a dessert in itself!~! Too bad you cant flambe this over some bananas. mmmmm . Kinda scothy finish for me. Ill be picking a few more of these up. 10% alchy. Wonder how it will age.
Deep dark brown below an ample tan head.  Fruity and malty aroma with plenty of yeast and spice notes. Quite flavorful. Banana, dates, cinnamon, bread pudding, treacle, and raison. A lovely beer.

(Draft)  Deep brown, with reddish tones, nice head and lace. Fruity, yeasty nose  with a touch of alcohol. Medium bodied, smooth, warming with sweet flavors of ripened fruit, nice yeast character, bready, hints of anise and alcohol. Fine brew.
Pours a deep brown with a light beige head. Aromas of cinnamon, vanilla bean and anise. Huge malty sweet body with a lot of breadiness. Lush flavors of dried fruits. Beautiful.

Dark amber, light beige head.  Could not pick up anything definitive in the nose.  That either means the nose was complex or I was just unable to determine.  Would have to say some spice and fruit.  Medium bodied.  The flavor was bitter and alcoholic.  Didnt much care for this one.

Bottle:  Sweet aroma.  Kind of has a coke syrup smell to it with some spice.  Pours a brown with some red hilights when held to the light.  Okay off-white head.  Unless youve been to the Dominican Republic you probably dont know what Im talking about, but this has a strong mamajuana (mixture of rum, honey, white wine, roots, sticks, spices, and a whole bunch of other stuff) taste to it.  Flavor of coke syrup lingers in the background.

(draft)  Highly recommended by all whod had it at Rich Os.  Definitely a Christmas Ale - all sorts of complex flavors.  I thought the fruitiness was a little bit too much but I suppose it was needed to mask all of that alcohol.
Draft Rich Os: Poured cloudy caramel brown with a medium tan head. Fruity malty aroma. Sweet alcohol flavor. Lightly frutiy taste with a mildly grassy finish. Somewhat vodka-ish as well.

What a winter warmer should be.  Aroma is a wonderful mix of figs, brown sugar and plums-almost like a homemade fruitcake.  At 10% abv itll definitely warm you up on a winter evening.  My favorite of the belgian x-mas brews (so far.)

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Pours a deep brown/ amber hue with a slight off-white head.  Aromas of caramel and toffee and a little hay.  Flavors of copper????? with a slight dryness and brown sugar and spice.  A little disappointing for a Belgian winter ale.
This beer poured a medium brown w/ reddish hues and very slight head and no lacing.  Malty, raisin sweetness, w/ hints of black malt.  Woody on the palate, big effervescence and slightly wet.

on tap at elysian. nice work by duff in talking them into giving us a glass of this stuff. ruby amber colour, some woody cherry aroma, loads of alcohol and candi sugar flavour drowning out any yeast character. i think this batch must have been tainted in some way

750 ml bottle. Cloudy Orange in color with a tan fluffy head. Fig, raisiny, prune aroma. Sweet. Malty dry palate. Fruity.  Shared with Maibockaddict. Year old bottle. Nice smooth sweetness and maltiness, not overpowering. Nice beer.

This would have gotten a 5 for appearance if the label didnt look like a lame knockoff of the St Feuillien Noel label. Floral, fruity, somewhat cocoa aroma and flavor . Warming, ABV masked.  Moderately sweet, spicy bitterness. Woody, pointed spicy finish with a medium body. My only real complaint about this otherwise balanced beer is that it had notes of artificial grape

750 ml bottle, cellared from last year. Cloudy orange with tan fluffy head. Aroma of figs, dates, raisins, cotton candy, and just general sweetness. Malty but dry firm palate. Malty fruitiness lingers well after each sip. Not cloying, a but sort of sweet maltiness  that one can enjoy. The raisins and other fruits shine as they meld with the malt. This is real nice and I would have to say will cellar a good long time if cared for properly.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Chestnut body with a dirty load of suspended particles and a loose fluffy head. Malty aroma of molasses and an odd note similar to pumpkin. Sweet flavor of dark candy sugar, molasses, brown sugar and some moderate spicy hops. Nice hop bitterness and a leathery quality balance the sweetness and round this out well.

(sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm) Mahogny brown with ruby notes. Dense tan head. Fruity, sweet and deep aroma of figs, plums, pears and black pepper. Thick malty flavour of figs, fresh tobacco, dried plums with a slightly peppery alcoholic note. Long warming finish with strong notes of belgian chocolate and figs. Oily, thick mouthfeel.

Murky brown with a medium sized tan head. Aroma sweet and of fermented candi sugar, some spice.  Taste suprises in a good way. not as sweet as smell..lots of caramel and toffee.spice is cardomonomomnomomn or nutmeg. Very good.

Rich, brown and garnet in the glass, light tan head rising an inch above the beer.  Lots of lacing.  Complex aromas of sweet yeast, licorice, and oak.  Flavors are also full and vibrant, with a subtle sweetness and a complementary toasted malt.  A full palate enhances the depth of this top-fermented beer.

poured an ultra dark ruby color almost as dark as cola with a thin white head...Aroma was strongly of sweet malts...Flavor was very sweetly malted with notes of dark fruits, raisins and plums...a nice Christmas beer

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2006 Dark, murky brown color with a big creamy tan head. Sweet aroma of candi sugar, malt and caramel. Sweet malty flavor with lots of caramel, candi sugar and spices(nutmeg, anise). Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2006 This is one of the many joys of the Christmas season. The coming of the holiday ales. This is probably my favorite brewer on the planet. But this was my first opportunity to try this particular selection. Sampled from a 25 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark red-brown color with a small tan head. The aroma was sweet and fruity though it had a bit of an alcohol sting to it. The flavor was sweet, tart and had a noticeable cherry element. The alcohol shows through rather harshly though and that for me was the only real detraction. Otherwise a nice brew.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2009  On draught at The Rover, Göteborg.  
Dark brown, light brown head. Aroma from prune and dried fruits, rich malty with pleasant salmiak. Ultra smooth palate, flavour is a little spicy with dried fruits and salmiak and tidbits. Superb beer.

Black color with a tall, thick and creamy head.  Damn baby, it looks beautiful!  Wonderful aroma of bread and spice with a hit of alcohol.  The taste is very similar, expounding on the bread.  There is a very interesting peppery finish that is remincient of tobacco.  This must be a house flavor as it seems to show up in every other Gouden Ive had.  The alcohol is ridiculously well hidding.  Damn fine beer!

2003 Vintage:  Brown/Red Coloring with Good Tan Head.  Cherry...Currant Spices..Bread Dough and Alcohol Aroma...On The Tongue...Bread Dough, Winter Spices..Tobacco...Giving it a Sharp Tang at the End.  Good Warming...Nice Thick Body.. A Subtle Brew Overall and Quite Seductive, As It Slowly Lures You in To Drink More and More.  VERY Enjoyable Winter Ale!!

Vintage 2003, matured on keg for one year.

The colour is clear brown with a small hint of red. The firm beige foam is two-finger thick and made of medium sized bubbles. 

The smell is very complex and intense: Among the flavours I noticed marzipan, dark rum, cinnamon, caraway, preserved cherries, milk chocolate and a full apple pie. Wow!

The carbonation is robust and grand with small bubbles.

The taste starts with some sweet lactose-notes that slowly change into a full-bodied taste of apple pie, complete with cinnamon and butter. There is a slight flavour of alcohol, but it isnt dominating at all. The long and multifaceted aftertaste includes such flavours as sweet Madeira wine, candid apples, clotted cream and, for that special contrast, a hint of bitter hops. 

This is indeed a world-class yuletide beer. Yummy!

I talked to the publican at The Rover (in Gothenburg, Sweden) about this beer. He had stored it for a year in his cellar, just for fun. At that point, he wasnt even sure that the beer had survived the maturing! We agreed that the keg probably needed to settle for a few days to reduce the carbonation a little.

Thin light brown head which lasts the duration due to some great carbonation.  Aroma of brown sugar, yeast, maybe a hint of black cherry and a touch of alcohol.  Color is a cloudy dark brown with some orange around the edges.  Thick and warming with caramel, alcohol, dark fruit and a bit of a tangy zip (sour).  Finish is slightly sour and warming.  A good belgian but not as goods as the Gouden Carolus Cuvee Van De Keizer.  The best thing brewery makes.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2005 Dark brown, with a brown head.  Aroma is yeasty(like a brown bread), brown sugar(dark Belgian candi) and slightly hoppy.  Flavor is syruppy sweet and slightly bitter(maybe hallertau?) .  Full bodied.  Well made/

Dark brown color with a thin layer of head.  The aroma is a very spicy one, mostly marked by an anise with hints of cherries in the background.  Flavor is rather smooth, with a nice combination of sweetness and spice, followed by an overall warming sensation.  Another quality brew by this brewer.
Dark brown colour with nice lasting head. Aroma is sweet and malty, with hints of licorice. Flavor is malty with a clear taste of licorice, some alcohol in the finish.

Dark amber color, lasting yellow head. Sweet caramel, licorice and bubble gum aroma, slight alcohol comes up too. Strong licorice with sweet roasted notes in flavor. Medium to full bodied, still little bit of thin for 10.5% ABV. High carbonation is little surprise, but it fits here well. Warm mouthfeel with high alcohol, although it is covered pretty well. Licorice lasts in aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2004 Bottled (0.75l), alc. 10.5% (BB 10/2006)
Dark red portwine-like color with small tanned head. Aroma has anis, licorice, plum, fruitcake and chocolate. Par to flavor: lots of salty licorice. Mouthfeel is (a bit too) carbonated. Alcohol jumps from palate in the finish. Aftertaste is salty and malty. Really interesting and complex brew. (9/4/7/4/16 4.0)
Draught, alc. 11%
Deep clear red, huge creamy brown head. Sweet berries in a nose. Sweet, wineous portwine-like, tasting grapes. Easy to drink and warming, hides ABV well. Totally different than bottled version - but almost as good. (8/5/7/4/15 3.9)

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 (Bottled, 0.75l, 6 months old, sampled 2/2005) Deep, dark red-amber color with a largeish, light beige, lacy head. Sweetish-caramely, slightly alcoholic aroma with lots of anise and licorice. Very smooth, sweet, very anise-licorice-malty, spicy and herby, cough-syrup-like flavor. Long, sweetish and sticky anise finish. Medium to full-bodied, quite soft-carbonated, slightly liqueur-like palate. Alcohol is quite well hidden. A nicely spiced and herby, sweet herb-liqueur-like brew. Maturing even for a few months makes the brew clearly more balanced and enjoyable. A quite original brew, no matter what. (15 months old, sampled 11/2005, BBE 10/2006: no real change, maybe some smoothing in the flavor and flowery hops, too. Alcohol is now perfectly hidden. Still not quite ready yet - or maybe it just is what it is. Stored too cold (in +6 C), though. Quite sweet - like anise liquour.) (18 months old, sampled 2/2006, stored in room temp) Clearly dried flavor with immense fruitiness and huge amounts of salty licorice. Quite yummy, but not close to its peak, I guess.
Bottle. Sweet, spicy, anisy aroma. Dark chestnut colour, small light-brown head. Flavour is sweet, spicy, anisy, cough-syrup-like. Very complex.

750 ml bottle, 2003-4 presumably.  Dark, rich molasses in color, soupy off-white head.  Rich bourbon-vanilla in nose, with hints of orange, juicy thick spicy Seville orange.  Whiskey and smoke join the lusciously complex fruit on the tongue, combining for a very drinkable, "wet" approach, alcohol well-hidden throughout, great sweet-sour balance; another work of art from Het Anker.

Great beer! Dark brown/red with a wonderful beige creamy head. Mature and dried fruits  aroma with powerful alcohol hints. Taste has notes of orange peel, raisins, chocolate, ruhm and a lot more. Great body,  very balanced in carbonation, hops and sweetness.

Pours with an amazing color. Purple with ascents of yellow, orange and red. Beautiful color, it glows in the light. However, a pretty lousy Belgian head. 

Smells like fruit punch. 

WOW! Sour red grapes, cherries, red licorice, raisins and caramel up front. Finishes with a somewhat sour, sweet malt and chocolate-caramel combination with a hint of alcohol. Tastes unbelieveable!

Bottled. Purchased at Delirium Cafe. Dark ruby body with foamy brown head. Nose is malty with chocolate and spices (ginger and nutmeg) along with dark fruits and anise. Taste is malty and rich with chocolaty notes, dark fruits, and spices. Sweet and spicy would sum it up best. Carbonated with light sharpness. Finish is somewhat dry with cocoa, dark fruits and spice. Great beer!

OOOOO!, is all I can think, at first, as I merely sniff the bottle-top before pouring...a gorgeous garnet hue fills my glass, with a creamy tan head on top. Aroma is fresh, sweet, buttery, strangely fruity, apricots, peaches, and others Im not as familiar with, but damned, if aint fruitiness! Smooth mouthfeel, mellow texture, tingly, but minor hop sensation. Loads of maltiness! Utterly gorgeous, and an instant favorite on first sample! Wonderfully warm and alcoholic, but deceptive in its strength. Can this little sweetie-pie really be 1O.5%? And she said she was...

Sweet syrupy nose with fig, anise, caramel. Dark brown clear with off-white lacing head. Thick bodied with light carbonation. Sweet start, spices, anise, alcohol. Nutty flavor, pistachio, baklava. No acidity, light bitter. Vapory finish, with sweet nutty spicy after.

Bottle pours brown, amber hues, medium off-white frothy head that quickly settles, small bits floating about, light carbonation with fairly attractive lacing.   Aroma is of dark pitted fruit, sweet, candi sugar, with hints of licorice.   Flavor is of plums, some fig, raisin, candy, and some licorice.   This one seems quite the treat.   Great body, full mouthfeel.   Finishes with even more of a licorice bite.   Probably one of the better Winter offerings to come out of Belgium.   Highly recommended, and its even much better on draught.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2004 2 for 1 deal at freakin frog las Vegas
dark brown color nutty fruit taste strong Alcohol there but not overwheming.
Gotta have this again in the winter
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2005 Bottle. Hazy dark brown, Fruity sweet aroma and taste, and a hint of alcohol in the end. I just love this beer. And they have it in the bottle shop just 1 floor down.

Lasting light beige head on a coppery brown body.  Malty, plums, dark fruit, hints of roast,  a perfumey floral and caramel invade the olfactory senses.  Some alcohol and brown sugary sweetness, and a lightly solvent aroma as it warms.  Flavor is malty and well balanced, light plum and raisin flavors, light hop flavor and bitterness in the finish.  Aftertaste is lightly bitter, roast and cararamel.  Some sugar sweetness and toasty malts in between.  Lighter medium body, higher carbonation, and light alcohol warmth.  I really like this beer! Id like to see it age a little bit as well to see if complexities increase, but this is a pretty good one IMHO!  Well worth trying.

Pepper, sweet malt, coriander, bitter orange, marzipan in the aroma. Clear, dark amber with decent tan head that recedes to thick lasting cover with some lace.  Yeasty flavour with spiciness and plenty of dark fruit complexity. Sweet malts balance. Tea-like tannins are noteable. Pretty full bodied, strong carbonation and great smooth wheat-like mouthfeel. Excellent. Bottle (enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere). Thanks Guzzler67.

Cloudy dark brown, good off-white film, fully lasting. Spicy nose, christmas spruce, minty. Mild alcohol comes through, but youd never guess 10%. Spiced old ale reminiscent. Very yeasty, cloves, maybe chocolate, christmas cake fruitiness+prunes+dates and other dark fruits, leafy, coffeeish. Complex like most of its kind. Red licorice and toffee malt sweetness, very tea-like in mouth, lemon notes. Fluffy heavy body, high carbonation...Marvellous christmas beer, stylish and flavorful. Props to you Larry!

Pours a deep mahogany brown with a thick, puffy, and well-lacing, bone colored head.  Musty and lightly spiced aroma is nicely balanced with Belgian caramel malt and yeast.  Starts sweet and caramely, with a hint of peppery spice and a sweeter, yet somewhat alcoholic finish.  Nice complexity and spice balance throughout,  an enjoyable holiday beer.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Super sweet candy sugar. Apple sauce, yeasty, sugary, thick, sweet and sticky, theres a lot of flavour, but it doesnt go anywhere. Way too sweet, with a big shot of the 10% alcohol at the end.
Chestnut brown to reddish color, with a nice little tan head on top. Aroma is very nice, candi sugar, dark fruits, brandy, licorice. Flavor is balanced, dark fruits somealcohol. Very nice beer.
reddish brown color with very little head.  on tap at the Toronado.  bananas and caramel taste, very yummy!

Presentation: 75 cl corked bottle. Poured into a Leffe chalice.

Dark reddish-brown, nice beige/tan head w/ good retention.
Enormous, warm, spicy, in-your-face aroma full of the best Christmas has to offer. And then some.
Gorgeously balanced taste; the powerful, richly warming, and complex spiciness is kept beautifully in check by a nice, bitter finish. Mouthfeel and drinkability are through the roof; I had to pace myself in order not to finish this one too quickly. Wow.

This is one of the best beers I've tasted, and certainly the best winter seasonal, easily surpassing even the magnificent Brøckhouse Julebryg 2003.
I cannot wait to see how this one ages; I'm afraid I'll have to ask my girlfriend to hide the key to the cellar, lest I prematurely break open one or more of the eight bottles of Gouden Carolus Christmas I've stashed there...
Dark cloudy brown color with spicy caramel smell.Sweet spicy flavor with a warming alcohol feel. Fairly complex but missing something. Finishes a little like syrup but still slightly bitter.

Dark, slightly murky brown with a big, tan head as one might expect of a fine Belgian brew.  Nose is redolent of an alcohol strenth combining port like with a fermenting berry note.  Spices are muted, dark ripe fruit,plums, apple and leather combine with light coffee and a succinct of mocha.  Alcohol warmth is quite noticable.  A big, bold holiday brew.

Scents of rich spice and intresting yeast.  Flavors of rich toffee, chocolate, maple syrup, mint, and spice dominate. Very hearty and really sweet.  Unfortunately, any of the deep complexities (like yeast) are covered by an overwhelming sweet candi sugar and toffee flavor.
Sweet caramel with some alcohol in the aroma.  the color is yellowish, but with copper edges.  Taste is thick, sweet to syrupy and strong of alcohol.  Not great, but OK for Belgian.
Malty sweet with some hints of fruit (cherries?) and a warming sensation of alcohol.  A bit syrupy like a port or sherry with low carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2004 2004-06-04, Keg, 8-5-8-4-16=41Dark amber color, ruby; creamy head. Can really smell all the 5 spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, ). Malty, velvety, spicy: wonderful Xmas treat!2004-02-22, Bottle, 7-4-8-4-15=38Dark amber color; creamy head. Aroma dominated by the caramel, with a light feeling of ammonia. Quite sweet, and a lot of caramel, a quite good Christmas beer, but missing some complexity. Thanks Jens (Ungstrup) for this bottle.
Aroma of sour apples, spice, yeast and bubble gum. Nice spicy notes with sharp bitterness comming out clearly. Some citrus. Metallic aftertaste in the end.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2006 Deep brown body.  Brownish, fastly diminishing head, Fairly lacing.  Malty (roasted) and spicy aroma.  Also a lightly alcoholic aroma.
Lighty bitter - sweet flavour.  Long bitter finish.  Alcohol-dry palate.
Smelled great, so many good things in there. But I was overwhelmed by the flavor. As stated before, there was a certain perfume flavor that I couldn't get over.
Dark with small head. Sweet, perfumy, fruity, lightly spicy. Full. Complex.

Almost opaque brown color with a small tan head.  Decent lacing.  Mild aroma...malty sweet and fruity.  Flavor is sweet...very sweet.  Earthy.  Body is rich and thick.  Spicy aftertaste as well.  The 10% is well masked.  Pretty darn good.
Big, Belgian candy sweetness, with big notes of spice, orange, banana, and some herbs and veggies even. A little sourness and bitterness balanced things out.

Estery, dried fruit, yeast, cocoa nose.  Very attractive ruby-brown hue.  Steady carbonation.  Slight sourness, woody notes, cherry, dark chocolate, medicinal, spice, dried apricot, medium body, finishing long, lingering fruit, dryness, and subtle hop/spice usage...Alcohol is very well hidden in my opinion.  I bet this will do well with some age.  Very nice, an incredible Holiday beer.  A must try!
Dark brown, tan head. Sweet spicecake nose with nutmeg, ginger, licorice. Flavor is quite sweet, with a nice bready yeastiness. Spice flavors are notable, as is a slight touch of chocolate.

A nice Belgian strong, with a good color and a very nice nose featuring banana and alcohol notes.  Flavor features both again, with more emphasis on both than in the nose.  The palate is a bit short lived in my opinion, but a good brew anyway.  Alcoholic warmth lingers an exceptionally long time, though.

This is a great strong brown that is full of malty richness, finishing with a crisp and tangy, though root beer like charactor. Spicy, but not too spicy. Full, strong and bursting with flavor, just like I like it. Very nice!

The most dark fruits (figs, raisins, plums) I've ever tasted in a beer. Dense, bready texture with walnut flavor as well. Flavors of a molasses chew (sticky brown sugar and malt), and a bit of allspice. Definitely a holiday ale. Brings the term "winter warmer" to a new level.

Dark, coppery body. Thin, yeasty head. Rich, chocolatey aromas. Malt flavor is sweet, chocolatey. A touch of dark fruit is present in the finish, sugary, rich, warming. Finish is smooth, lacks bitterness, abv is covered quite well. Fruit flavors are subtle and the overall malt flavor leaves just a bit to be desired. Still a fine brew. Lingering sweetness....
a very deep red colour, good head. a very special taste/flavour rousted malt, grain, chocalte avery nice beer!

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2004 75cl Corked bottle No date. Poured a hazy deep amber color with a thin tan head which settled to a thin film. Aroma has a sugary sweetness to it, some bready malt and fruit overtones. Alcohol shows up as it warms. Has a medium body that is smooth with a crispy finish. Flavor is sweet with malt almost barley style. Some fruit and a bit of spiciness also detectable. Overall not a bad seasonal.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Good amber color.  Very festive beer with the cinnamon flavor.  Fruity smell.

Good one to round out the season with, as work beckons tomorrow.  Deep amber brown, decent but fading head.  Aroma of toffee, butterscotch oriented malts, with thick candied fruits.  Layers of flavor dance on the palate, candied fruits, namely oranges, some anise (but not enough to detract), tiny hint of cinnamon, some plums, and some hoppy kick on the finish to provide a bit of balance.  Good stuff.

No snow to go with my bottle. Just the accompanying good friend (that procured and delivered said bottle). Says a lot that after three other hefty holiday beers this one still shines. A tad darker than the others sampled with among other things a hint of anise. Thick, rich, full warm, yum, good, nice, quaffable, sip, glug. (author notes that it makes going back to work more of a chore)

Bottle.  A dark murky brown color with a light brown head.  Sweet toffee, caramel, alcohol, a fruit aroma.  As others have mentioned, I found that something off in the flavor.  It was as if the individual components were good, but when they were combined something went wrong.  A thick plum and spice flavor.

Very cloudy dark brown color with a beige head. Very sweet aroma with dark fruit, alcohol and sweet malt. Very sweet spicey flavor. Dark fruit, malt, cinnamon, clove, pepper and alcohol. Very nice tingly feel and crisp finish.

Cloudy, cloudy brown with a medium tan head. The aroma was full of dark fruits, sugar, spices, and wet bark. The flavor was fruity as well...figs, cherries, slight banana, with a noticeable alcohol punch. The feel was very lively...crisp, dry finish.
Sweet malty candied fruity aroma.Dark chestnut appearance.Very sweet caramel Fruity cherry dark fruits flavor with a metallic mild hoppy finish.Liquid fruit cake.

Ahh a very fine brew for xmas but i wouldn't expect anything else from the Belgians.A nice rich brown brew with a foamy head that dissapated after a few minutes.Heavy taste of alcohol like rum which was delicious.The finish kept my belly warm for awhile.

Dec. 25th is the only time to treat oneself to a Christmas a fine Beer like this.  YES!  This was very nice Christmas beer with a lot of flavor and a very nice finish.  This was an exceptional Christmas Ale. Merry Christmas!

What better to review for Christmas day than this one? 750ml brown bottle, corked and caged. No freshness date seen, but it's the 2003 batch. The cork basically shot out of the bottle when opened, indicating a very effervescent beer inside. Served in my Chimay chalice for full effect. Rich aromas of the season, such as nutmeg, cinnamon, yeasty bread, rum soaked raisins, brandy soaked dark fruits like figs, dates, and plums. Poured out a murky light brown color, with a decadent oatmeal colored head. Thick lacing evident along the sides of the glass, along with a mat of yeasty islands floating in the middle. Tastes are of Christmas in a glass. Grandma's special brandy soaked fruitcake, in liquid form.
Absolutely heavenly in both taste & texture. Incredibly rich mouthfeel, silky & smooth. Spicy yeast makes for an interesting combination with the strong malt backbone. Finishes dry, and somewhat sweet, but not cloying. A really great choice on my part for today.

The Ale pours a red amber color with a tan head and little lace.  The aroma is of ripe cheese.  The flavor is sweet and spicy and shows some woody/sherry notes.  The palate is rather light.  Overall, I like this pretty well.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2004 Draught at The Rover, Gothenburg.
Dark amber with a fine head.
Fresh and spicy aroma and a sweetish flavour with toffee.
A bit thin though.
Re-rate christmas 04. Its now a year older and has matured a lot. Really full aroma; a bit aceton and chocolate. A lot of raisin in the flavour.

Extremely rich aroma propelled by alcohol, giving fruit and malts.  Moderate head, frothing on a dark wood-red body.  Complex alcohol flavors.  (Sampled at Southern Ratebeer Gathering, Austin, TX, December 6, 2003)
Sweet liquorice aroma.  Good caramel malt sweetness, Malt is deep and rich.  Sweet alcoholic finish.  Straigtforward,but very pleasant in an uncomplex way.
Sweet licorce and cream aroma. Ruby, light brown head, good lace. Licorice, anis, sweet, butter, soft. I think this beer must age well.

Creamy salmiacaroma. It seems surprisingly thin at first, but it isn't. Flavor has salmiac, anis and butter. A malty sweetness, that gets stronger. Storage is needed to gain some depth and complexity.
Dutch ratebeer meeting. Clear red-brown, medium head. Aroma of licorice and anis. Sweet taste, licorice, butter, lakritz/salmiak, anis.
Clear and dark amber body. Light brown fast disappearing head. Liquorice/menthol nose. Flavor is sweet with tones of menthol and alcohol.

Dutch ratebeer meeting. Clear red-brown, medium head. Aroma of alcohol and liquorice, nice. Flavour of malts and anise, pretty complex. Lingering palate. Nice beer, but it gets kind of boring after awhile.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2008 (dutch ratebeer meeting) Smell is creamy, lakritz/salmiak and has some fruits in it. Clear, dark red/brown coloured with a thin and lasting head.
