Salmiak, anis taste; sweet, a bit fruity and some butter. Bit thin palate. Alcohol is quite well hidden. This beer can use some aging.

Bottle from same batch as my previous entry (2003, dec 14) Only now aged for 4,5 years. The beer becomes more porty and dusty and looses some of the heavy laurel/licorice flavor. So the beer has gained more balance and complexity.  I would say my conclusion 4,5 years ago was correct. I recommend a little less aging, say three years, so it is a little less dusty (and hopefully still has the good port taste)

Pours a dark brown with a reddish edge to it. Foamy head accompanied by a nice layer of lace.  Pretty standard nose for a BSA. Malts, a yeast, and a peculiar sweet fruit I'm trying to figure out. Maybe an apricot. Some bubblegum aromas as well. Very similar flavors. More of the bubblegum apparent in the flavor. Very smooth palate though, finishing with a great floral hop flavor. This is nice.

2003: Dark ruby, mahogany color with a huge puffy head. This bottle is relentless and is always giving me good head and lacing. Even with the bottle conditioning I never encountered a yeast layer at the bottom, happy of that. The aroma is has some traditional belgian noses, nothing outstanding, a little fruity. The flavor is extrememly well rounded; alcohol hidden, malt is semi sweet and flavorful while the hops balance everything else. On the negative front this seems a bit metallic to me. Finishes very pleasent though and I keep coming back for more. Great BSA Winter for Buck Dich!
Appears a murky, unfiltered brown.  Very fruity aroma, and taste seems a bit geusy.  Extra points for the Gouden.

Hazy brown hue with small head and okay lace. Nice big floral aroma of dried fruit, sweet malts, spicy, and heavy yeast esters. The taste starts swet and spicy with a light bitter finish and citric undertones. Medium-bodied with a slight bite on the lively palate. Wow, what a nice Christmas brew. Pick one up for yourself and your best friends.

Aroma:  pine boughs, mint, fresh rain, and hospital halls
Appearance:  dark brown/amber
Flavor:  minty (similar to a mouthwash), with earthiness mixed in.  
Palate:  bitter carbonation that bites you on the side of the tongue.  
Good for a Christmas beer.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Creamy and spicy aroma, so strong, rich and floral, just beautiful.  Clear dark amber appearance with a big white head.  So thick and rich, the flavors are hard to put into words.  Sweet cider, banana, alcohol, celery or carrots.  Wonderfully smooth, with a bit of medicine-like flavors in the finish.

Mon Dieu... This ale really impressed me.  Its aroma, color and mouthfeel really wowed me.  We had this at our club X-mas party, so I am trying to dig deep to remember all the aspects of this wonderful exlir.  It started of with a nice caramel taste with lingering notes of raisin.  A little sweet, but not cloying.  The carbonation was lively and had a nice head that lingered around for awhile.  The one thing that struck me the most was the wonderful aroma (sweet with a slight lactic twinge and an estery yeast note)  Great Noel beer.
Very fruty and heavy. Banana flavor. Quite dry, but still well balanced. Strong alcohol taste. It explodes in yourd mouth.

Dark brown in colour with a dense tan head. Aroma of nutmeg, strong malt, raisins and a few other fruits. Medium-bodied; Slight sweet fruit flavour up front with raisins and other pit fruits rounding out the flavours. Aftertaste bittered from the malt and shares some dark spiceyness. Overall, a decent beer-definately worth trying in the winter! I shared this bottle, purchased by good friend JonR888710, which he purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia. I sampled this one on 29-November-2003.
Ruby red with nice head; citrus nose, oily constitution.  Aroma was inviting but taste failed my expectations and finished hard.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: I just bought this bottle, so I am assuming it is the 2003.  Very pretty red amber color with a lasting foamy beige head.  I got lots of orange in the nose.  Very sharp orange liquer taste that was harsh on my tongue.  I was frankly expecting more, but still a nice offering.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2004 2002 bottle. Aroma of raisins, plums and malts. Sweet up front with some dry fruity flavors. Clean slightly spiced and warming finish. Good stuff. 

re-rate. Unknown vintage.  Mahogany color with a beautiful head. Fruity and spicy aroma, melon, plum and corriander.  Lightly sweet, some bready dough flavor. Some fruit notes and bubblegum like sweetness in the finish.

2002 bottle. Deeper orange/amber color, thicker tan head. Aroma of ripe fruit (raisins, plum, cherry), caramel, malt, and some alcohol. Fruity flavor again with caramel and some cinnamon spice. Creamier mouthfeel gives way to strong alcohol burn. A very nice Christmas beer.

Orangey-amber colour.  Thick, lightly browned head.  Aroma of cherries, alcohol, semisweet chocolate, oranges.  The palate is assertively alcoholic, with cherries, slight spiciness and a lightly orangey fruitiness.  Lingering alcohol in the finish.

This is a No Shit Brew, it knocked my freaking shoes off and I halved a bottle with BeanDip. The body poured a rich amber brown oak, balancing out a slight tan head, though large rings of lacing are left behind. The aroma and flavor are FULL with ripened pit fruits, pear, plum- but more prune, apricot, raisin, fig, 
cinnamon, & vanilla,  … A mass of brown sugar, doughy yeast, buttered Sunday biscuits, caramelized apples, intense; exhilarating got me sloppy, Terrific! Amazingly creamy and full toffee palate, Delightful, one of the best Christmas brews I’ve had yet! 
 I’m soon going to buy another bottle for sure!
Toffee, caramel and some fruit in the aroma, deep amber, lovely sponge toffee head. Rich toffee taste, along with raisins, plums and nuts. Silky smooth texture, nicely bitter. Fantastic!

Live, amber-woody tone, thick creamy head. Mellow malt base, woody with richness of flavours typical of Belgian ales. Unusual a bit like Baltic porter that was mixed with strong Belgian. Spicy, strong but short bitterness. Medium is somehow softer and creamier with touch of honey.

Dark, purple-red color with a medium thick, khaki colored head. Smells of hops, dates, nutmeg spice, raisins and a lingering German  hop smell remniscent of Heiniken and other german lagers (not a good thing). Flavor is sweet and strong with cherries, malt, raisins, dates and anise. Aftertaste is sweet and spicy and hangs on the tongue for quite awhile. Pretty good winter ale, although not great. Sampled from a 750ml purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, VA

Cloudy dark red-amber. Beige head. Complex fruity (cherries, black currants, banana) & malty (caramel, rye bread) aroma. Full, smooth body. Rich, fruity (cherry, banana) & malty (caramel, rye bread) flavour  w/ hints of licorice & raisins. Some woodiness. Lovely dry finish.

brownish prune juice color with a nice tan head and lovely lacing. aroma is huge of very modest alcohol and big on the dark fruits and. flavor also has some alcohol and the darker fruits, but there is a mild roasted bitter chocolatiness to it as well. the spices are not all that perceptible to me, but something about the flavor reminds me very much of abbaye des rocs, and that's a good thing!

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Rerate: The appearance is the same. Aroma is incredible. Caramelly, full of liqourice, has cloves and anise notes, marzipan and I could go on. Very smooth and rounded. Flavour as well is fantastic. Much more rounded and subtle than the fresh one. This in my book is a perfect beer to keep in the cellar for several years. It only grows. 
Bottled: Dark ruby coloured. Clear. Has a light brown quite quickly diminishing head. Aroma is fruity and malty with a good spicy character. Flavour is impressive and complex. Loads of liqourice, fruit (plums and dates) and spices in this co. The high ABV is perfectly hidden. Very well balanced beer, that has a smooth, sweet and alcaholwarming finish. Great beer. 8-4-9-4-18

As I pop the cork on the 750 a blast of raisin aroma emanates form the bottle.  Plum aromas mixed with alcoholic rum like notes escape as I pour this lightly hazy amber-brown beer.  A dense tan to light brown head tops the Noël.  There are some notes of dried fig in the aroma as well, overall a phenomenally enticing aroma to this beer, and I have yet to taste it.The taste; a rich brew, though light bodied given its 10.5% alcohol by volume, by no means light though.  There is some definite spiciness here, seems like some coriander along with some other spices have been used, though because this beer is so rich and fruity it may just be the Belgian yeast character.  This beer finishes with a definite alcoholic bite, though it is not overbearing and goes well with the spice notes.  Lightly sweet with raisin and other dark fruit notes are in the fore front of this beer.  There is no real bitterness, the spices and alcohol counter-point the sweetness and fruity flavors.  This beer is incredibly good, and incredibly under-rated.  I am certainly going to get a couple more bottles of this to age, next winter these could be stunning.  This is just a damn good winter seasonal beer, certainly the best I have had yet this year.

Sticky-sweet caramel highly malty aroma.  No head on a reddish brown body.  Mild carbonation, and a slightly hoppy, but very festively spiced finish.  The flavor is strong with unbalanced malts.  Strange BSA, but overall is a decent beer.

Deep amber in color, little carbonation - begins with a small head that disappears completely - big, "festive" nose, full of plums, figs...fruitcake smelling - flavor has lots of plums, spices, brown sugar, cloves - quite interesting and complex - the finish falls short and is a bit thin - alcohol is well-masked, considering, but is noticable - I think this will really improve with age.

Cork needs little persuasion to leap from the bottle. POP! Aroma reaches my nose before I have a chance to even lift the glass! Deep, dark, sweet roasted fruits. Raisins, figs, licorice. Quite an amazing and complex nose! Color is deep ruby red/amber and clear. Carbonation is light, and what little head there is fades very quickly. (Could it be because of the 10.5% abv?) Quite lively on the tongue. Lots of character. This is very warming, the alcohol is not hidden as well as in some other strong beers. Malt and fruit complexity weave in an out and around and finishes with a warming sensation that is quite relaxing!

The aroma is sweet and fruity with notes of caramel, cloves, and dates. The color is dark brown and it has a beutiful though disappearing beige head. The flavor is very complex - malt sweet with notes of fruits, cloves and dates. A great Christmas brew.

Murky brownish red body topped by a frothy tan head. Lacing is nice and appealing. The aroma is Sweet and malty with a firm yeast backing. The flavor is big and sweet. Much sweeter then the average Beligian Strong. I really like the flavors. The aftertaste is woody and sweet. The body is big and warming. The alcohol is quite noticeable and is very pleasant to drink in cold weather.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2004 Nice and strong(!) Belgian ale. Roasted toffee like aroma. Full body and a warming sweetness ending in a well balanced bitter finish. Perhaps a bit too sweet for me (I had it with duck); am I the only one who notes some licorice?!?
UPDATED: DEC 6, 2004 A very nice and full bodied christmas brew. Loads of dark fruits and warming sweetness. Notes of mint. Very tasty.
Nice dark amber/copper color with a almost non existing beige head. The taste is plums, fruits, slight malt and spices. Finishes very nice with almost port like palate.

(75o ml bottle) Had to flip back in the pages of the notebook to get this review. Deep copper body and an almonde head. "Figs and molasses" came dancing out of Kimchee's mouth while reviewing this beer next to me. Plums, black sour cherries, corriander, leaf spice and yeast flavours. Port finish. Excellent example of a Belgian Strong. I love Kasta for bringing this!

it wasn't christmas when I had this beer, but that muggy august night at capflu's might have well been with all the beers we had.  this one, a surprise that kasta pulled out for the last beer of the evening.  hazy dark with a tan head.  figs and dried fruit, molasses and yeast come dancing out of the glass.  spicy yeasty flavour with chocolate, caramel, raisin, cherry, and black pepper.  warming port like finish.  nicely complex.  a beer on my wishlist I never thought I would get to try.  thanks kasta!

Superb ruby red clear with medium sized shortish lasting tan head. Medium festive fruity and alcohol with hint of just extinguished wax candle aroma. Very smooth medium palate. Fortified wine (port) lightly spiced with hints of chocolate and coffee flavours. Well balanced bitter sweet lightly alcoholic finish.
Ruby red in colour.  Aroma is fruity with dark cherries, chocolate.  Flavour was peppery, yeasty, with some alcohol.  Finishes with some mild bitterness and dry.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2008 Out of a rummy oven comes steaming marzipan candy cakes, sprinkled with cocoa powder...Thick licorice ensconced in old coffee beans, ending up in supporting black pepper...Muscular celebrations call for rich nourishment and this one is ready to step up to the plate everytime...Het Anker really has a knack for those sweet monsters...
I didn't get too much fruitiness like the others, but I did get quite a mint aroma, and even a mint taste. Copper color with a tan head. Finish is slight bitterness and alcohol. Fantastic beer.
strong raisin aroma, dark red, strong dates and raisins, choclatey with a dry finish

Big brwn ale with glints of orange with a wonderfully ripe nose of strawberries, mango, hay and rum.The small white head dissapates quickly, revealing the potent depth of this great Belgian ale, wonderful flavors of ripe tree and vine fruit-pear, blueberry, the afore-mentioned strawberry and mango, etc., with a light spiciness that reminds of cinnamon and nutmeg, but well integrated and noy really identifiable as such. well hidden alcohol under the tangy molasses and brown sugar finish, yet still fairly dry. The Gouden Carolus beers have come a long way back in recent years from the brink of disaster, and this is a great addition to the family.

This one pours a dark reddish brown color with a small tan head that does not linger. The aroma is strongly malty with some fruit and yeast notes. Full body with moderate carbonation, the flavor is richly malty with hints of plums, raisons, and yeasts. The finish is sweet and yeast with a touch of alcohol. Yes, I think Santa would be happy if you left this beer for him instead some stale cookies, I know I would be.

On the pour, the beer appears to be a somewhat caliginous cherry red color, the head Bunyanesque in size, the texture creamy, with sticky sheets of lace to caress the glass. Nose is fruit sweet, over ripe apples and or banana comes to mind, malt tones and light caramel hints also present a treat for the old honker to sniff. The start is honey sweet, the top lean, the finish is pleasantly acidic, cheerfully hopped, dry and somewhat alcohol bitter aftertaste. Yes, it does Warm the Tummy, and should definitely be put in the Winter Warmer category. If you like strong high ABV beer this is a must try, but you may find it a bit pricey at $10.49 a 750ml bottle. Personally I dont mind the price, because Im Worth It Baby!

Highly carbonated, brown head disappeared quickly, leaving no trace. Has a dark brown orange color. Minty orange and vanilla nose at first but then I lost it. Brown sugar and molasses taste. The flavors really blended well at room temp.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2003 Opaque red brown body with a thick tan head with lots of lace.  Spicy malt aroma with a slight sweetness and piney accents.  Sweet malty flavor with a slight spiciness and a touch of alcohol.  A fruitiness reminiscent of cantalope is present.  The finish is spicey and slightly coffeeish.  Dry, full bodied and slightly warming.

Pours dark, aroma of fruit, and alcohol stand out
I think this is a great beer.  Very barlywine like.  Lots of fruit flavors on the palate, sweet, rich.  Full bodied, and full flavored.

Started off badly - irritating wet cardboard taste in the first few sips.  Well, let's let it warm and try again.  Thick, sweet, plum, various unknown spices.  The pieces just don't come together well in this.

Ruby color, poor head retention and no lacing.  The best aspect of this beer is its aroma - malt, figs, spice, and a hint of alcohol.  The flavor is a bit disappointing given the nose, but definitely not bad, just a little thin.  Effervescent, medium body, a bit of alcohol in the finish.  Not on the same level as some of the elite Belgian strong ales, but quite enjoyable and one of the better Christmas beers I've tried.

This beer poured a deep reddish amber color and formed a light tan bubbly head that left some circular lace. Quite a bit of carbonation is present. An aroma of malt, caramel, spices and dark fruit. A flavor of malt, caramel and fruits. Some elements of spices such as cinnamon and nutmeg are also present. A very heavy flavor presence to this beer.
dark ruby-brown colour, fine head, deep aroma of banana and port wine with notes of spices and licorice, full-bodied, sweet and heavy with a long dry bitter and alcohol finish

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2003 ReRate: 750 corked [2003 fresh]:Murky mahogany copper rests in the glass as a patch-work of wispy taupe coloured clouds disperse like the Pangaea of old. . . The aroma fills my nostrils and head with sharp anise, nutmeg, tea leaves, cherry skin and fruity dough.  Full spicy flavour that begins with white grape skin, buttered toast , bitter cranberries and finishes with coarse black pepper and other spices.

Orginal [2002 fresh] (3.5): Dark brown, minimal head, but lingering. . . Nice nutty/malty aroma. . . Good amount of alcohol on the palate, good spices in the back of the mouth and on the way down.  Lingering malty flavours with some fruit, another great Christmas present.

Very tasty ale.  Malty and creamy, the mouthfeel is so soft that you hardly know it's there.  The aroma is fantastic, I don't know what it is but it smells great.  I need an air freshener that smells like this.  10.5% very well hidden. I like this brewery so far.

The aroma is malty and soapy with notes of caramel, yeast, winter spices and a whisper of mint and alcohol.
Sparkling clear, deep ruby hue with a copper tint. Large, frothy khaki-colored head. Mostly lasting with very impressive lacework.
The flavor starts with pears and fuzzy fruits with blasts of caramel, toffee and butter. Nicely balanced with light bitterness on the backside. The high ABV is fairly well-hidden.
Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Medium-length, acrid and dry finish.
Very good Belgian ale excepting an unfamiliar, and not entirely welcomed, hop or spice addition.

Pours a deep red color with a nice tan/off-white head.  The aroma is sweet and fruity, marked by apples, cherries, prunes, raisin, and alcohol.  Nice fruit in the flavor, but also a bit of nut, whole grain, caramel and subtle spices.  A nice holiday brew even though it's been awhile.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2004 2002:  Light chestnut. Dense, rocky, light tan foam.  Fruitcakey malt amid oodles of plum, fig, and bubblegum notes. Hints of icorice, ginger, butter rum, clove, aniseed, mint, and rock candy. Firm, velvety carbonation. Chewy. Huge fruitiness mixed of aniseed and  plummy malts. Traces of mint and ginger. Beautiful finish shows long notes of caramel malt breadinesss and licorice. Lingering fruitcake flavors with soft spices.There's nothing quite like this. A winner of a holiday brew.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Medium brown color with a good sized head sittin atop.  Muted dark flavors with black licorice, plum, raisins, and some cherries.  Noticable alcohol with some balanced hops.
Good ale goes down warm.  Creamy malty carmel flavor.  Well hidden Abv. Recommended

Dark amber/garnet color with a bit of cloudiness.  Tan foamy head.  Spicy aroma with licorice dominating. AS this one warms smells more like night time cold medicine.  Tastes like licorice infused date.  Nice solid mouth feel.  Unfortunately I am not a fan of either  licorice or date.   This is a well made beer, but it contains flavors I do not favor. 
For the right person, this is a awesome beer, bbut my overall is a personal one.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2003 Totally different after aged a year. It was a black licorice catastrophe but now yields delicious flavors of ripe plums and juicy raisons. Alcohol is better masked and aftertaste is complex and yeasty.
Reddish body, huge head, sweet malty and fruity nose. My second 10+ ABV of the night; not a good idea. ;) Lots of fruit in the body, with some mild spice. Pretty good stuff.

Hazy red brown body with big light beige head.  Aroma is sweet, anise and alcohol -- the mix comes out something like spiked root beer.  Flavor is much the same -- rich, sweet, anise and root beer, with pleasant alcohol flavor.  Delicious winter brew!

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 750mL bottle (Jun 2014 bottling). Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain/bread/pastry), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of sassafras, peppermint, anise/fennel, raisin, cinnamon. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Not as good as the 2013 batch...the nose is quieter and simpler, and it seems a bit more watery in texture...the 2013 was richer, more luxurious, and more complex. Still very nice, especially in the flavor balance (most of these things are overly sweet), for a spiced Belgian strong ale, but not a 4+ this time.
Bottled. Dark amber. Intense and complex nose; esters, port, dried fruit and banana. Reasonably dry and malty with lightly bitter finish. An excellent ale full of character!

Dark -deep coulour with obvious reddish shine. Nose of madeira, raisins, roasted malts and molasses. Taste immediately spritzy acidity, then fruity & estery. In aftertaste fruity character has again fruit-acids in it. Palate is however thinnish, but with alcohol-throatwarming effect.

This was great to smell and look at, but there wasnt much substance to it.  Rather bland in the mouth and acutally too smooth if one can picture something with not much taste, but easily drinkable.  I liked it and recommend it, but there are better examples out there.
Brilliant red amber beer with a medium creamy head. Spicy, koriander?, aroma. Very spicy, sweet full taste. A wonderful beer.
Bizarre spices.  Candyish, but its got a bit of smokiness.  Almost meaty, in some strange way.  Cant identify it, but didnt particularly enjoy it.
